questions.explanation: There are many reasons why you might lose your CDL for a year in California, including alcohol, crimes, and serious traffic violations such as hit and run.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a likely consequence of having several licenses?
questions.answer3: Having your California CDL canceled
questions.explanation: Having more than one license is a very serious matter. The first time you are convicted, you will be fined, sent to jail, or have your CDL canceled.

questions.question: Unless the cargo you're transporting is interstate, you're deemed to be engaging in interstate commerce in California.
questions.answer2: originates in the state and is headed for a location in the state.
questions.answer3: consists of waste or other hazardous substances.
questions.answer4: is headed for a location out of state.
questions.explanation: The only situation that does not qualify as interstate commerce is cargo originating in California and staying in the state.

questions.question: In a seven-day period, you are only allowed to drive for a total of ___ hours.
questions.explanation: In a seven-day period, you may only be on duty for 60 hours. If your employer operates 7 days a week, you are not eligible to be on duty after 70 hours in eight days. You must then take 34 or more consecutive hours off duty.

questions.question: What should you do if you're in a car accident that results in death, injury, or property damage of more than $1,000?
questions.answer2: Stop driving your vehicle for 10 days.
questions.answer3: File an official report on form SR-1 within 10 days.
questions.explanation: If any such incidents occur, you must file an official report, using Form SR-1, within 10 days. Your employer will have its own rules about company reporting and driving its trucks.

questions.question: Any traffic offenses (excluding parking) must be reported to your employer within how many days?
questions.explanation: If you have a traffic violation in any vehicle you are driving (including your personal vehicle), you must notify your employer within 30 days.

questions.question: What is the most crucial and evident reason to examine your vehicle, according to the state of California?
questions.answer3: To see if your vehicle needs a wash
questions.answer4: To make sure your paint is not chipped
questions.explanation: Safety is the most important thing. Inspections can help you avoid costly and dangerous breakdowns and collisions. Federal and state inspectors will check your vehicle, so you must make sure it's safe; otherwise, they may put it out of service for violations.

questions.question: Which of the following is a step in the seven-step inspection process?
questions.answer3: Step 6: Check the Signal Lights
questions.explanation: The Seven-Step Inspection Method includes 1. Vehicle Overview; 2. Check Engine Compartment; 3. Start Engine and Inspect Inside the Cab; 4. Turn off Engine and Check Lights; 5. Do Walk Around Inspection; 6. Check Signal Lights; 7. Start the Engine and Check.

questions.question: Which of these should you undertake as part of your en route check during a trip?
questions.answer1: Watch your gauges to check for trouble.
questions.answer2: Pay attention with your senses to possible problems.
questions.answer3: Check critical items when you stop, such as brakes, tires, and lights.
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should be staying very alert to the situation, using your senses and gauges to stay aware, and checking critical items at stops.

questions.question: During a seven-step inspection, the engine compartment is not included
questions.answer2: the coolant level in the radiator.
questions.answer3: the oil pressure gauge.
questions.explanation: Checking your engine compartment consists of checking several fluid levels contained within. The oil pressure gauge is checked in a different step.

questions.question: You double-check your seatbelt to make sure that
questions.answer2: it matches the color of the rest of your cab.
questions.answer3: it is original equipment.
questions.answer4: it has six yards of slack.
questions.explanation: You should inspect your seat belt to be sure that it is securely mounted, not ripped or frayed, and latches properly. Color and other aesthetics are not important, and six yards is way too much slack.

questions.question: The steps for checking your signal lights include the following
questions.answer1: Turn off all lights, turn on the stop lights, and turn on the left turn signal lights.
questions.answer2: Turn on all lights, turn on the stop lights, and turn on the left turn signal lights.
questions.answer3: Turn off all lights, turn on the left turn signal lights, and turn on the stop lights.
questions.answer4: Turn on the stop lights, turn off all lights, and turn on the left turn signal lights.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your signal lights, the first step is to turn off all lights. Next, turn on your stop lights by applying the hand brake or having your partner apply the brake pedal. Then turn on the left turn signal lights.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a rule to follow if you want to back up safely?
questions.answer1: Back slowly while using your mirrors.
questions.answer2: Make use of a helper as often as possible.
questions.answer3: Accelerate slightly to complete the backing process quickly.
questions.answer4: Combine backing and turning toward the driver's side whenever you can.
questions.explanation: Backing safely involves taking it slowly: Look around, watch your path as well as your mirrors, and pay attention to your helper's signals. You should never have to accelerate while backing.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the basic shifting method?
questions.answer2: Push in the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time.
questions.answer3: Release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time.
questions.answer4: Accelerate while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side.
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, push in the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, push in the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: According to the Handbook, how far ahead do most good drivers look?
questions.answer3: 12 to 15 seconds
questions.explanation: Good drivers look ahead for 12 to 15 seconds; that is, the distance that the vehicle will travel in 12 to 15 seconds. At highway speeds, that could be about a quarter of a mile.

questions.question: Retarders
questions.answer1: reduce wear and tear on the brakes.
questions.answer2: apply braking power to the drive wheels.
questions.answer3: reduce the need to apply the brakes to slow the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Retarders, of which there are many types, apply braking power directly to the drive wheels so that you will not need to use your brakes as often.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an acceptable method of signaling?
questions.answer2: Flash your signals to draw more attention.
questions.answer3: Turn your signal off after completing the maneuver.
questions.answer4: Signal continuously until you have completed your turn.
questions.explanation: Flashing your turn signals is unnecessary. Simply follow the rules: Signal early and continuously, and then cancel the signal after completing the maneuver. Flashing lights unnecessarily is especially dangerous at night.

questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations Part 392.22, issued by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA). Those regulations also specify where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as two-way roads and curves.

questions.question: Which of the following sums up to the entire stopping distance?
questions.answer2: Perception distance + reaction distance + braking distance
questions.answer3: Perception distance + reaction distance
questions.answer4: Reaction distance + braking distance + signal distance
questions.explanation: Total stopping distance is the sum of your perception distance (how far the vehicle goes from when you see the hazard until your brain processes it), reaction distance (how far the vehicle goes from when your brain orders your foot to take action until your foot actually starts to brake), and braking distance (how far the vehicle continues to travel once you apply the brake).

questions.question: When driving in heavy traffic, what is the safest speed?
questions.answer2: The speed of other traffic (if not illegal or unsafe)
questions.answer3: 15 mph below the speed of other traffic
questions.answer4: As fast as possible, to get out of the way
questions.explanation: When you drive at the speed of other traffic, you do not have to constantly pass others or be passed by them, making collisions less likely. However, you should not attempt to keep up with drivers who drive faster than the speed limit for commercial motor vehicles (CMVs).

questions.question: When you're being tailgated, which of the following should you avoid?
questions.answer3: Avoid tricks such as flashing your brake lights.
questions.explanation: Most tailgaters aren't deterred by the vehicle ahead exceeding the speed limit. Do not fall into the trap of increasing your speed to get away from or appease a tailgater. Simply continue at a safe speed and, if possible, move into another lane to let the tailgater pass.

questions.question: Which of the following statements concerning the relationship between cargo and height is correct?
questions.answer1: The weight of the cargo changes a vehicle's height.
questions.answer2: The weight of the cargo does not change a vehicle's height.
questions.answer3: An empty van is lower than a loaded one.
questions.answer4: The height of an empty van is the same as that of a loaded one.
questions.explanation: Cargo changes the height of a vehicle and thus can affect your overhead clearance. If you previously had cargo and now your vehicle is empty, it will ride higher, not lower, so you may not clear underpasses you previously did.

questions.question: Which of these is not an issue with other drivers when driving at night?
questions.answer3: Lack of alertness from fatigue
questions.explanation: Other drivers may experience problems with their vision, glare, and fatigue that will make them hazards on the road, but hunger is not considered a problem for American drivers.

questions.question: Which of the following are indications of a drunk driver?
questions.answer1: Trouble staying in his or her own lane
questions.answer2: Difficulty maintaining his or her speed
questions.answer3: Stopping suddenly for no apparent reason
questions.explanation: Drivers under the influence tend to drive like a drunk friend at a party walks: They can't stay in their lane, they suddenly stop, and they slow down or speed up for no reason.

questions.question: Which of the following should you avoid doing at night while driving?
questions.answer2: Avoid glare from the headlights of oncoming vehicles.
questions.answer3: Avoid using your high beams, just in case.
questions.explanation: Use your high beams to see farther, as long as you are not within 500 feet of an approaching vehicle.

questions.question: If you have a flat tire, you should not do which of the following?
questions.answer3: Apply the brakes hard and immediately.
questions.answer4: Be aware that a tire has failed.
questions.explanation: While it's natural to want to take control of the situation by braking, slamming on your brakes could actually cause you to lose control of your vehicle, so brake slowly after you have regained control of the vehicle.

questions.question: An antilock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: not change the way you brake normally.
questions.explanation: ABS only kicks in to prevent the wheels from locking up when you brake hard. ABS does not change the way you normally brake. It doesn't eliminate the need for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, and good maintenance.

questions.question: During a drive wheel skid, which of the following should you NOT do?
questions.answer3: Steer into the skid.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles have a tendency to keep right on turning, which means you could find yourself skidding the opposite way unless you countersteer.

questions.question: If you're in a car accident, you should
questions.answer2: do the best you can to care for injured persons.
questions.answer3: gather appropriate information for a collision report.
questions.explanation: When involved in a collision, there are several steps that you should take, including gathering the information needed for the report you must file, helping the injured, and notifying the authorities.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a common source of vehicle fires?
questions.answer3: Halogen headlights
questions.explanation: Halogen bulbs, when installed properly, are not dangerous. However, flammable cargo, underinflated tires, and problems in the electrical system can all cause fires.

questions.question: Which types of flames can be extinguished with an A, B, or C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Gasoline
questions.explanation: The B: C type fire extinguisher is designed to work on electrical fires and burning liquids. The A: B: C type is designed to work on burning wood, paper, and cloth as well. To fight a fire in combustible metals, you need a specialized D type fire extinguisher.

questions.question: You should do the following to assist you stay aware and safe while driving:
questions.answer1: avoid medications whose warning labels mention drowsiness.
questions.answer2: drink coffee if you get drowsy.
questions.answer3: roll down your windows to get fresh air.
questions.answer4: have a whiskey to brace yourself.
questions.explanation: Be careful with medications that warn you they may cause drowsiness. If you have a concern about prescribed medications, speak to your doctor. Do not try to fight sleepiness with coffee, fresh air, or especially alcohol. The only cure for feeling tired is sleeping until you are rested.

questions.question: When driving in extremely hot weather, which of the following is NOT a major concern?
questions.answer1: Driving slowly enough to prevent overheating
questions.answer2: Tar bubbling up and causing slippery roadways
questions.answer3: Your seat belt causing you to sweat
questions.explanation: When it is extremely hot, you should be keeping an eye on going slowly, checking your vehicle's belts for the water pump and fan, and tar "bleeding." Discomfort from the seat belt is of lesser concern.

questions.question: Your car has become stranded on railroad tracks. You ought to
questions.answer1: immediately get out of the cab and move away from the tracks.
questions.answer2: try to save some of the cargo if you don't see a train yet.
questions.answer3: gather up your belongings and paperwork and then leave the cab.
questions.answer4: keep trying to move your vehicle until you see the train.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks, your safety comes first. Immediately leave the vehicle and get away. Do not risk your life to save belongings, paperwork, cargo, or even the vehicle.

questions.question: Children, according to the Handbook, are a danger because
questions.answer1: they move quickly without checking traffic.
questions.answer2: they often have grudges against truck drivers.
questions.answer3: they don't know how to drive.
questions.answer4: they don't know that trucks are dangerous.
questions.explanation: Most children allowed to play outside are old enough to understand the danger of large vehicles. Often, however, they do not check for traffic before running into the street.

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in your first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: smoke, eat, and drink on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no other vehicles around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. If possible, turn off your phone and keep it off until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: Start the engine and inspect the inside of the cab is the third phase in the seven-step inspection process.This step involves each of the following tasks, EXCEPT
questions.answer3: starting the engine, then listening for unusual noises.
questions.answer4: starting the engine, then putting the gearshift in neutral.
questions.explanation: When performing this part of the inspection, you must put the gear shift in neutral, then start the engine and listen for any unusual noises. Once you perform the engine check, check all your gauges and controls, such as the air pressure gauge and transmission controls.

questions.question: Your safety gear must include the following items:
questions.answer1: spare electrical fuses, but only if your vehicle has circuit breakers.
questions.answer2: three red reflective triangles to be used as warning devices.
questions.answer3: spare brake drums.
questions.explanation: Spare electrical fuses are required only if your vehicle DOES NOT have circuit breakers. Brake drums and axles may need to be replaced at times, but they are not a normal part of your safety equipment.

questions.question: How speed you should reduce when you drive on wet roads?
questions.answer3: one-third.
questions.explanation: When a road is wet, stopping distance is increased, and you should reduce your speed by one-third. On snow, slow to one-half your usual speed. On icy roads, slow to a crawl and stop driving as soon as you can do so safely.

questions.question: Checking your vehicle's suspension does NOT include checking
questions.answer3: the tires.
questions.explanation: Checking the suspension includes checking the springs, axles, shock absorbers, torque rods or arms, etc. The tires are on a different checklist.

questions.question: At what speed should you test the service brakes' stopping power?
questions.answer3: 2 mph
questions.explanation: To test the stopping action of your service brakes, you should go at about 5 mph and press the brake pedal firmly. If the vehicle pulls to one side or stopping takes longer than normal, it could mean trouble.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a basic skill needed to operate a commercial vehicle?
questions.answer3: Ability to back the vehicle safely
questions.explanation: You must be proficient in several driving skills such as steering and backing, but no one can multitask and drive well. Unfortunately, many people have mistakenly thought they could, which is why there have been so many accidents caused by texting while driving.

questions.question: When you back with a trailer, you should
questions.answer1: turn the steering wheel in the same direction in which you want to go.
questions.answer3: not pull forward once you have started backing.
questions.answer4: back in as straight a line as possible.
questions.explanation: Try to keep everything straight while backing. This involves correcting drift as soon as it occurs and backing as straight as you can. You must also turn the wheel opposite to the direction in which you want to go. Then turn the wheel the other way once the trailer starts to turn. Pull forward as often as needed to make corrections and reposition.

questions.question: When evaluating hoses with the instructor during your pre-trip examination, seek for
questions.answer3: frays in the water pump belt.
questions.answer4: a low windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: During your pre-trip test, when inspecting hoses, you need to look for signs of leaks and cracks, such as puddles on the ground and fluids that are dripping on the underside of the engine or transmission. Also check hoses for leaks or problems.

questions.question: After your pre-trip inspection, you should inspect your cargo
questions.answer1: within 25 miles of the start of the trip.
questions.answer2: within 50 miles of the start of the trip.
questions.answer3: within an hour after starting the trip.
questions.answer4: within 10 miles of the start of the trip.
questions.explanation: Inspect the cargo and its securing devices again within the first 50 miles of the start of the trip. Make any adjustments needed.

questions.question: A top-heavy load is hazardous because it can cause
questions.answer2: a rollover if you swerve around a hazard.
questions.answer3: damage to the axles or steering.
questions.explanation: A top-heavy load raises your vehicle's center of gravity so that you're much more likely to roll over on a curve or if you swerve to avoid a hazard. A top-heavy load is also an unbalanced load, which can damage certain parts of your vehicle, such as the axles.

questions.question: The aggregate working load limit of your cargo tiedowns must be at least ______ times the weight of the cargo.
questions.answer3: one-half
questions.explanation: Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations Part 393.106, issued by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA), requires the aggregate working load limit of any securement system used to secure an article or group of articles against movement to be at least one-half times the weight of the article or group of articles.

questions.question: Flags or lights are required on projecting loads that extend
questions.answer1: 4 or more feet beyond the rear body.
questions.answer2: 3 or more feet beyond the rear body.
questions.answer3: 6 or more feet beyond the rear body.
questions.answer4: 56 inches or more beyond the rear body.
questions.explanation: A load that extends 4 feet or more beyond the rear body of the vehicle is considered a projecting load and thus requires a 12-inch-square red or fluorescent orange flag in the daytime and two lit red lights visible for 500 feet at night.

questions.question: What is the gross vehicle weight (GVW)?
questions.answer1: A vehicle's maximum weight rating, specified by its manufacturer
questions.answer2: The total weight of the vehicle, including the load and any trailers
questions.answer3: The total weight of a single vehicle and its load
questions.explanation: GVW is the weight of a single vehicle plus the weight of the load that it is carrying.

questions.question: Legal maximum weight limits may not be safe in all of the following, EXCEPT
questions.answer3: a storm.
questions.explanation: Maximum weight limits may not always be safe, especially in bad weather or steep mountain driving. Traffic is a fact of life, though.

questions.question: How speed you should reduce when you drive on wet roads?
questions.answer3: one-third.
questions.explanation: When a road is wet, stopping distance is increased, and you should reduce your speed by one-third. On snow, slow to one-half your usual speed. On icy roads, slow to a crawl and stop driving as soon as you can do so safely.

questions.question: Why should you cover cargo?
questions.answer1: To protect individuals from any spilled cargo
questions.answer2: To protect your cargo from bad weather
questions.answer3: Because many states require it
questions.explanation: There are several reasons to cover your cargo, including protecting other people and the cargo itself. It will also help you comply with regulations in several states.

questions.question: Letting the air out of hot tires
questions.answer1: is a good idea because the extra pressure will be relieved.
questions.answer2: is a bad idea because when the tires cool off, the pressure will be too low.
questions.answer3: will have no effect at all.
questions.answer4: will cool them down. You will be able to continue your journey sooner.
questions.explanation: When tires get hot, the air pressure increases. However, relieving that extra pressure will leave the air pressure too low when the tires cool again, and then the tires may catch fire or blow out. If your tires are too hot to touch, stop until they have cooled down.

questions.question: Always try to back toward the driver's side because
questions.answer1: it's more comfortable for turning your neck.
questions.answer2: you can see better, watching the vehicle's rear out the side window.
questions.answer3: your truck will naturally pull toward the driver's side.
questions.answer4: all of the above are true.
questions.explanation: You should always back toward the driver's side because you will be able to see things much more easily. For example, you can keep an eye on the vehicle's rear by viewing it out your side window. If your truck pulls in either direction, it needs service, and your neck's comfort should not affect your safety decision.

questions.question: The minimum tread depth for front tires, according to the Colorado Commercial Driver License Manual, is
questions.answer3: 1/2-inch.
questions.explanation: According to the Colorado Commercial Driver License Manual, the tires on the steering axle should have at least 4/32 inch of tread, and all other tires should have at least 2/32 inch of tread. This is a federal requirement. However, under a new Colorado law that went into effect on August 2, 2019, the minimum tire tread on all vehicles in Colorado from September 1 to May 31 is now 3/16 inch (6/32 inch), which exceeds the federal requirement. This requirement applies to I-70 from Morrison at mile marker 259 to Dotsero at mile marker 133. Furthermore, CMVs with a gross combined weight rating of 26,001 pounds or more are required to have four or more drive wheels covered with an appropriate traction device. Approved traction devices include tire chains, tire sanders, tire spinners, and Autosocks. (Buses must cover two drive wheels to comply.) CMVs with fewer than four drive wheels must have all drive wheels covered with an appropriate traction device. [C.R.S. § 42-4-106]

questions.question: Which of the following should NOT be checked during a trip?
questions.answer3: Text messages
questions.explanation: You should keep an eye on all of your vehicle's key systems during your trip, such as the instruments, gauges, tires, voltmeter, mirrors, and cargo. Make sure you put your phone away for the entire journey.

questions.question: How often do you have to pull over to inspect your goods while driving?
questions.answer3: Every 3 hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, it's a good idea to check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your journey. While you should then check it as often as necessary, the manual recommends every 3 hours or 150 miles as a rule of thumb.

questions.question: Before transporting a sealed load, you must inspect
questions.answer1: a small sample of whatever is inside.
questions.answer2: a picture of whatever is inside.
questions.answer3: that you don't exceed gross weight and axle weight limits.
questions.explanation: You cannot actually inspect sealed loads, but it's still your responsibility to ensure that you do not exceed your axle weight limits or gross weight restrictions.

questions.question: If you are drowsy, what action should you take before driving farther?
questions.answer2: Open your vehicle's windows for some fresh air.
questions.answer3: Pull off the road and get some sleep.
questions.explanation: You cannot make drowsiness disappear by drinking coffee or other caffeinated beverages or by getting fresh air. They may make you feel more alert momentarily, but the only real solution is to get off the road and get some rest.

questions.question: If you have a flat tire, you should not do which of the following?
questions.answer3: Engage the brakes hard and immediately.
questions.answer4: Be aware that a tire has failed.
questions.explanation: Braking could cause the vehicle to go out of control, so brake gently only after the vehicle has slowed down.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: There is no quick way to get alcohol out of your system. Coffee or fresh air will not do it. You must wait until you are sober or else risk losing your CDL if you drive.

questions.question: How many tie-downs are required for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tie-down per ten feet of cargo, and at least two tie-downs per load regardless of its length. So for 20 feet, you would have two.

questions.question: Which of the following determine(s) the safe speed for going down a steep downgrade?
questions.answer1: The total weight of the vehicle and cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: To select a safe speed for going down a steep downgrade, you should consider such factors as its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations Part 392.22, issued by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA). Those regulations also specify where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as two-way roads and curves.

questions.question: The most significant hand gesture on which you and your assistance should both agree is
questions.answer3: Stop.
questions.explanation: You and your helper must agree on a hand signal for "stop" so that you'll be able to stop what you are doing before an incident occurs.

questions.question: How many seconds does it take for a normal tractor-trailer to clear a double track?
questions.answer3: More than 30 seconds
questions.explanation: You can expect it to take more than 15 seconds for a regular tractor-trailer to clear a double track, and 14 seconds to be safely over a single track.

questions.question: How do you get started without rolling backwards?
questions.answer1: Put on the parking brake whenever necessary.
questions.answer2: Engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake.
questions.answer3: Apply the trailer brake hand valve.
questions.explanation: If you have a manual transmission vehicle, partly engage the clutch before you take your right foot off the brake. Put on the parking brake whenever necessary to keep from rolling back. Release the parking brake only when you have applied enough engine power to keep from rolling back. On a tractor-trailer equipped with a trailer brake hand valve, the hand valve can be applied to keep from rolling back.

questions.question: In which two special conditions should you downshift?
questions.answer1: Starting down a hill and entering a curve
questions.answer2: Starting up a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer3: Starting down a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer4: Starting up a hill and entering a curve
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill allows you to take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required to climb the hill or lower. Downshifting before a curve improves stability and ensures that you will have the power to accelerate out of the turn.

questions.question: Which of the following retarder assertions is true?
questions.answer1: Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for using your brakes.
questions.answer2: When your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarder may cause them to skid.
questions.answer3: You should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow-covered.
questions.answer4: All of these answers are correct.
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should always turn off your retarder in poor weather.

questions.question: What is Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW)?
questions.answer1: A vehicle's maximum weight rating, specified by its manufacturer
questions.answer2: The total weight of the vehicle, towed vehicles, and the load
questions.answer3: The total weight of a single vehicle and its load
questions.explanation: Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW) is the weight of just a single vehicle and the load that it is carrying.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key steering component?
questions.answer3: Gear box
questions.explanation: The gear box is an integral part of the steering system. All the other choices are key parts of the suspension system.

questions.question: When evaluating hoses with the instructor during your pre-trip examination, seek for
questions.answer3: frays in the water pump belt.
questions.explanation: During your pre-trip test, when inspecting hoses, you need to look for signs of leaks, such as puddles on the ground or fluids that are dripping on the underside of the engine or transmission. Also check the hoses for leaks or other problems.

questions.question: How do you know if your vehicle has an anti-lock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for yellow ABS malfunction lamps on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the basic shifting method?
questions.answer2: Push in the clutch and shift into higher gear at the same time.
questions.answer3: Release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time.
questions.answer4: Accelerate while pressing the clutch and turn toward the driver's side.
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, push in the clutch and shift to neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, push in the clutch and shift into higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: What is the definition of a hazard?
questions.answer2: A road user or road condition that could present a possible danger
questions.answer3: Something you must stop for
questions.explanation: A hazard is something that could go wrong but shouldn't if you've been vigilant.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true about an escape ramp?
questions.answer1: It may be located a few miles from the top of a downgrade.
questions.answer2: It is of no use if you are traveling too fast.
questions.answer3: It may be made of soft gravel.
questions.explanation: Escape ramps are designed with soft gravel, turning uphill, or both, to slow down vehicles that experience brake failure on a downgrade. Regardless of your speed, look for one of these escape ramps, which can save lives, equipment, and cargo.

questions.question: If you are traveling at 55 mph in a 30-foot vehicle, you should leave ___ seconds of following distance.
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. So for a 30-foot vehicle going 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are
questions.answer1: signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo.
questions.answer2: signs on the inside of the vehicle that remind the driver what he is carrying.
questions.answer3: signs that help tax collectors determine how much to tax hazardous cargo.
questions.answer4: signs that warn the public to stay at least 1000 feet away from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are four regulated signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo for those who need to know, such as emergency service personnel or those who load and unload cargo.

questions.question: To avoid becoming a distracted driver,
questions.answer1: turn off your cell phone if possible until you reach your destination.
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in the first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: smoke, eat, and drink on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no cars around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. If possible, turn off your phone and keep it off until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: An anti-lock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: keep your brakes from locking up when you brake hard.
questions.explanation: ABS kicks in only to keep the wheels from locking up, which could cause a skid. ABS does not change the way you normally brake the rest of the time. It is not a substitute for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, or regular maintenance.

questions.question: If you are convicted of a second DUI offense in either a CMV or your personal vehicle, how long will you lose your CDL driving privileges?
questions.answer3: Life
questions.explanation: A second DUI offense, regardless of the vehicle being driven, will cause you to lose your CDL for life. Consider your first DUI a wake-up call and a chance to get help - because your second offense will mean unemployment in your chosen profession.

questions.question: The temperature has just dropped to freezing. Which of the following areas may be slippery?
questions.answer3: A road that looks wet
questions.explanation: Once the temperature dips down to freezing, some sections of the roadway will begin to freeze, starting with shaded areas and bridges. A road that looks wet may have a layer of black ice, which is slippery.

questions.question: To maintain alertness during the trip, drivers should
questions.answer1: schedule trips during the daytime hours.
questions.answer3: avoid medications that cause drowsiness.
questions.explanation: Sleep debt is a dangerous condition in which missing sleep adds up and you risk falling asleep at the wheel until you are fully rested. People are often surprised when they find out that getting less than six hours of sleep per night triples your risk of accident. To prevent drowsiness before a trip, the driver should get adequate sleep (adults need 8 to 9 hours to maintain alertness); prepare route carefully to identify total distance, stopping points and other logistic considerations; schedule trips for the hours you are normally awake, not the middle of the night; drive with a passenger; avoid medications that cause drowsiness; consult your physician if you suffer from daytime sleepiness, have difficulty sleeping at night or take frequent naps; incorporate exercise into your daily life to give you more energy.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When your speed doubles, your stopping distance nearly quadruples (i.e., four times as much). For example, doubling your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 148 feet.

questions.question: Total stopping distance equals
questions.answer3: perception distance + reaction distance + braking distance.
questions.answer4: reaction distance + viewing distance + braking distance.
questions.explanation: Total stopping distance is the sum of your perception distance (how far the vehicle goes from when you see the hazard until your brain processes it), reaction distance (how far the vehicle goes from when your brain orders your foot to take action until your foot actually starts to brake), and braking distance (how far the vehicle continues to travel once you apply the brake).

questions.question: In your emergency kit, you do not need to have
questions.answer3: a fire extinguisher.
questions.explanation: While a jacket might keep you comfortable, it is not a required part of your emergency kit. You must have a working fire extinguisher, warning devices, and spare electrical fuses (unless your vehicle has circuit breakers).

questions.question: When backing, it is important to use a helper
questions.answer2: because people feel more comfortable when you do.
questions.answer3: because you are providing a job for someone else.
questions.answer4: for all of the above reasons.
questions.explanation: Using a helper when you are backing is important since you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals - especially "stop."

questions.question: Which of the following types of vehicles can be operated without a CDL?
questions.answer1: Military vehicles operated by active duty personnel
questions.answer2: Emergency snow plowing vehicles, used during emergency snow removal situations
questions.answer3: Farm vehicles, if operated by a farmer within 150 miles of the individual's farm
questions.explanation: There are several types of vehicles that can be operated without a CDL but only under certain conditions. Check the list in the Colorado Commercial Driver License Manual or contact the Colorado DMV for details.

questions.question: What is the best way to calculate how many seconds of following distance you have?
questions.answer1: Wait until a vehicle passes a shadow or landmark and start to count the seconds until you reach it.
questions.answer2: Get 1/4 closer to the car in front of you and then back off again. Multiply how long this has taken you by four.
questions.answer3: Use the stopwatch on your cell phone to determine how long it takes you to reach a mile marker after the car in front of you has passed it.
questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to reach some object after the car in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here either will not work or involve dangerous distractions. Note that you should increase your following distance in heavy traffic, in bad weather, with heavy vehicles, or at higher speeds.

questions.question: How far ahead should drivers look while driving, according to the manual?
questions.answer3: 12 to 15 seconds
questions.explanation: Good drivers look ahead for 12 to 15 seconds; i.e., the distance that your CMV will travel in that time. At highway speeds, this is about 1/4 mile.

questions.question: On which of the following types of fires should you NOT use a B:C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Wood
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher should not be used on burning materials that you can use regular water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: Any of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide, a driver might try to pass you on your right while you are turning. Instead, make the turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This denies drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: While performing the pre-trip inspection, you should place the starter switch key into your pocket because
questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.
questions.answer3: it could damage the starting mechanism.
questions.answer4: all of the above could happen.
questions.explanation: While you are performing the pre-trip inspection, you do not want someone who doesn't know you're underneath the truck to start the engine and move the truck.

questions.question: While driving at night, which beams should you use as often as you can?
questions.answer3: Emergency flashers
questions.explanation: When driving at night, you should use your high beams to expand your field of vision as often as possible, as long as it is safe and legal and you will not blind any other drivers. The rule of thumb is to use high beams as long as there are no approaching vehicles within 500 feet.

questions.question: To transport cargo safely, which of these are you NOT responsible for?
questions.answer3: Making sure that cargo is properly secured
questions.answer4: Ensuring the freshness of sealed cargo
questions.explanation: You are not responsible for the state of sealed cargo, nor can you inspect it. You are only responsible for the safety of the cargo, ensuring that it is balanced, secured, and not overloaded, and does not get in the way of emergency equipment.

questions.question: Do empty trucks have the best braking?
questions.answer3: Yes, but only on wet surfaces.
questions.answer4: Yes, but only if the trucks are newer than 1998.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are being used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have greater stopping distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels.

questions.question: Each of the following tasks is involved in starting the engine and inspecting the cab, EXCEPT
questions.answer3: starting the engine, then listening for unusual noises.
questions.answer4: starting the engine, then putting the gearshift in neutral.
questions.explanation: When performing this part of the inspection, you must put the gearshift in neutral, then start the engine and listen for any unusual noises. Once you perform the engine check, check all your gauges and controls, such as the air pressure gauge and transmission controls.

questions.question: You should do the following to assist you stay aware and safe while driving:
questions.answer1: avoid medications whose warning labels mention drowsiness.
questions.answer2: drink coffee if you get drowsy.
questions.answer3: roll down your windows to get fresh air.
questions.answer4: have a whiskey to brace yourself.
questions.explanation: Be careful with medications that warn you they may cause drowsiness. If you have a concern about prescribed medications, speak with your doctor. Do not try to fight sleepiness with coffee, fresh air, or especially alcohol. The only "cure" for being tired is sleeping until you are rested.

questions.question: What is a common cause of tire fires?
questions.answer3: Cold tires
questions.explanation: Underinflated tires and dual tires that touch are the most common causes of tire fires.

questions.question: Always try to back toward the driver's side because
questions.answer1: it's more comfortable for turning your neck.
questions.answer2: you can see better, watching the vehicle's rear from the side window.
questions.answer3: your truck will probably pull toward the driver's side.
questions.answer4: all of the above are true.
questions.explanation: You should always back toward the driver's side because you will be able to see things much more easily. For example, you can keep an eye on the vehicle's rear by viewing it from your side window. If your truck pulls in either direction, it needs service. Your neck's comfort should not affect your safety decision.

questions.question: The minimum tire tread depth for front tires is
questions.answer3: 1/2 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels and any visible evidence of cracks or leaks.

questions.question: Which of the following should NOT be checked during a trip?
questions.answer3: Text messages
questions.explanation: During your trip, you should keep an eye on all of your vehicle's key systems, such as the instruments, gauges, tires, voltmeter, mirrors, and cargo. Make sure you put your phone aside for the entire trip.

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you
questions.answer1: avoid using your cell phone until you reach your destination.
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in the first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: eat, drink, and smoke only on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no other vehicles around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. Avoid using your cell phone until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: Letting the air out of hot tires
questions.answer1: is a good idea because the extra pressure will be relieved.
questions.answer2: is a bad idea because when the tires cool off, the pressure will be too low.
questions.answer3: will have no effect at all.
questions.answer4: will cool them down. You will be able to continue your trip sooner.
questions.explanation: When tires get hot, the air pressure increases. However, relieving that extra pressure will leave the air pressure too low when the tires cool again, and then the tires may catch fire or blow out. If your tires are too hot to touch, stop until they have cooled down.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an antilock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: What is the definition of a hazard?
questions.answer2: A road user or road condition that presents a possible danger
questions.answer3: Something you must stop for
questions.explanation: A hazard is a road user or road condition that presents a possible danger. A hazard is something that can go wrong but shouldn't if you've been vigilant.

questions.question: How long does it take a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double railroad track?
questions.answer3: More than 30 seconds
questions.explanation: You can expect it to take more than 15 seconds for a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double track and at least 14 seconds to clear a single track.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key steering component?
questions.answer3: Gear box
questions.explanation: The gear box is an integral part of the steering system. The other three choices are parts of the suspension system.

questions.question: What is the best method for calculating the number of seconds of following distance you have?
questions.answer1: Wait until the vehicle ahead of you passes a shadow or landmark. Then count the seconds until you reach it.
questions.answer2: Get 1/4 closer to the vehicle in front of you, then back off again. Multiply how long this took you by four to give the following distance.
questions.answer3: Use the stopwatch on your cell phone to determine how long it takes you to reach a mile marker after the vehicle in front of you has passed it.
questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to reach some stationary object after the vehicle in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here either don't work or involve dangerous distractions. Note that you should increase your following distance in heavy traffic, in bad weather, with heavy vehicles, or at higher speeds.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are
questions.answer1: signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo.
questions.answer2: signs on the inside of the vehicle that remind the driver of what he or she is carrying.
questions.answer3: signs that help tax collectors determine how much to tax a hazardous cargo.
questions.answer4: signs that warn the public to stay at least 1,000 feet from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are four regulated signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo for those who need to know, such as emergency service personnel or those who load and unload cargo.

questions.question: When you start to drive down a steep downgrade, which of the following should influence your choice of speed?
questions.answer1: The total weight of your vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: When choosing a safe speed for driving down a steep downgrade, consider its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: How speed you should reduce when you drive on wet roads?
questions.answer3: one-third.
questions.explanation: When a road is wet, stopping distance is increased, and you should reduce your speed by one-third. On snow, slow to one-half your usual speed. On icy roads, slow to a crawl and stop driving as soon as you can do so safely.

questions.question: Do empty trucks have the best braking?
questions.answer3: Yes, but only on wet surfaces.
questions.answer4: Yes, but only if the trucks are newer than 1998.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have longer stopping distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: An antilock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: keep your wheels from locking when you brake hard.
questions.explanation: ABS kicks in only to keep the wheels from locking, which could cause a skid. ABS does not change the way you normally brake the rest of the time. It is not a substitute for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, or regular maintenance.

questions.question: You should do the following to assist you stay aware and safe while driving:
questions.answer1: avoid medications that can cause drowsiness.
questions.answer2: drink coffee if you get drowsy.
questions.answer3: roll down your windows to get fresh air.
questions.answer4: have a whiskey to brace yourself.
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, some prescription and over-the-counter medications can cause drowsiness, sedation, or impaired coordination, which make them dangerous for CMV operators. If you are unsure about the effects of a particular medication, check the warning label or ask your pharmacist or doctor. Never try to fight drowsiness with coffee, fresh air, or especially alcohol. The only "cure" for being tired is sleeping until you are rested.

questions.question: What can you do at an accident scene to help avoid another accident?
questions.answer1: Stay in your vehicle and do nothing until help arrives.
questions.answer2: Set out warning devices to keep other vehicles from running into the accident scene.
questions.answer3: Leave your vehicle, do nothing, and get to higher ground.
questions.answer4: Have a drink to calm your nerves.
questions.explanation: Unless you have been injured, it is your responsibility to ensure that others can see your vehicle at the accident scene. Set out your warning devices as quickly as possible to avoid further accidents such as a pile-up.

questions.question: Each of the following tasks is involved in starting the engine and inspecting the cab, EXCEPT
questions.answer3: starting the engine, then listening for unusual noises.
questions.answer4: starting the engine, then putting the gearshift in neutral.
questions.explanation: Please note that the question says "EXCEPT." When performing this part of the inspection, start the engine after you have put the gearshift in neutral. Then listen for any unusual noises. Once you perform the engine check, you will check all your gauges and controls, such as the air pressure gauge and transmission controls.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: All of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide to the left, a driver may try to pass you on your right while you are turning. Instead, make the right turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This will deny drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: When evaluating hoses with the instructor during your pre-trip examination, seek for
questions.answer3: frays in the water pump belt.
questions.answer4: a low windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: When you inspect hoses during your pre-trip test, you need to look for signs of leaks, such as puddles on the ground or fluids that are dripping on the underside of the engine or transmission. Also check the hoses for cracks or other problems.

questions.question: In which of the following two situations should you downshift?
questions.answer1: Starting down a hill and entering a curve
questions.answer2: Starting up a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer3: Starting down a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer4: Starting up a hill and entering a curve
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill lets you take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required, which is usually lower than the gear required to climb the hill. Downshifting before a curve improves stability and helps you get the power you will need to accelerate out of the turn.

questions.question: It has just reached freezing. Which of the following areas may be slippery?
questions.answer3: A wet-looking road
questions.explanation: Once the temperature drops to freezing, some sections of road will start to freeze before others. The first to freeze will be shaded areas and bridges. If the road appears wet, it may be covered in black ice, a thin layer of slippery ice through which you can see the road.

questions.question: Why is it important to use a helper when backing?
questions.answer2: Because people feel more comfortable when you do
questions.answer3: Because you are providing a job for someone else
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: It is important to use a helper when you are backing because you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals for "Go" and (most importantly) "Stop."

questions.question: You should put the starter switch key into your pocket while you perform the pre-trip inspection because
questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.
questions.answer3: it could damage the starting mechanism.
questions.answer4: any of the above could occur.
questions.explanation: While you are performing the pre-trip inspection, you do not want someone (such as a co-driver) who is unaware of your location to start your vehicle and accidentally injure you.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to brake to a stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your braking distance increases by roughly the square of the speed increase – to about four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 148 feet.

questions.question: Before transporting a sealed load, you must inspect
questions.answer1: a small sample of whatever is inside.
questions.answer2: a picture of whatever is inside.
questions.answer3: that you don't exceed gross weight or axle weight limits.
questions.explanation: While you cannot actually inspect sealed loads, it's still your responsibility to ensure that you do not exceed your axle weight limits or gross weight restrictions, so check them both.

questions.question: The most significant hand gesture on which you and your assistance should both agree is
questions.answer3: “Stop.”
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: On which of the following types of fires should you NOT use a B:C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Wood
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher should not be used on burning materials that you can use ordinary water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: To maintain alertness on your trips, you should
questions.answer1: schedule your trips for the daytime hours.
questions.answer3: avoid medications that cause drowsiness.
questions.explanation: Sleep debt is a dangerous condition in which missing sleep adds up until you risk falling asleep at the wheel unless you get some rest. People are often surprised that getting less than 6 hours of sleep per night triples the risk of an accident. At least 15% of heavy truck crashes are believed to involve driver fatigue. Before a trip, you should get adequate sleep (adults need 8 to 9 hours to maintain alertness); prepare your route carefully to identify total distance, stopping points, and other logistical considerations; schedule trips for the hours during which you are normally awake, not the middle of the night; drive with a passenger; avoid medications that cause drowsiness; consult your physician if you suffer from daytime sleepiness, have difficulty sleeping at night, or take frequent naps; and incorporate exercise into your daily life to give yourself more energy.

questions.question: How do you get started without rolling backwards?
questions.answer1: Put on the parking brake whenever necessary.
questions.answer2: Engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake.
questions.answer3: Apply the trailer brake hand valve.
questions.explanation: If you have a manual transmission vehicle, partly engage the clutch before you take your right foot off the brake. Put on the parking brake whenever necessary to keep from rolling back. Release the parking brake only when you have applied enough engine power to keep from rolling back. On a tractor-trailer equipped with a trailer brake hand valve, the hand valve can be applied to keep from rolling back.

questions.question: To transport cargo safely, which of these are you NOT responsible for?
questions.answer3: Making sure that cargo is properly secured
questions.answer4: Ensuring the freshness of sealed cargo
questions.explanation: You are not responsible for the state of sealed cargo, nor can you inspect it. You are only responsible for the safety of the cargo, ensuring that it is balanced, secured, and not overloaded, and does not get in the way of emergency equipment.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four fundamental abilities required to operate a commercial motor vehicle?
questions.answer3: First-aid certification
questions.explanation: As described in detail in section 2.2 of the Connecticut Commercial Driver License Manual, the four basic skills for safe operation of a commercial motor vehicle are accelerating, steering, stopping, and backing safely. While first-aid certification might come in handy at some point in your career, it is not one of the four basic skills.

questions.question: As part of your skills test, the examiner may ask you to perform an alley dock maneuver (i.e., back your vehicle into an alley). You must bring the rear of your vehicle within ________ of the rear of the alley without touching boundary lines or cones.
questions.answer3: 12 inches
questions.explanation: As part of your skills test, the examiner may ask you to perform an alley dock maneuver (i.e., back your vehicle into an alley). You must bring the rear of your vehicle within three feet of the rear of the alley without touching boundary lines or cones. When you have completed this, your vehicle must be straight within the alley.

questions.question: Which of the following retarder assertions is true?
questions.answer1: Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for braking.
questions.answer2: When your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarders may cause them to skid.
questions.answer3: You should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow covered.
questions.answer4: All of the above statements are correct.
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should always turn off your retarders in poor weather.

questions.question: If the engine is not overheated, is it completely safe to remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer3: Yes, as long as there is no overflow.
questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.
questions.explanation: It is not enough for the engine not to be overheated. The system should have cooled completely before you even attempt to remove the radiator cap, and even then, you should be very careful as there may be tremendous pressure and damaging steam and fluids.

questions.question: You must park on the shoulder of a level, straight, two-lane road. Where should the reflective triangles be placed?
questions.answer1: One about 10 feet to the rear of the vehicle, one about 100 feet to the rear, and one about 100 feet in front of the vehicle
questions.answer2: One about 10 feet to the rear of the vehicle, one about 100 feet to the rear, and one about 200 feet to the rear
questions.answer3: One about 10 feet to the rear of the vehicle, one about 50 feet to the rear, and one about 100 feet to the rear
questions.answer4: One about 50 feet to the rear of the vehicle, one about 100 feet to the rear, and one about 100 feet in front of the vehicle
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulation 49 CFR 392.22. This regulation also specifies where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as one-way roads and curves. (The Connecticut Commercial Driver License Manual also covers some of these situations. Oddly, however, it does not discuss the situation of placing warning devices on a one-way road or divided highway. Most CDL manuals published by other states discuss this situation.)

questions.question: How long will you lose your CDL driving privileges if you are convicted of a second DUI offense in either a CMV or your private vehicle?
questions.answer3: Life
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of DUI for a second time, you will lose your CDL privileges for life. While you are driving a CMV, a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.04% or above qualifies as DUI. Your first offense is a wake-up call and a chance to get help, but your second offense is going to mean unemployment. If you get a DUI, seek help before you lose your salary and your future.

questions.question: What is gross vehicle weight (GVW)?
questions.answer1: A vehicle's maximum weight rating, specified by its manufacturer
questions.answer2: The total weight of the vehicle, towed vehicles, and the load
questions.answer3: The total weight of a single vehicle and its load
questions.explanation: GVW is the simplest of the vehicle weight terms, defined as the weight of just a single vehicle and the load that it is carrying.

questions.question: Which lights should you use the most when driving at night?
questions.answer3: Emergency flashers
questions.explanation: While driving at night, you should use your high beams to see farther as long as it is safe and legal and you will not blind any other drivers. The Connecticut Commercial Driver License Manual recommends that you dim your headlights whenever you are within 500 feet of any other vehicle.

questions.question: How often do you have to pull over to inspect your goods while driving?
questions.answer3: Every three hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, the Connecticut Commercial Driver License Manual states that you should check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your trip and then every 3 hours or 150 miles, as well as after each break you take.

questions.question: If you are traveling at 55 mph in a 30-foot vehicle, you should leave how many seconds of following distance?
questions.answer3: 3 seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per 10 feet of vehicle, and then add an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. So for a 30-foot vehicle going 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: If you have a flat tire, you should not do which of the following?
questions.answer3: Brake hard and immediately.
questions.answer4: Be aware that a tire has failed.
questions.explanation: Hard braking could cause your vehicle to go out of control, so brake gently only after the vehicle has slowed down and you have regained control.

questions.question: What is a common cause of tire fires?
questions.answer3: Cold tires
questions.explanation: Underinflated tires and dual tires that touch are the most common causes of tire fires.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the basic shifting method?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, press the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, press the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: Why should you cover your cargo?
questions.answer1: To protect individuals from any spilled cargo
questions.answer2: To protect your cargo from bad weather
questions.answer3: Because many states require it
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: There are several reasons to cover your cargo, including protecting other people and the cargo itself. In addition, it will help you comply with regulations in several states.

questions.question: Total stopping distance equals
questions.answer3: perception distance + reaction distance + braking distance.
questions.answer4: reaction distance + viewing distance + braking distance.
questions.explanation: Total stopping distance is the sum of your perception distance (how far the vehicle goes from when you see the hazard until your brain processes it), reaction distance (how far the vehicle goes from when your brain orders your foot to take action until your foot actually starts to brake), and braking distance (how far the vehicle continues to travel once you apply the brake).

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.
questions.answer3: Call the police from your cell phone if you can do it safely.
questions.explanation: If an aggressive driver is trying to confront you, do not give the person the confrontation that he or she seeks. Instead, seek police, peace, and safety.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: Your body breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate. Typically, this is one standard drink per hour, where one standard drink equals 1.5 ounces of hard liquor, 5 ounces of wine, or 12 ounces of beer. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: How many tie-downs are required for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tie-down per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two per load, regardless of the length. So for 20 feet, you should have two tie-downs.

questions.question: If you are traveling at 55 mph in a 30-foot vehicle, you should leave how many seconds of following distance?
questions.answer3: 3 seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. Therefore, for a 30-foot vehicle traveling at 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: Always try to back toward the driver's side because
questions.answer1: it's more comfortable for turning your neck.
questions.answer2: you can see better, watching the vehicle's rear from the side window.
questions.answer3: your truck will probably pull toward the driver's side.
questions.answer4: all of the above are true.
questions.explanation: You should always back toward the driver's side because you will be able to see things much more easily. For example, you can keep an eye on the vehicle's rear by viewing it from your side window. If your truck pulls in either direction, it needs service. Your neck's comfort should not affect your safety decision.

questions.question: The minimum tire tread depth for front tires is
questions.answer3: 1/2 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels and any visible evidence of cracks or leaks.

questions.question: Which of the following should NOT be checked during a trip?
questions.answer3: Text messages
questions.explanation: During your trip, you should keep an eye on all of your vehicle's key systems, such as the instruments, gauges, tires, voltmeter, mirrors, and cargo. Make sure you put your phone aside for the entire trip.

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you
questions.answer1: avoid using your cell phone until you reach your destination.
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in the first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: eat, drink, and smoke only on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no other vehicles around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. Avoid using your cell phone until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: Letting the air out of hot tires
questions.answer1: is a good idea because the extra pressure will be relieved.
questions.answer2: is a bad idea because when the tires cool off, the pressure will be too low.
questions.answer3: will have no effect at all.
questions.answer4: will cool them down. You will be able to continue your trip sooner.
questions.explanation: When tires get hot, the air pressure increases. However, relieving that extra pressure will leave the air pressure too low when the tires cool again, and then the tires may catch fire or blow out. If your tires are too hot to touch, stop until they have cooled down.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an antilock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: What is the definition of a hazard?
questions.answer2: A road user or road condition that presents a possible danger
questions.answer3: Something you must stop for
questions.explanation: A hazard is a road user or road condition that presents a possible danger. A hazard is something that can go wrong but shouldn't if you've been vigilant.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key steering component?
questions.answer3: Gear box
questions.explanation: The gear box is an integral part of the steering system. The other three choices are parts of the suspension system.

questions.question: What is the best method for calculating the number of seconds of following distance you have?
