questions.answer1: Wait until the vehicle ahead of you passes a shadow or landmark. Then count the seconds until you reach it.
questions.answer2: Get 1/4 closer to the vehicle in front of you, then back off again. Multiply how long this took you by four to give the following distance.
questions.answer3: Use the stopwatch on your cell phone to determine how long it takes you to reach a mile marker after the vehicle in front of you has passed it.
questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to reach some stationary object after the vehicle in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here either don't work or involve dangerous distractions. Note that you should increase your following distance in heavy traffic, in bad weather, with heavy vehicles, or at higher speeds.

questions.question: To transport cargo safely, which of the following are you NOT responsible for?
questions.answer1: Ensuring the safety of the cargo
questions.answer3: Making sure that cargo is properly secured
questions.answer4: Ensuring the freshness of sealed cargo
questions.explanation: You are not responsible for the state of sealed cargo, nor can you inspect it. You are only responsible for the safety of the cargo, ensuring that it is balanced, secured, and not overloaded, and does not get in the way of emergency equipment.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are
questions.answer1: signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo.
questions.answer2: signs on the inside of the vehicle that remind the driver of what he or she is carrying.
questions.answer3: signs that help tax collectors determine how much to tax a hazardous cargo.
questions.answer4: signs that warn the public to stay at least 1,000 feet from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are four regulated signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo for those who need to know, such as emergency service personnel or those who load and unload cargo.

questions.question: When you start to drive down a steep downgrade, which of the following should influence your choice of speed?
questions.answer1: The total weight of your vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: When choosing a safe speed for driving down a steep downgrade, consider its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: How do you get started without rolling backwards?
questions.answer1: Set the parking brake whenever necessary.
questions.answer2: Engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake.
questions.answer3: Apply the trailer brake hand valve.
questions.explanation: If you have a manual transmission vehicle, partly engage the clutch before you take your right foot off the brake. Set the parking brake whenever necessary to keep from rolling back. Release the parking brake only when you have applied enough engine power to keep from rolling back. On a tractor-trailer equipped with a trailer brake hand valve, the hand valve can be applied to keep from rolling back.

questions.question: How speed you should reduce when you drive on wet roads?
questions.answer3: one-third.
questions.explanation: When a road is wet, stopping distance is increased, and you should reduce your speed by one-third. On snow, slow to one-half your usual speed. On icy roads, slow to a crawl and stop driving as soon as you can do so safely.

questions.question: If the engine is not overheated, is it completely safe to remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer3: Yes, as long as there is no overflow.
questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.
questions.explanation: It is not enough for the engine not to be overheated. The cooling system must cool completely before you attempt to remove the radiator cap. Even then, you should be very careful because there may still be tremendous pressure and damaging steam and fluids.

questions.question: Do empty trucks have the best braking?
questions.answer3: Yes, but only on wet surfaces.
questions.answer4: Yes, but only if the trucks are newer than 1998.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have longer stopping distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: An antilock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: keep your wheels from locking when you brake hard.
questions.explanation: ABS kicks in only to keep the wheels from locking, which could cause a skid. ABS does not change the way you normally brake the rest of the time. It is not a substitute for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, or regular maintenance.

questions.question: You should do the following to assist you stay aware and safe while driving:
questions.answer1: avoid medications that can cause drowsiness.
questions.answer2: drink coffee if you get drowsy.
questions.answer3: roll down your windows to get fresh air.
questions.answer4: have a whiskey to brace yourself.
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, some prescription and over-the-counter medications can cause drowsiness, sedation, or impaired coordination, which make them dangerous for CMV operators. If you are unsure about the effects of a particular medication, check the warning label or ask your pharmacist or doctor. Never try to fight drowsiness with coffee, fresh air, or especially alcohol. The only "cure" for being tired is sleeping until you are rested.

questions.question: What can you do at an accident scene to help avoid another accident?
questions.answer1: Stay in your vehicle and do nothing until help arrives.
questions.answer2: Set out warning devices to keep other vehicles from running into the accident scene.
questions.answer3: Leave your vehicle, do nothing, and get to higher ground.
questions.answer4: Have a drink to calm your nerves.
questions.explanation: Unless you have been injured, it is your responsibility to ensure that others can see your vehicle at the accident scene. Set out your warning devices as quickly as possible to avoid further accidents such as a pile-up.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: All of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide to the left, a driver may try to pass you on your right while you are turning. Instead, make the right turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This will deny drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: When evaluating hoses with the instructor during your pre-trip examination, seek for
questions.answer3: frays in the water pump belt.
questions.answer4: a low windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: When you inspect hoses during your pre-trip test, you need to look for signs of leaks, such as puddles on the ground or fluids that are dripping on the underside of the engine or transmission. Also check the hoses for cracks or other problems.

questions.question: In which of the following two situations should you downshift?
questions.answer1: Starting down a hill and entering a curve
questions.answer2: Starting up a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer3: Starting down a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer4: Starting up a hill and entering a curve
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill lets you take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required, which is usually lower than the gear required to climb the hill. Downshifting before a curve improves stability and helps you get the power you will need to accelerate out of the turn.

questions.question: It has just reached freezing. Which of the following areas may be slippery?
questions.answer3: A wet-looking road
questions.explanation: Once the temperature drops to freezing, some sections of road will start to freeze before others. The first to freeze will be shaded areas and bridges. If the road appears wet, it may be covered in black ice, a thin layer of slippery ice through which you can see the road.

questions.question: Why is it important to use a helper when backing?
questions.answer2: Because people feel more comfortable when you do
questions.answer3: Because you are providing a job for someone else
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: It is important to use a helper when you are backing because you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals for "Go" and (most importantly) "Stop."

questions.question: You should put the starter switch key into your pocket while you perform the pre-trip inspection because
questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.
questions.answer3: it could damage the starting mechanism.
questions.answer4: any of the above could occur.
questions.explanation: While you are performing the pre-trip inspection, you do not want someone (such as a co-driver) who is unaware of your location to start your vehicle and accidentally injure you.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to brake to a stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your braking distance increases by roughly the square of the speed increase – to about four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 148 feet.

questions.question: Before transporting a sealed load, you must inspect
questions.answer1: a small sample of whatever is inside.
questions.answer2: a picture of whatever is inside.
questions.answer3: that you don't exceed gross weight or axle weight limits.
questions.explanation: While you cannot actually inspect sealed loads, it's still your responsibility to ensure that you do not exceed your axle weight limits or gross weight restrictions, so check them both.

questions.question: The most significant hand gesture on which you and your assistance should both agree is
questions.answer3: “Stop.”
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: What is the gross vehicle weight (GVW)?
questions.answer1: A vehicle's maximum weight rating, specified by its manufacturer
questions.answer2: The total weight of the vehicle, towed vehicles, and the load
questions.answer3: The total weight of a single vehicle and its load
questions.explanation: GVW is the simplest of the vehicle weight terms, defined as the weight of just a single vehicle and the load that it is carrying.

questions.question: On which of the following types of fires should you NOT use a B:C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Wood
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher should not be used on burning materials that you can use ordinary water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: To maintain alertness on your trips, you should
questions.answer1: schedule your trips for the daytime hours.
questions.answer3: avoid medications that cause drowsiness.
questions.explanation: Sleep debt is a dangerous condition in which missing sleep adds up until you risk falling asleep at the wheel unless you get some rest. People are often surprised that getting less than 6 hours of sleep per night triples the risk of an accident. At least 15% of heavy truck crashes are believed to involve driver fatigue. Before a trip, you should get adequate sleep (adults need 8 to 9 hours to maintain alertness); prepare your route carefully to identify total distance, stopping points, and other logistical considerations; schedule trips for the hours during which you are normally awake, not the middle of the night; drive with a passenger; avoid medications that cause drowsiness; consult your physician if you suffer from daytime sleepiness, have difficulty sleeping at night, or take frequent naps; and incorporate exercise into your daily life to give yourself more energy.

questions.question: Which of the following retarder assertions is true?
questions.answer1: Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for braking.
questions.answer2: When your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarder may cause them to skid.
questions.answer3: You should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow covered.
questions.answer4: All of the above statements are correct.
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should always turn off your retarders in poor weather.

questions.question: If you have a flat tire, you should not do which of the following?
questions.answer3: Brake hard and immediately.
questions.answer4: Be aware that a tire has failed.
questions.explanation: Hard braking could cause your vehicle to go out of control, so brake gently only after the vehicle has slowed down and you have regained control.

questions.answer3: Life
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of DUI for a second time, you will lose your CDL privileges for life. While you are driving a CMV, a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.04% or above qualifies as DUI. Your first offense is a wake-up call and a chance to get help, but your second offense is going to mean unemployment. If you get a DUI, seek help before you lose your salary and your future.

questions.answer3: For-hire situational drivers
questions.explanation: Delaware offers a special Non-CDL license for farmers and firefighters who operate CMV’s under the CDL waiver provisions. Non-CDL licenses may not be used in interstate commerce or in for-hire situations.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four fundamental abilities required to operate a commercial motor vehicle?
questions.answer3: First-aid certification
questions.explanation: As described in detail in section 2.2 of the State of Delaware Commercial Driver License Manual, the four basic skills for safe operation of a commercial motor vehicle are accelerating, steering, stopping, and backing safely. questions.question: How long does it take a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double railroad track?
questions.answer3: More than 30 seconds
questions.explanation: You can expect it to take more than 15 seconds for a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double track and at least 14 seconds to clear a single track.

questions.question: Which lights should you use the most when driving at night?
questions.answer3: Emergency flashers
questions.explanation: While driving at night, you should use your high beams to see farther as long as it is safe and legal and you will not blind any other drivers. Section 2.11.5 of the State of Delaware Commercial Driver License Manual recommends that you dim your headlights whenever you are within 500 feet of another vehicle.

questions.question: How often do you have to pull over to inspect your goods while driving?
questions.answer3: Every three hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, the State of Delaware Commercial Driver License Manual states that you should check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your trip and then every 3 hours or 150 miles, as well as after each break you take.

questions.question: Each of the following tasks is involved in starting the engine and inspecting the cab, EXCEPT
questions.answer3: starting the engine and then listening for unusual noises.
questions.answer4: starting the engine and then putting the gearshift in neutral.
questions.explanation: Please note that the question says "EXCEPT." When performing this part of the inspection, start the engine after you have put the gearshift in neutral. questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulation 49 CFR 392.22. questions.answer3: roll down your windows to get fresh air.
questions.answer4: have a whiskey to brace yourself.
questions.explanation: Be careful with medications that warn you they may cause drowsiness. If you have a concern about prescribed medications, speak with your doctor. Do not try to fight sleepiness with coffee, fresh air, or especially alcohol. The only "cure" for being tired is sleeping until you are rested.

questions.question: Which of the following must you present when applying for your District of Columbia CDL?
questions.answer2: Valid District of Columbia driver license
questions.answer3: Valid CDL learner permit
questions.explanation: When you go to take your CDL test, you must have your medical certificate, valid driver license, and CDL learner permit with you. But that's not all. You must also have your US DOT medical examination report, proof of US citizenship, and an empty commercial vehicle of the type you are trying to get licensed for. Before you go to take the test, check online to make sure that you have everything you need.

questions.question: What is the most important hand signal that you and a helper should agree on?
questions.answer3: Stop.
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: In which of the following two conditions should you downshift?
questions.answer1: Starting down a hill and entering a curve
questions.answer2: Starting up a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer3: Starting down a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer4: Starting up a hill and entering a curve
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill allows you to take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required, which is usually lower than the gear required to climb the hill. Downshifting before a curve improves stability and helps you have the power you need to accelerate out of the turn.

questions.question: Each of the following tasks is involved in starting the engine and inspecting the cab, EXCEPT
questions.answer3: starting the engine, then listening for unusual noises.
questions.answer4: starting the engine, then putting the gearshift in neutral.
questions.explanation: When performing this part of the inspection, you must put the gearshift in neutral, then start the engine and listen for any unusual noises. Once you have performed the engine check, you will check all your gauges and controls, such as the air pressure gauge and transmission controls.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your stopping distance increases to almost four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 148 feet.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: All of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide to the left, a driver may try to pass on your right when you are about to turn right. Instead, make the right turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide without allowing drivers room on the right to pass you.

questions.question: It has just reached freezing. Which of the following area(s) may be slippery?
questions.answer3: A wet road
questions.explanation: Once the temperature drops to freezing, some sections of the road will start to freeze before others. The first to freeze will be shaded areas and bridges. If the road appears wet, it may be covered in black ice – a thin layer of slippery ice through which you can see the actual road.

questions.question: Before transporting a sealed load, you must inspect
questions.answer1: a small sample of whatever is inside.
questions.answer2: a picture of whatever is inside.
questions.answer3: that you don't exceed gross weight and axle weight limits.
questions.explanation: You cannot actually inspect sealed loads. However, it's still your responsibility to ensure that you do not exceed your axle weight limits and your gross weight restrictions, so check them both.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT part of the basic method of shifting up?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, push in the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, push in the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: Which of the following factors can influence the safe speed for going down a steep downgrade?
questions.answer1: The total weight of the vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: There are several factors that may influence your choice of a safe speed for going down a steep downgrade: its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: For how long will you lose your CDL driving privileges if you are convicted of a second DUI offense?
questions.answer3: Life
questions.explanation: Due to nationwide drunk driving laws, a second DUI offense in either a CMV or non-CMV vehicle will cause you to lose your CDL for life. (See Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations Part 383.51, issued by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA)). Your first offense is a wake-up call and a chance to get help, but your second offense is going to mean unemployment. If you get a DUI, seek help before you lose your salary and your future.

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you
questions.answer1: turn off your cell phone until you reach your destination.
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in your first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: smoke, eat, and drink on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no other vehicles around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. If possible, turn off your phone and keep it off until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: Your liver breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate, typically one standard drink (one ounce of hard liquor or one-half glass of wine) per hour. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: How many tiedowns are required for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tiedown for every 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two tiedowns per load regardless of the length. So for 20 feet, you would have two tiedowns.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are
questions.answer1: signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo.
questions.answer2: signs on the inside of the vehicle that remind the driver of what he or she is carrying.
questions.answer3: signs that help tax collectors determine how much to tax a hazardous cargo.
questions.answer4: signs that warn the public to stay at least 1,000 feet away from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are four regulated signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo for those who need to know, such as emergency service personnel or those who load and unload cargo.

questions.question: Why should you cover cargo?
questions.answer1: To protect individuals from any spilled cargo
questions.answer2: To protect your cargo from bad weather
questions.answer3: Because many states require it
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: There are several reasons to cover your cargo, including protecting other people and the cargo itself. In addition, it will help you comply with regulations in several states.

questions.question: If the engine is not overheated, is it completely safe to remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer3: Yes, as long as there is no overflow.
questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.
questions.explanation: It is not enough for the engine not to be overheated. The cooling system must cool completely before you attempt to remove the radiator cap.

questions.question: You should put the starter switch key into your pocket while you perform the pre-trip inspection because
questions.answer1: it could damage the steering mechanism.
questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.
questions.answer3: it could damage the starting mechanism.
questions.answer4: any of the above could occur.
questions.explanation: When you are performing the pre-trip inspection, you do not want someone (such as a co-driver) who is unaware of your location to start your vehicle and accidentally injure you.

questions.question: Tire fires are commonly caused by
questions.answer3: cold tires.
questions.explanation: Underinflated tires and dual tires that touch are the most common causes of tire fires.

questions.question: What is the best method for calculating the number of seconds of following distance you have?
questions.answer1: Wait until the vehicle ahead of you passes a shadow or landmark. Then start to count the seconds until you reach it.
questions.answer2: Get 1/4 closer to the car in front of you, then back off again. Multiply how long this took you by four to give the following distance.
questions.answer3: Use the stopwatch on your cell phone to determine how long it takes you to reach a mile marker after the car in front of you has passed it.
questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to reach some object after the vehicle in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here either will not work or involve dangerous distractions. Note that you should increase your following distance in heavy traffic, in bad weather, with heavy vehicles, or at higher speeds.

questions.question: What is the definition of a hazard?
questions.answer2: A road user or road condition that presents a possible danger
questions.answer3: Something you must stop for
questions.explanation: A hazard is a road user or road condition that presents a possible danger. A hazard is something that could go wrong but shouldn't if you've been vigilant.

questions.question: Which of the following retarder assertions is true?
questions.answer1: Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for using your brakes.
questions.answer2: If your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarder may cause them to skid.
questions.answer3: You should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow-covered.
questions.answer4: All of the above statements are correct.
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should always turn off your retarder in poor weather.

questions.question: Which lights should you use the most when driving at night?
questions.answer3: Emergency flashers
questions.explanation: When driving at night, you should use your high beams to expand your field of vision as often as possible, as long as it is safe and legal and you will not blind any other drivers. The rule of thumb is to use high beams as long as there are no approaching vehicles within 500 feet.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an anti-lock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for yellow ABS malfunction lamps on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: What can you do at an accident scene to help prevent another accident?
questions.answer1: Stay in your vehicle and do nothing until help arrives.
questions.answer2: Set out warning devices to keep other vehicles from running into the accident scene.
questions.answer3: Leave your vehicle, do nothing, and get to higher ground.
questions.answer4: Have a drink to calm your nerves.
questions.explanation: Unless you have been injured, it is your responsibility to ensure that others can see your vehicle at an accident scene. Set out your warning devices as quickly as possible to avoid further accidents such as a pile-up.

questions.question: While you are on the road, how often must you stop to check your cargo?
questions.answer3: Every three hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, in DC, you must check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your journey and then every three hours or 150 miles, whichever comes first.

questions.question: When evaluating hoses with the instructor during your pre-trip examination, seek for
questions.answer3: frays in the water pump belt.
questions.answer4: a low windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: During your pre-trip test, when inspecting hoses, you need to look for signs of leaks, such as puddles on the ground or fluids that are dripping on the underside of the engine or transmission. Also check the hoses for cracks or other problems.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should
questions.answer2: ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.
questions.answer3: call the police from your cell phone if you can do it safely.
questions.explanation: When an aggressive driver is trying to confront you, do not give the person the confrontation that he or she seeks. Instead, seek police, peace, and safety.

questions.question: Which of the following should you NOT check during a trip?
questions.answer3: Text messages
questions.explanation: During your trip, you should keep an eye on all your vehicle's key systems, such as the instruments, gauges, tires, voltmeter, mirrors, and cargo. Make sure you put your cell phone away for the entire journey. Have it available only for emergencies.

questions.question: How speed you should reduce when you drive on wet roads?
questions.answer3: one-third.
questions.explanation: When a road is wet, stopping distance is increased, and you should reduce your speed by one-third. On snow, slow to one-half your usual speed. On icy roads, slow to a crawl and stop driving as soon as you can do so safely.

questions.question: When backing, it is important to use a helper
questions.answer2: because people feel more comfortable when you do.
questions.answer3: because you are providing a job for someone else.
questions.answer4: for all of the above reasons.
questions.explanation: It is important to use a helper when you are backing since you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals - especially "Stop."

questions.question: How long does it take for a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double railroad track?
questions.answer3: More than 30 seconds
questions.explanation: You can expect it to take more than 15 seconds for a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double track and at least 14 seconds to clear a single track.

questions.question: How many hours of sleep per night does the average person need to avoid accumulating sleep debt?
questions.answer3: 8 to 9 hours
questions.explanation: In sleep debt, missing sleep adds up until you risk falling asleep at the wheel until you have fully rested. Surprisingly, studies have shown that getting only six hours or less of sleep per night triples your risk of an accident.

questions.question: Do empty trucks have the best braking?
questions.answer3: Yes, but only on wet surfaces.
questions.answer4: Yes, but only if the trucks are newer than 1998.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have greater stopping distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations Part 392.22, issued by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA). These regulations also specify where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as two-way roads and curves.

questions.question: Which is NOT one of the four basic skills that the safe operation of a commercial vehicle requires?
questions.answer3: First aid
questions.explanation: As described in detail in section 2.2 of the manual, the four basic skills for safe operation of a commercial vehicle are accelerating, steering, stopping, and backing safely. While first aid certification could certainly come in handy at some point in your career, it is not one of the four basic skills.

questions.question: What is the main goal of a vehicle inspection?
questions.answer2: To make sure your vehicle is safe
questions.answer3: To check the cleanliness of your vehicle
questions.answer4: To make sure the paint is not chipped
questions.explanation: The main purpose of a vehicle inspection is to determine whether your vehicle is safe enough to drive. This includes your safety and that of other road users. In addition, discovering defects during a vehicle inspection can help avert a costly or even dangerous breakdown on the road.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a key steering system component?
questions.answer3: Axle
questions.explanation: Each axle is, of course, an integral part of your vehicle. However, it is not a key part of the steering system, which includes the other choices, the steering column, the arm and knuckle, the hydraulic fluid reservoir, the Pitman arm, and the spindle.

questions.question: The minimum tire tread depth for the front tires is
questions.answer3: 1/2 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: How many reflective warning triangles must you carry with you for emergencies?
questions.answer3: Four
questions.explanation: Your truck's emergency equipment must include warning devices such as three reflective red triangles, three liquid burning flares, or six fusees.

questions.question: Your vehicle's safety equipment must include
questions.answer1: spare electrical fuses, but only if your vehicle has circuit breakers.
questions.answer3: spare brake drums.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's safety equipment must include warning devices (such as reflective triangles) and a properly charged and rated fire extinguisher. You must also have spare electrical fuses but only if your vehicle uses fuses instead of circuit breakers.

questions.question: Why should you use a helper when you're backing your vehicle?
questions.answer1: Because every truck has blind spots
questions.answer2: To make sure you don't damage your truck
questions.answer3: Because it's the law
questions.answer4: To check your style of driving
questions.explanation: You should use a helper when you are backing because you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals for "Go" and (most importantly) "Stop."

questions.question: The most significant hand gesture on which you and your assistance should both agree is
questions.answer3: “Go backward.”
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about retarders are true?
questions.answer2: Retarders apply braking power to the drive wheels.
questions.answer3: Retarders make a skid more likely when traction is poor.
questions.answer4: All of the above are true.
questions.explanation: Retarders (of which there are several types) help slow your vehicle, reducing the need for braking. However, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should turn off your retarder in poor weather.

questions.question: When going down a downgrade in a vehicle with an automatic transmission, you should
questions.answer3: change your range in the middle of the downgrade.
questions.explanation: If you just keep applying the brakes to control your speed on a steep descent, the brakes may fade (lose their effectiveness). Instead, if your vehicle has an automatic transmission, select a low range that prevents the transmission from shifting up beyond the selected gear. This will generate a braking effect to slow the vehicle, known as engine braking. The lower the gear, the greater the engine braking effect. Apply the brakes only when engine braking is insufficient or you want to stop.

questions.question: To shift up, you should release the accelerator, push in the clutch and shift into neutral, and then
questions.answer3: release the clutch.
questions.explanation: To shift up with double clutching, release the accelerator, press the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, press the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time.

questions.question: Total stopping distance equals
questions.answer2: perception distance + reaction distance + braking distance.
questions.answer3: perception distance + reaction distance.
questions.answer4: reaction distance + braking distance + signal distance.
questions.explanation: Total stopping distance is the sum of your perception distance (how far your vehicle goes from when you see the hazard until your brain processes it), reaction distance (how far the vehicle goes from when your brain orders your foot to take action until your foot actually starts to brake), and braking distance (how far the vehicle continues to travel once you apply the brake).

questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulation 49 CFR 392.22. This regulation also specifies where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as undivided two-way roads and curves. (These situations are also covered in section 2.5.2 of the Florida CDL Handbook.)

questions.question: How far ahead should you look while driving, according to the Florida CDL Handbook?
questions.answer3: 12 to 15 seconds
questions.explanation: According to the Florida CDL Handbook, you should look ahead the distance that your CMV will travel in 12 to 15 seconds. At the slower speeds of city driving, your CMV will travel about one block in 15 seconds. At 60 mph, your CMV will travel a quarter mile (1,320 feet) in 15 seconds.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to brake to a stop?
questions.answer3: Four times as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your braking distance increases by roughly the square of the speed increase – to about four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 148 feet.

questions.question: Why should you keep your tires properly inflated?
questions.answer1: You will be driving a lot faster.
questions.answer3: You will never go into a skid.
questions.answer4: It will make the ride quieter.
questions.explanation: Keep your tires properly inflated. (Use a tire pressure gauge to get an accurate reading.) Overinflated tires are more likely to fail prematurely. Low tire pressures cause faster tire wear and reduced cornering ability and increase the effect of hydroplaning. Underinflation also causes increased flexing of the tire, which increases tire temperature. Tires that overheat can catch fire. Of course, even properly inflated tires are no guarantee against skids.

questions.question: What is the best way to check what is going on behind and to the sides of your vehicle?
questions.answer1: Stop every 50 miles and look around.
questions.answer3: Check your reflection in other vehicles.
questions.answer4: Turn your head to check your blind spots.
questions.explanation: To know what's going on behind and to the sides of your vehicle, check your mirrors regularly while you drive, and check them even more often in special situations. Before you start to drive, adjust your mirrors so that each mirror shows a different part of your vehicle.

questions.question: A truck's braking distance is shorter when it's empty than when it's fully loaded. True or false?
questions.answer3: It cannot be determined without more information about the cargo.
questions.answer4: It cannot be determined without more information about the truck.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have longer braking distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: In which of the following conditions is hydroplaning most likely?
questions.answer1: When there is standing water on the road
questions.answer2: When you're in a shady area the morning after a freeze
questions.answer3: When you are on a bridge right before a freeze is forecast
questions.answer4: When the temperature is below freezing but the road looks wet
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning occurs when there is standing water on a roadway. At higher speeds, the tires cannot channel the water away very well, and your tires may start to lose contact with the road and ride over the water like a set of water skis. This can lead to a total loss of braking and steering control. To prevent the onset of hydroplaning, slow down. Icy surfaces can also lead to skids but not by hydroplaning.

questions.question: What is the best method for calculating the number of seconds of following distance you have?
questions.answer1: Wait until the vehicle ahead of you passes a shadow or landmark. Then count the seconds until you reach it.
questions.answer2: Get 1/4 closer to the vehicle in front of you, then back off again. Multiply how long this took you by four to give the following distance.
questions.answer3: Use the stopwatch on your cell phone to determine how long it takes you to reach a mile marker after the vehicle in front of you has passed it.
questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to reach some stationary object after the vehicle in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here involve dangerous distractions or don't work at all. Note that you should increase your following distance in heavy traffic, in bad weather, with heavy vehicles, or at higher speeds.

questions.question: Avoid swinging left before turning right because
questions.answer2: another vehicle may try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: you may move into an opposing lane.
questions.answer4: it won't help you through the intersection.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide to the left before turning right, a driver may try to pass you on your right while you are turning, which can result in an accident. Instead, make the right turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This will deny drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should
questions.answer3: hit the brakes.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, avoid sudden changes or tricks such as flashing your brake lights. Instead, increase your following distance to give both you and the tailgater more space to react to hazards. This may also encourage the tailgater to pass you. Don't speed up in an attempt to appease or outdistance the tailgater. No speed is too fast for some tailgaters.

questions.question: If you are driving a 30-foot vehicle at 55 mph, you should leave how many seconds of following distance?
questions.answer3: 5 seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. Therefore, for a 30-foot vehicle traveling at 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: Getting only _______ or less of sleep the night before your trip will triple your risk of an accident.
questions.answer3: 6 hours
questions.explanation: Getting only 6 hours or less of sleep the night before your trip will triple your risk of an accident. Adults really need 8 to 9 hours of sleep to maintain alertness.

questions.question: Which of the following is MOST likely to get stuck on raised railroad crossings?
questions.answer2: A single-axle tractor pulling a trailer whose landing gear is set to accommodate it
questions.answer3: A single-axle bobtail tractor
questions.explanation: The two types of combination vehicles most likely to get stuck at a raised railroad crossing are low-slung units (car carriers, lowboys, moving vans, etc.) and single-axle tractors that are pulling a long trailer whose landing gear is set to accommodate a tandem-axle tractor. Be very careful when driving such vehicles at railroad crossings.

questions.question: When you're about to start down a steep downgrade, you should
questions.answer3: release the brakes.
questions.explanation: When you're about to start down a steep downgrade, shift into a low gear and use engine braking to slow your vehicle. Don't try to downshift after your speed has already built up. You will not be able to shift into a lower gear. You may not even be able to get back into any gear and all engine braking effect will be lost.

questions.question: An antilock braking system (ABS)
questions.answer3: shortens your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: does not change the way you normally brake.
questions.explanation: ABS does not have much effect on your everyday driving. It does not affect your braking capability or necessarily shorten your stopping distance. It just helps you keep control of your vehicle by activating when your wheels are about to lock up.

questions.question: An A:B:C type fire extinguisher can work on which of the following types of fires?
questions.answer3: Gasoline
questions.explanation: Make sure to use the right type of fire extinguisher to put out a fire. Class A fires involve ordinary combustibles such as wood, paper, or cloth. Class B fires involve oily liquids such as grease or gasoline. Class C fires involve electrical equipment. Class D fires involve combustible metals such as magnesium.

questions.question: Signs of a drunk driver include all of the following EXCEPT
questions.answer2: running stop signs or red lights.
questions.answer3: reacting quickly to hazards.
questions.answer4: driving too fast or too slowly.
questions.explanation: Alcohol can impair a driver's coordination and judgment and increase his or her reaction time. As a result, the driver may straddle two lanes, weave from lane to lane, fail to obey traffic laws, drive dangerously fast, or (in an attempt to stay in control) drive very slowly.

questions.question: In Florida, if you are convicted of drugged driving that resulted in an accident, you may face which of the following penalties?
questions.answer3: Loss of commercial driving privileges
questions.explanation: Under Florida law, if you are convicted of drugged driving that resulted in an accident involving property damage, you will face a fine of up to $1,000, a jail sentence of up to one year, or both. (If the accident resulted in injury to someone, the penalties will be more severe.) Furthermore, you will be disqualified from driving CMVs for at least one year. If you are convicted of this offense a second time, you will be disqualified from driving CMVs permanently, ending your career in commercial driving. [FL Stat § 316.193], [FL Stat § 322.61], [FL Stat § 775.082], [FL Stat § 775.083]

questions.question: If you don't have enough weight on the front axle,
questions.answer1: you may not be able to steer safely.
questions.answer3: you may experience tire failure.
questions.answer4: all of the above may occur.
questions.explanation: Less weight may mean less grip of the road. Insufficient weight on the front axle may make it harder to steer safely. Underloading the driving axles increases the chance that the drive wheels will spin.

questions.question: Once you start your trip, you must inspect the securement of your cargo within
questions.answer3: an hour.
questions.explanation: Once you start your trip, you must inspect the securement of your cargo within 50 miles and then every 3 hours or 150 miles thereafter.

questions.question: Why should you cover your cargo?
questions.answer1: To protect individuals from any spilled cargo
questions.answer2: To protect your cargo from bad weather
questions.answer3: Because many states require it
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: There are several reasons to cover your cargo, including protecting other people and the cargo itself. In addition, it will help you comply with regulations in several states. Florida law requires you to cover loose cargo to prevent any part of it from blowing off, falling off, or otherwise escaping from your vehicle. [FL Stat § 316.520]

questions.question: In Florida, to pass an emergency vehicle that is stopped on the side of a multilane roadway, you must move into a non-adjacent lane – if it's safe to do so. Otherwise, you must slow down to
questions.answer3: 10 mph.
questions.explanation: Under Florida's Move Over Law, when you encounter an emergency vehicle, sanitation vehicle, utility vehicle, or tow truck that is stopped with its flashing lights on, you must move into a non-adjacent lane if possible, leaving at least one vacant lane between you and the vehicle. If this is impossible (e.g., no other lanes in your direction) or unsafe, you must slow down until you have passed the vehicle. If the posted speed limit is greater than 20 mph, you must slow down to 20 mph below the posted speed limit; otherwise, you must slow down to 5 mph. (Note: All US states now have their own Move Over Laws, but some of them require drivers to do different things. When traveling out of state, always check the local traffic laws.)

questions.question: Under Florida law, which of the following drivers must hold a CDL?
questions.answer1: A driver of a military vehicle
questions.answer2: A farmer carrying fresh produce to the market
questions.answer3: A long-haul trucker carrying fresh produce
questions.explanation: Military drivers, emergency personnel, farmers, and farm employees (but not those employed to drive vehicles for farms) are exempt from needing a CDL. Also, someone who drives a recreational vehicle or straight truck for noncommercial purposes (e.g., to move the driver's own personal property) is exempt from needing a CDL.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels and any visible evidence of cracks or leaks.

questions.question: Letting the air out of hot tires
questions.answer1: is a good idea because the extra pressure will be relieved.
questions.answer2: is a bad idea because when the tires cool off, the pressure will be too low.
questions.answer3: will have no effect at all.
questions.answer4: will cool them down. You will be able to continue your trip sooner.
questions.explanation: When tires get hot, the air pressure increases. However, relieving that extra pressure will leave the air pressure too low when the tires cool again, and then the tires may catch fire or blow out. If your tires are too hot to touch, stop until they have cooled down.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an antilock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: What is the definition of a hazard?
questions.answer2: A road user or road condition that presents a possible danger
questions.answer3: Something you must stop for
questions.explanation: A hazard is a road user or road condition that presents a possible danger. A hazard is something that can go wrong but shouldn't if you've been vigilant.

questions.question: How long does it take a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double railroad track?
questions.answer3: More than 30 seconds
questions.explanation: You can expect it to take more than 15 seconds for a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double track and at least 14 seconds to clear a single track.

questions.question: To transport cargo safely, which of the following are you NOT responsible for?
questions.answer1: Ensuring the safety of the cargo
questions.answer3: Making sure that cargo is properly secured
questions.answer4: Ensuring the freshness of sealed cargo
questions.explanation: You are not responsible for the state of sealed cargo, nor can you inspect it. You are only responsible for the safety of the cargo, ensuring that it is balanced, secured, and not overloaded, and does not get in the way of emergency equipment.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are
questions.answer1: signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo.
questions.answer2: signs on the inside of the vehicle that remind the driver of what he or she is carrying.
questions.answer3: signs that help tax collectors determine how much to tax a hazardous cargo.
questions.answer4: signs that warn the public to stay at least 1,000 feet from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are four regulated signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo for those who need to know, such as emergency service personnel or those who load and unload cargo.

questions.question: When you start to drive down a steep downgrade, which of the following should influence your choice of speed?
questions.answer1: The total weight of your vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: When choosing a safe speed for driving down a steep downgrade, consider its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely to cause a vehicle fire?
questions.answer1: Driver smoking in a rest area
questions.answer3: Spilled fuel cleaned up quickly and properly
questions.explanation: Smoking, flammable cargo, and spilled fuel are potentially dangerous. Properly managed, however, they should not start a fire except under special circumstances such as a short circuit or loose connection.

questions.question: What can you do at an accident scene to help avoid another accident?
questions.answer1: Stay in your vehicle and do nothing until help arrives.
questions.answer2: Set out warning devices to keep other vehicles from running into the accident scene.
questions.answer3: Leave your vehicle, do nothing, and get to higher ground.
questions.answer4: Have a drink to calm your nerves.
questions.explanation: Unless you have been injured, it is your responsibility to ensure that others can see your vehicle at the accident scene. Set out your warning devices as quickly as possible to avoid further accidents such as a pile-up.

questions.question: Before transporting a sealed load, you must inspect
questions.answer1: a small sample of whatever is inside.
questions.answer2: a picture of whatever is inside.
questions.answer3: that you don't exceed gross weight or axle weight limits.
questions.explanation: While you cannot actually inspect sealed loads, it's still your responsibility to ensure that you do not exceed your axle weight limits or gross weight restrictions, so check them both.

questions.question: If you feel drowsy while driving, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Open the windows for some fresh air.
questions.answer3: Pull off the road and get some sleep.
questions.explanation: If you are drowsy, cold air, fresh air, or caffeinated beverages may make you feel more alert only momentarily. The only real solution is to get off the road as soon as possible and get some real rest.

questions.question: If you have a flat tire, you should not do which of the following?
questions.answer3: Brake hard and immediately.
questions.answer4: Be aware that a tire has failed.
questions.explanation: Hard braking could cause your vehicle to go out of control, so brake gently only after the vehicle has slowed down and you have regained control.

questions.question: What is a common cause of tire fires?
questions.answer3: Cold tires
questions.explanation: Underinflated tires and dual tires that touch are the most common causes of tire fires.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: Your body breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate. Typically, this is one standard drink per hour, where one standard drink equals 1.5 ounces of hard liquor, 5 ounces of wine, or 12 ounces of beer. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: How many tie-downs are required for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tie-down per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two per load, regardless of the length. So for 20 feet, you should have two tie-downs.

questions.question: During a walk-around inspection, you should check the front of your vehicle for
questions.answer3: loose or worn parts in the steering system.
questions.explanation: There are a lot of things to check at the front of your vehicle: the condition of the axle, the condition of the steering system, the condition of the windshield, and the condition of all lights and reflectors located on the front of the vehicle.

questions.question: If you're driving a vehicle with an automatic transmission, in which of these situations should you select a low range?
questions.answer1: If you start to get drowsy
questions.answer2: If you're going down a steep downgrade
questions.answer3: If you feel you're driving too fast
questions.explanation: If you keep applying the brakes to control your speed on a steep descent, the brakes will fade (lose their effectiveness). Instead, if your vehicle has a manual transmission, you should downshift; if your vehicle has an automatic transmission, you should select a low range that prevents the transmission from shifting up beyond the selected gear. This will generate a braking effect to slow the vehicle, known as engine braking. The lower the gear, the greater the engine braking effect. Apply the brakes only when engine braking is insufficient or you want to stop.

questions.question: If you must stop on a road or the shoulder of any road, you must set out your emergency warning devices within
questions.answer3: twenty minutes.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on a road or the shoulder of any road, you must set out your emergency warning devices within ten minutes.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a key steering system component?
questions.answer3: Leaf spring
questions.explanation: The tie rod, gear box, and steering shaft are parts of the steering system. A leaf spring is part of the suspension system.

questions.question: Which of these should you do during a trip as part of your en-route inspection?
questions.answer1: Watch your gauges to check for trouble.
questions.answer2: Use your other senses to detect trouble.
questions.answer3: Regularly check safety-critical items.
questions.explanation: During a trip, always be alert for any possible problems. Watch your gauges for indications of trouble. Use all your senses – including sight, hearing, and smell – to try to detect trouble. At each stop you make, check safety-critical items such as the lights, tires, and the cargo itself.

questions.question: You are in the right lane of a multi-lane highway. You see an emergency vehicle with its lights flashing that is stopped on the shoulder ahead. What should you do?
questions.answer3: Slow down; also move into a non-adjacent lane if possible.
questions.answer4: Move into a non-adjacent lane if possible; otherwise slow down.
questions.explanation: Under Georgia's Move Over Law, if you encounter an emergency vehicle, sanitation vehicle, utility vehicle, or tow truck that is stopped with its flashing lights on, you must move into a non-adjacent lane if possible, leaving at least one vacant lane between you and the vehicle. If this is impossible (e.g., no other lanes in your direction) or unsafe, you must slow down to a reasonable speed until you have passed the vehicle. (Note: All US states now have their own Move Over Laws, but some of them require drivers to do different things. When traveling out of state, always check the local traffic laws.) [Georgia's Move-Over Law, Section 5: Traffic Laws, Georgia Drivers Manual], [GA Code § 40-6-16]

questions.question: How do you test a vehicle's hydraulic brakes for leaks?
questions.answer1: Pump the brakes 3 times. Then apply firm pressure for 5 seconds.
questions.answer2: Pump the brakes 5 times. Then apply firm pressure for 3 seconds.
questions.answer3: Pump the brakes 3 times. Then apply firm pressure for 10 seconds.
questions.answer4: Apply firm pressure for 5 seconds. Then pump the brakes 3 times.
questions.explanation: To test a vehicle equipped with hydraulic brakes for leaks in the brakes, first pump the brakes three times. Next, apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. If it moves, the brakes may have a leak or some other problem.

questions.question: Why should you use a helper when you are backing?
questions.answer1: Because every truck has blind spots
questions.answer2: To make sure you don't damage your truck
questions.answer3: Because it's the law
questions.answer4: To check your style of driving
questions.explanation: You should use a helper when you are backing because you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals for "Go" and (most importantly) "Stop."

questions.question: The most significant hand gesture on which you and your assistance should both agree is
questions.answer3: Keep backing.
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: Total stopping distance equals
questions.answer2: perception distance + reaction distance + braking distance.
questions.answer3: perception distance + reaction distance.
questions.answer4: reaction distance + braking distance + signal distance.
questions.explanation: Total stopping distance is the sum of your perception distance (how far the vehicle goes from when you see the hazard until your brain processes it), reaction distance (how far the vehicle goes from when your brain orders your foot to take action until your foot actually starts to brake), and braking distance (how far the vehicle continues to travel once you apply the brake).

questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward the approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward the approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward the approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward the approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulation 49 CFR 392.22. This regulation also specifies where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as undivided two-way roads and curves. (These situations are also covered in section 2.5.2 of the Georgia Commercial Drivers Manual.)

questions.question: It has just reached freezing. Which of the following areas is slippery?
questions.answer3: A wet-looking road
questions.explanation: Once the temperature drops to freezing, some sections of road will start to freeze before others. The first to freeze will be shaded areas and bridges. If the road appears wet, it may be covered in black ice, a thin layer of slippery ice through which you can see the road.

questions.question: Which of the following are safe ways to communicate your presence?
questions.answer1: Tapping your horn when it's legal and you're about to pass
questions.answer2: Flashing your headlights at night when you're about to pass
questions.answer3: Using your headlights in bad weather
questions.explanation: There are several ways to safely communicate your presence and intentions. When you're about to pass, lightly tap your horn if it is legal to do so. At night, flash your headlights from low beam to high beam and back again. Use your headlights at night and whenever visibility is difficult, such as in bad weather. Whenever you pull off the road and stop, turn on your four-way emergency flashers. This is especially important at night.

questions.question: How far ahead should you look while driving, according to the Georgia Commercial Drivers Manual?
questions.answer3: 12 to 15 seconds
questions.explanation: According to the Georgia Commercial Drivers Manual, you should look ahead the distance that your CMV will travel in 12 to 15 seconds. At the slower speeds of city driving, your CMV will travel about one block in 15 seconds. At 60 mph, your CMV will travel a quarter mile (1,320 feet) in 15 seconds.

questions.question: If you are traveling at 55 mph in a 30-foot vehicle, you should leave how many seconds of following distance?
questions.answer3: Three seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. Therefore, for a 30-foot vehicle traveling at 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, which of the following should you NOT do?
questions.answer3: Avoid tricks such as flashing your brake lights.
questions.explanation: Don't try to speed up to outdistance or appease a tailgater. No speed is too fast for some tailgaters. Instead, increase your following distance and if possible, keep right to let the tailgater pass.

questions.question: What is the main difference between aggressive driving and road rage?
questions.answer3: Intent to do harm or physical assault
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is driving in a selfish or pushy manner, which is dangerous enough. Road rage is even worse: intentionally driving to harm someone or physically assaulting someone in his or her vehicle.

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you
questions.answer1: avoid using your cell phone until you reach your destination.
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in your first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: eat, drink, and smoke only on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no other vehicles around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. Avoid using your cell phone until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.
questions.answer3: Call the police from your cell phone if you can do it safely.
questions.explanation: When an aggressive driver is trying to confront you, do not give them the confrontation that they want. Instead, seek police, peace, and safety.

questions.question: Which lights should you use the most when driving at night?
questions.answer3: Emergency flashers
questions.explanation: While driving at night, you should use your high beams to see farther as long as it is safe and legal and you will not blind any other drivers. Section 2.11.5 of the Georgia Commercial Drivers Manual recommends that you dim your headlights whenever you are within 500 feet of any other vehicle.

questions.question: If your brakes get wet, they may
questions.answer3: rust immediately.
questions.explanation: If your brakes get wet, they may apply unevenly, work weakly, or grab, any of which can be dangerous. Try to maintain light pressure on the brakes for a short distance to heat them up and dry them out.

questions.question: When you're about to drive down a steep downgrade, which of the following should you do first?
questions.answer3: Release the brakes.
questions.explanation: When you're about to start down a steep downgrade, release the gas pedal, shift into a low gear, and use engine braking to slow your vehicle. Don't try to downshift after your speed has already built up. You will not be able to shift into a lower gear then. You may not even be able to get back into any gear and all engine braking effect will be lost. If you try to downshift an automatic transmission after your speed has already built up, you may damage the transmission.

questions.question: How many hours of sleep does the average person require per night, according to the Georgia Commercial Drivers Manual?
questions.answer3: Eight to nine hours
questions.explanation: Sleep debt is a dangerous condition in which missing sleep adds up until you risk falling asleep at the wheel unless you get some rest. People are often surprised that getting less than 6 hours of sleep per night triples the risk of an accident. At least 15 percent of heavy truck crashes are believed to involve driver fatigue. According to the Georgia Commercial Drivers Manual, the average person needs seven or eight hours of sleep every 24 hours.

questions.question: The minimum tire tread depth for front tires is
questions.answer3: 1/2 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels and any visible evidence of cracks or leaks.

questions.question: Your emergency kit does NOT need to include
questions.answer3: a fire extinguisher.
questions.explanation: While a jacket might keep you comfortable, it is not a required part of your emergency kit. You must have a working fire extinguisher, warning devices such as flares or reflective triangles, and spare electrical fuses (unless your vehicle has circuit breakers).

questions.question: Letting the air out of hot tires
questions.answer1: is a good idea because the extra pressure will be relieved.
questions.answer2: is a bad idea because when the tires cool off, the pressure will be too low.
questions.answer3: will have no effect at all.
questions.answer4: will cool them down. You will be able to continue your trip sooner.
questions.explanation: When tires get hot, the air pressure increases. However, relieving that extra pressure will leave the air pressure too low when the tires cool again, and then the tires may catch fire or blow out. If your tires are too hot to touch, stop until they have cooled down.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an antilock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: What is the definition of a hazard?
questions.answer2: A road user or road condition that presents a possible danger
questions.answer3: Something you must stop for
questions.explanation: A hazard is a road user or road condition that presents a possible danger. A hazard is something that can go wrong but shouldn't if you've been vigilant.

questions.question: What is the best method for calculating the number of seconds of following distance you have?
questions.answer1: Wait until the vehicle ahead of you passes a shadow or landmark. Then count the seconds until you reach it.
questions.answer2: Get 1/4 closer to the vehicle in front of you, then back off again. Multiply how long this took you by four to give the following distance.
questions.answer3: Use the stopwatch on your cell phone to determine how long it takes you to reach a mile marker after the vehicle in front of you has passed it.
questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to reach some stationary object after the vehicle in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here either don't work or involve dangerous distractions. Note that you should increase your following distance in heavy traffic, in bad weather, with heavy vehicles, or at higher speeds.

questions.question: To transport cargo safely, which of the following are you NOT responsible for?
questions.answer1: Ensuring the safety of the cargo
questions.answer3: Making sure that cargo is properly secured
questions.answer4: Ensuring the freshness of sealed cargo
questions.explanation: You are not responsible for the state of sealed cargo, nor can you inspect it. You are only responsible for the safety of the cargo, ensuring that it is balanced, secured, and not overloaded, and does not get in the way of emergency equipment.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are
questions.answer1: signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo.
questions.answer2: signs on the inside of the vehicle that remind the driver of what he or she is carrying.
questions.answer3: signs that help tax collectors determine how much to tax a hazardous cargo.
questions.answer4: signs that warn the public to stay at least 1,000 feet from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are four regulated signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo for those who need to know, such as emergency service personnel or those who load and unload cargo.

questions.question: When you start to drive down a steep downgrade, which of the following should influence your choice of speed?
questions.answer1: The total weight of your vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
