questions.explanation: When choosing a safe speed for driving down a steep downgrade, consider its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: If the engine is not overheated, is it completely safe to remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer3: Yes, as long as there is no overflow.
questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.
questions.explanation: It is not enough for the engine not to be overheated. The cooling system must cool completely before you attempt to remove the radiator cap. Even then, you should be very careful because there may still be tremendous pressure and damaging steam and fluids.

questions.question: Do empty trucks have the best braking?
questions.answer3: Yes, but only on wet surfaces.
questions.answer4: Yes, but only if the trucks are newer than 1998.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have longer stopping distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: An antilock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: keep your wheels from locking when you brake hard.
questions.explanation: ABS kicks in only to keep the wheels from locking, which could cause a skid. ABS does not change the way you normally brake the rest of the time. It is not a substitute for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, or regular maintenance.

questions.question: What can you do at an accident scene to help avoid another accident?
questions.answer1: Stay in your vehicle and do nothing until help arrives.
questions.answer2: Set out warning devices to keep other vehicles from running into the accident scene.
questions.answer3: Leave your vehicle, do nothing, and get to higher ground.
questions.answer4: Have a drink to calm your nerves.
questions.explanation: Unless you have been injured, it is your responsibility to ensure that others can see your vehicle at the accident scene. Set out your warning devices as quickly as possible to avoid further accidents such as a pile-up.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: All of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide to the left, a driver may try to pass you on your right while you are turning. Instead, make the right turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This will deny drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: In which of the following two situations should you downshift?
questions.answer1: Starting down a hill and entering a curve
questions.answer2: Starting up a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer3: Starting down a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer4: Starting up a hill and entering a curve
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill lets you take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required, which is usually lower than the gear required to climb the hill. Downshifting before a curve improves stability and helps you get the power you will need to accelerate out of the turn.

questions.question: You should put the starter switch key into your pocket while you perform the pre-trip inspection because
questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.
questions.answer3: it could damage the starting mechanism.
questions.answer4: any of the above could occur.
questions.explanation: While you are performing the pre-trip inspection, you do not want someone (such as a co-driver) who is unaware of your location to start your vehicle and accidentally injure you.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to brake to a stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your braking distance increases by roughly the square of the speed increase – to about four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 148 feet.

questions.question: On which of the following types of fires should you NOT use a B:C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Wood
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher should not be used on burning materials that you can use ordinary water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: If you feel drowsy while driving, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Open the windows for some fresh air.
questions.answer3: Pull off the road and get some sleep.
questions.explanation: If you are drowsy, cold air, fresh air, or caffeinated beverages may make you feel more alert only momentarily. The only real solution is to get off the road as soon as possible and get some real rest.

questions.question: Which of the following might get stuck at a raised railroad crossing?
questions.answer3: Lowboy
questions.explanation: The two types of combination vehicles most likely to get stuck at a raised railroad crossing are low-slung units (car carriers, lowboys, moving vans, etc.) and single-axle tractors that are pulling a long trailer with its landing gear set to accommodate a tandem-axle tractor. Be very careful when driving such vehicles at railroad crossings.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about an escape ramp is FALSE?
questions.answer1: It may be located a few miles from the top of a downgrade.
questions.answer2: It is of no use if you are traveling too fast.
questions.answer3: It may be made of soft gravel.
questions.explanation: Escape ramps are designed with soft gravel, upgrades, or both, to slow down vehicles that experience brake failure on a downgrade. Regardless of your speed, look for one of these escape ramps, which can save lives, equipment, and cargo. Find out ahead of time where the escape ramps are located on your route.

questions.question: Which of the following retarder assertions is true?
questions.answer1: Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for braking.
questions.answer2: When your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarder may cause them to skid.
questions.answer3: You should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow covered.
questions.answer4: All of the above statements are correct.
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should always turn off your retarders in poor weather.

questions.question: If you have a flat tire, you should not do which of the following?
questions.answer3: Brake hard and immediately.
questions.answer4: Be aware that a tire has failed.
questions.explanation: Hard braking could cause your vehicle to go out of control, so brake gently only after the vehicle has slowed down and you have regained control.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: Your body breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate. Typically, this is one standard drink per hour, where one standard drink equals 1.5 ounces of hard liquor, 5 ounces of wine, or 12 ounces of beer. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: How many tie-downs are required for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tie-down per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two per load, regardless of the length. So for 20 feet, you should have two tie-downs.

questions.question: How long does it take a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double railroad track?
questions.answer3: More than 30 seconds
questions.explanation: You can expect it to take more than 15 seconds for a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double track and at least 14 seconds to clear a single track.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels and any visible evidence of cracks or leaks.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key steering component?
questions.answer3: Gear box
questions.explanation: The gear box is an integral part of the steering system. The other three choices are parts of the suspension system.

questions.question: What is the gross vehicle weight (GVW)?
questions.answer1: A vehicle's maximum weight rating, specified by its manufacturer
questions.answer2: The total weight of the vehicle, towed vehicles, and the load
questions.answer3: The total weight of a single vehicle and its load
questions.explanation: GVW is the simplest of the vehicle weight terms, defined as the weight of just a single vehicle and the load that it is carrying.

questions.question: On which of the following types of fires should you NOT use a B:C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Wood
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher should not be used on burning materials that you can use ordinary water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Letting the air out of hot tires
questions.answer1: is a good idea because the extra pressure will be relieved.
questions.answer2: is a bad idea because when the tires cool off, the pressure will be too low.
questions.answer3: will have no effect at all.
questions.answer4: will cool them down. You will be able to continue your journey sooner.
questions.explanation: When tires get hot, the air pressure increases. However, relieving that extra pressure will leave the air pressure too low when the tires cool again, and then the tires may catch fire or blow out. If your tires are too hot to touch, stop until they have cooled down.

questions.question: How do you get started without rolling backwards?
questions.answer1: Put on the parking brake whenever necessary.
questions.answer2: Engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake.
questions.answer3: Apply the trailer brake hand valve.
questions.explanation: If you have a manual transmission vehicle, partly engage the clutch before you take your right foot off the brake. Put on the parking brake whenever necessary to keep from rolling back. Release the parking brake only when you have applied enough engine power to keep from rolling back. On a tractor-trailer equipped with a trailer brake hand valve, the hand valve can be applied to keep from rolling back.

questions.question: If you are traveling at 55 mph in a 30-foot vehicle, you should leave ___ seconds of following distance.
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. So for a 30-foot vehicle going 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: Total stopping distance equals
questions.answer3: perception distance + reaction distance + braking distance.
questions.answer4: reaction distance + viewing distance + braking distance.
questions.explanation: Total stopping distance is the sum of your perception distance (how far the vehicle goes from when you see the hazard until your brain processes it), reaction distance (how far the vehicle goes from when your brain orders your foot to take action until your foot actually starts to brake), and braking distance (how far the vehicle continues to travel once you apply the brake).

questions.question: To transport cargo safely, which of these are you NOT responsible for?
questions.answer3: Making sure that cargo is properly secured
questions.answer4: Ensuring the freshness of sealed cargo
questions.explanation: You are not responsible for the state of sealed cargo, nor can you inspect it. You are only responsible for the safety of the cargo, ensuring that it is balanced, secured, and not overloaded, and does not get in the way of emergency equipment.

questions.question: You should do the following to assist you stay aware and safe while driving:
questions.answer1: avoid medications whose warning labels mention drowsiness.
questions.answer2: drink coffee if you get drowsy.
questions.answer3: roll down your windows to get fresh air.
questions.answer4: have a whiskey to brace yourself.
questions.explanation: Be careful with medications that warn you they may cause drowsiness. If you have a concern about prescribed medications, speak with your doctor. Do not try to fight sleepiness with coffee, fresh air, or especially alcohol. The only "cure" for being tired is sleeping until you are rested.

questions.question: What is the minimum age to receive a CDL in the state of Hawaii?
questions.explanation: In Hawaii, you must be at least 21 years of age to get a CDL.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about retarders is correct?
questions.answer1: Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for braking.
questions.answer2: If your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarder may cause them to skid.
questions.answer3: You should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow-covered.
questions.answer4: All of the above statements are correct.
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should always turn off your retarder in poor weather.

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you
questions.answer1: turn off your cell phone until you reach your destination.
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in the first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: smoke, eat, and drink on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no other vehicles around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. If possible, turn off your phone and keep it off until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: Always try to back toward the driver's side because
questions.answer1: it's more comfortable for turning your neck.
questions.answer2: you can see better, watching the vehicle's rear out the side window.
questions.answer3: your truck will naturally pull toward the driver's side.
questions.answer4: all of the above are true.
questions.explanation: You should always back toward the driver's side because you will be able to see things much more easily. For example, you can keep an eye on the vehicle's rear by viewing it out your side window. If your truck pulls in either direction, it needs service. Your neck's comfort should not affect your safety decision.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: Any of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide, a driver might try to pass you on your right while you are turning. Instead, make the turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This will deny drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: An anti-lock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: keep your brakes from locking up when you brake hard.
questions.explanation: ABS kicks in only to keep the wheels from locking up, which could cause a skid. ABS does not change the way you normally brake the rest of the time. It is not a substitute for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, or regular maintenance.

questions.question: If you have a flat tire, you should not do which of the following?
questions.answer3: Engage the brakes hard and immediately.
questions.answer4: Be aware that a tire has failed.
questions.explanation: Braking could cause the vehicle to go out of control, so brake gently only after the vehicle has slowed down and you have regained control.

questions.question: Which of the following should NOT be checked during a trip?
questions.answer3: Text messages
questions.explanation: During your trip, you should keep an eye on all your vehicle's key components, such as the instruments, gauges, tires, voltmeter, mirrors, and cargo. Make sure you put your cell phone away for the entire journey. Have it available only for emergencies.

questions.question: How many hours of sleep per night does the average person need to avoid accumulating sleep debt?
questions.answer3: 8 to 9 hours
questions.explanation: In sleep debt, missing sleep adds up until you risk falling asleep at the wheel until you have fully rested. Surprisingly, studies have shown that getting only six hours or less of sleep per night triples your risk of an accident.

questions.question: While you are on the road, how often must you stop to check your cargo?
questions.answer3: Every three hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, in Hawaii, you must check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your journey and then every three hours or 150 miles, whichever comes first.

questions.question: Starting the engine and inspecting the cab involves each of these tasks, except
questions.answer3: starting the engine, then listening for unusual noises.
questions.answer4: starting the engine, then putting the gearshift in neutral.
questions.explanation: Please note that the question contains an 'except' clause! When performing this part of the inspection, however, you must put the gearshift in neutral, then start the engine and listen for any unusual noises. Once you perform the engine check, you will check all your gauges and controls, such as the air pressure gauge and transmission controls.

questions.question: What is the best method for calculating the number of seconds of following distance you have?
questions.answer1: Wait until the vehicle ahead of you passes a shadow or landmark. Then start to count the seconds until you pass it.
questions.answer2: Get 1/4 closer to the car in front of you, then back off again. Multiply how long this took you by four to give the following distance.
questions.answer3: Use the stopwatch on your cell phone to determine how long it takes you to reach a mile marker after the car in front of you has passed it.
questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to pass some object after the vehicle in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here either will not work or involve dangerous distractions. Note that you should increase your following distance in heavy traffic, in bad weather, with heavy vehicles, or at higher speeds.

questions.question: If the engine is not overheated, is it completely safe to remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer3: Yes, as long as there is no overflow.
questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.
questions.explanation: It is not enough for the engine not to be overheated. The cooling system must cool completely before you attempt to remove the radiator cap. Even then, you should be very careful because there may still be tremendous pressure and damaging steam and fluids.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an anti-lock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: In which of the following two situations should you downshift?
questions.answer1: Starting down a hill and entering a curve
questions.answer2: Starting up a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer3: Starting down a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer4: Starting up a hill and entering a curve
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill allows you to take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required, which is usually lower than the gear required to climb the hill. Downshifting before a curve improves stability and helps you get the power you will need to accelerate out of the turn.

questions.question: The minimum tread depth for front tires is
questions.answer3: 1/2 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: Before transporting a sealed load, you must inspect
questions.answer1: a small sample of whatever is inside.
questions.answer2: a picture of whatever is inside.
questions.answer3: that you don't exceed gross weight or axle weight limits.
questions.explanation: You cannot actually inspect sealed loads. However, it's still your responsibility to ensure that you do not exceed your axle weight limits or your gross weight restrictions, so check them both.

questions.question: What can you do at an accident scene to help avoid another accident?
questions.answer1: Stay in your vehicle and do nothing until help arrives.
questions.answer2: Set out warning devices to keep other vehicles from running into the accident scene.
questions.answer3: Leave your vehicle, do nothing, and get to higher ground.
questions.answer4: Have a drink to calm your nerves.
questions.explanation: Unless you have been injured, it is your responsibility to ensure that others can see your vehicle at an accident scene. Set out your warning devices as quickly as possible to avoid further accidents such as a pile-up.

questions.question: It has just reached freezing. Which of the following areas may be slippery?
questions.answer3: A wet-looking road
questions.explanation: Once the temperature drops to freezing, some sections of the road will start to freeze before others. The first to freeze will be shaded areas and bridges. If the road appears wet, it may be covered in black ice – a thin layer of slippery ice through which you can see the actual road.

questions.question: What is the most important hand signal that you and a helper should agree on?
questions.answer3: “Stop.”
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: Which is NOT one of the four skill areas that operating a commercial vehicle requires?
questions.answer3: First-aid certification
questions.explanation: As described in detail in section 2.2 of the CDL manual, the four basic skills for safe operation of a commercial vehicle are accelerating, steering, stopping, and backing safely. While first-aid certification could certainly come in handy at some point in your career, it is not one of the four basic skills.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your stopping distance increases to almost four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 148 feet.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT part of the basic method of shifting up?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, push in the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, push in the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: Which of the following factors can influence the safe speed for going down a steep downgrade?
questions.answer1: The total weight of the vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: There are several factors that may influence your choice of a safe speed for going down a steep downgrade: its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: For how long will you lose your CDL driving privileges if you are convicted of a second DUI offense?
questions.answer3: Life
questions.explanation: Due to nationwide drunk driving laws, a second DUI offense in either a CMV or non-CMV vehicle will cause you to lose your CDL for life. (See Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations Part 383.51, issued by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA)). Your first offense is a wake-up call and a chance to get help, but your second offense is going to mean unemployment. If you get a DUI, seek help before you lose your salary and your future.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time

questions.question: Why should you cover cargo?

questions.answer2: To protect your cargo from bad weather

questions.explanation: There are several reasons to cover your cargo, including protecting other people and the cargo itself. In addition, it will help you comply with regulations in several states.

questions.question: You should put the starter switch key into your pocket while you perform the pre-trip inspection because
questions.answer1: it could damage the steering mechanism.
questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.

questions.answer2: A road user or road condition that presents a possible danger

questions.question: Which lights should you use the most when driving at night?

questions.answer2: ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.

questions.answer2: because people feel more comfortable when you do.

questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
