If the road appears wet, it may be covered in black ice, a thin layer of slippery ice through which you can see the road.

questions.question: When backing, it is important to use a helper
questions.answer2: because people feel more comfortable when you do.
questions.answer3: because you are providing a job for someone else.
questions.answer4: for all of the above reasons.
questions.explanation: It is important to use a helper when you are backing since you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals – especially "Stop."

questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations Part 392.22, issued by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA). These regulations also specify where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as two-way roads and curves. (Those situations are also covered in section 2.5.2 of the Idaho Commercial Driver's Manual.)

questions.question: When you are driving at night, which lights should you use as often as you can?
questions.answer3: Emergency flashers
questions.explanation: When driving at night, you should use your high beams to expand your field of vision as often as possible, as long as it is safe and legal and you will not blind any other drivers. The rule of thumb is to use high beams as long as there are no approaching vehicles within 500 feet.

questions.question: While you are on the road, how often must you stop to check your cargo?
questions.answer3: Every three hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, in Idaho, you must check the securement of your cargo within the first 50 miles of your journey and then every three hours or 150 miles, whichever comes first.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about retarders is correct?
questions.answer1: Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for braking.
questions.answer2: If your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarder may cause them to skid.
questions.answer3: You should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow-covered.
questions.answer4: All of the above statements are correct.
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should always turn off your retarder in poor weather.

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you
questions.answer1: turn off your cell phone until you reach your destination.
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in the first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: smoke, eat, and drink on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no other vehicles around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. If possible, turn off your phone and keep it off until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: Always try to back toward the driver's side because
questions.answer1: it's more comfortable for turning your neck.
questions.answer2: you can see better, watching the vehicle's rear out the side window.
questions.answer3: your truck will naturally pull toward the driver's side.
questions.answer4: all of the above are true.
questions.explanation: You should always back toward the driver's side because you will be able to see things much more easily. For example, you can keep an eye on the vehicle's rear by viewing it out your side window. If your truck pulls in either direction, it needs service. Your neck's comfort should not affect your safety decision.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: Any of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide, a driver might try to pass you on your right while you are turning. Instead, make the turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This will deny drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: Which of the following should NOT be checked during a trip?
questions.answer3: Text messages
questions.explanation: During your trip, you should keep an eye on all your vehicle's key components, such as the instruments, gauges, tires, voltmeter, mirrors, and cargo. Make sure you put your cell phone away for the entire journey. Have it available only for emergencies.

questions.question: What is the best method for calculating the number of seconds of following distance you have?
questions.answer1: Wait until the vehicle ahead of you passes a shadow or landmark. Then start to count the seconds until you pass it.
questions.answer2: Get 1/4 closer to the car in front of you, then back off again. Multiply how long this took you by four to give the following distance.
questions.answer3: Use the stopwatch on your cell phone to determine how long it takes you to reach a mile marker after the car in front of you has passed it.
questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to pass some object after the vehicle in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here either will not work or involve dangerous distractions. Note that you should increase your following distance in heavy traffic, in bad weather, with heavy vehicles, or at higher speeds.

questions.question: If the engine is not overheated, is it completely safe to remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer3: Yes, as long as there is no overflow.
questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.
questions.explanation: It is not enough for the engine not to be overheated. The cooling system must cool completely before you attempt to remove the radiator cap. Even then, you should be very careful because there may still be tremendous pressure and damaging steam and fluids.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an anti-lock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: In which of the following two situations should you downshift?
questions.answer1: Starting down a hill and entering a curve
questions.answer2: Starting up a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer3: Starting down a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer4: Starting up a hill and entering a curve
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill allows you to take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required, which is usually lower than the gear required to climb the hill. Downshifting before a curve improves stability and helps you get the power you will need to accelerate out of the turn.

questions.question: The minimum tread depth for front tires is
questions.answer3: 1/2 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: What can you do at an accident scene to help avoid another accident?
questions.answer1: Stay in your vehicle and do nothing until help arrives.
questions.answer2: Set out warning devices to keep other vehicles from running into the accident scene.
questions.answer3: Leave your vehicle, do nothing, and get to higher ground.
questions.answer4: Have a drink to calm your nerves.
questions.explanation: Unless you have been injured, it is your responsibility to ensure that others can see your vehicle at an accident scene. Set out your warning devices as quickly as possible to avoid further accidents such as a pile-up.

questions.question: What is the most important hand signal that you and a helper should agree on?
questions.answer3: “Stop.”
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: Which is NOT one of the four skill areas that operating a commercial vehicle requires?
questions.answer3: First-aid certification
questions.explanation: As described in detail in section 2.2 of the CDL manual, the four basic skills for safe operation of a commercial vehicle are accelerating, steering, stopping, and backing safely. While first-aid certification could certainly come in handy at some point in your career, it is not one of the four basic skills.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your stopping distance increases to almost four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 148 feet.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT part of the basic method of shifting up?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, push in the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, push in the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: Which of the following factors can influence the safe speed for going down a steep downgrade?
questions.answer1: The total weight of the vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: There are several factors that may influence your choice of a safe speed for going down a steep downgrade: its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: Your liver breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate, typically one standard drink (one ounce of hard liquor or one-half glass of wine) per hour. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are
questions.answer1: signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo.
questions.answer2: signs on the inside of the vehicle that remind the driver of what he or she is carrying.
questions.answer3: signs that help tax collectors determine how much to tax a hazardous cargo.
questions.answer4: signs that warn the public to stay at least 1,000 feet away from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are four regulated signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo for those who need to know, such as emergency service personnel or those who load and unload cargo.

questions.question: Why should you cover cargo?
questions.answer1: To protect individuals from any spilled cargo
questions.answer2: To protect your cargo from bad weather
questions.answer3: Because many states require it
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: There are several reasons to cover your cargo, including protecting other people and the cargo itself. In addition, it will help you comply with regulations in several states.

questions.question: Tire fires are commonly caused by
questions.answer3: cold tires.
questions.explanation: Underinflated tires and dual tires that touch are the most common causes of tire fires.

questions.question: What is the definition of a hazard?
questions.answer2: A road user or road condition that presents a possible danger
questions.answer3: Something you must stop for
questions.explanation: A hazard is a road user or road condition that presents a possible danger. A hazard is something that could go wrong but shouldn't if you've been vigilant.

questions.question: When evaluating hoses with the instructor during your pre-trip examination, seek for
questions.answer3: frays in the water pump belt.
questions.answer4: a low windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: During your pre-trip test, when inspecting hoses, you need to look for signs of leaks, such as puddles on the ground or fluids that are dripping on the underside of the engine or transmission. Also check the hoses for cracks or other problems.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should
questions.answer2: ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.
questions.answer3: call the police from your cell phone if you can do it safely.
questions.explanation: When an aggressive driver is trying to confront you, do not give the person the confrontation that he or she seeks. Instead, seek police, peace, and safety.

questions.question: How speed you should reduce when you drive on wet roads?
questions.answer3: one-third.
questions.explanation: When a road is wet, stopping distance is increased, and you should reduce your speed by one-third. On snow, slow to one-half your usual speed. On icy roads, slow to a crawl and stop driving as soon as you can do so safely.

questions.question: How long does it take for a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double railroad track?
questions.answer3: More than 30 seconds
questions.explanation: You can expect it to take more than 15 seconds for a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double track and at least 14 seconds to clear a single track.

questions.question: Do empty trucks have the best braking?
questions.answer3: Yes, but only on wet surfaces.
questions.answer4: Yes, but only if the trucks are newer than 1998.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have greater stopping distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: Which of these should you watch for as you first approach your vehicle?
questions.answer3: Low-hanging tree limbs
questions.explanation: Before doing anything with your vehicle, you should check for all potential hazards in the vicinity.

questions.question: Which of the following should NOT influence your choice of speed when beginning a long downgrade?
questions.answer3: The steepness of the downgrade
questions.answer4: The weight of your vehicle plus its cargo
questions.explanation: You should handle the downgrade according to the conditions you are facing, not your schedule.

questions.question: When can you safely remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer2: Anytime, as long as the engine isn't overheated
questions.answer3: Whenever it is cold outside
questions.answer4: When the cap is cool enough to touch with a bare hand
questions.explanation: Don't take any chances with the radiator cap. If you open it while it is still hot, you can receive a blast of steam that can cause serious injury.

questions.question: What shoud you do if you come across a crew work on the highway?
questions.answer3: flash your lights.
questions.explanation: Road workers may have their backs to you and may be operating heavy machinery that will keep them from hearing you. Slow down and be prepared if some of the workers present a hazard.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about a spare tire is FALSE?
questions.answer1: It must be the correct size.
questions.answer2: It must come from the same manufacturer as the truck's tires.
questions.answer3: It must be in good condition.
questions.explanation: A spare tire must be the right size, in good condition, and at the right pressure. It does not need to come from the same manufacturer, however.

questions.question: What is the minimum tread depth for tires that are not front tires?
questions.answer3: 1/32 inch
questions.explanation: The minimum tread depth is 2/32 inch. If it's right on the limit, it will soon need to be changed.

questions.question: Why might your brakes begin to fade while driving downhill?
questions.answer1: Because they've picked up gravel from the road
questions.answer3: Because they are overheating
questions.explanation: As your brakes start to heat up, they may become spongy and less effective. This is why it is essential to take advantage of engine braking. If you rely solely on your brakes, you may soon find yourself with no brakes at all.

questions.question: When inspecting your vehicle's load, ensure that it conforms to
questions.answer1: the local regulations of the jurisdiction you are starting from.
questions.answer3: the state regulations of your destination.
questions.answer4: all local, state, and federal regulations that apply to your journey.
questions.explanation: You are responsible for adhering to the regulations of every jurisdiction through which you drive. It is insufficient to adhere just to the regulations of your departure point or destination; you might stop in a state or city with different regulations.

questions.question: A GPS device
questions.answer1: should have audible as well as visual warnings.
questions.answer2: should have a screen larger than 4 inches.
questions.answer3: should be made in the USA.
questions.answer4: should be designed for truck navigation.
questions.explanation: You should always use a GPS system that is designed for truck navigation. Such a truck-enabled GPS device contains information about truck-restricted roadways and designated routes and takes into account the size of your truck (length, weight, height, and load types) as it routes. A truck-enabled GPS device won't direct you onto roads that are unsuitable for your truck or on which trucks are prohibited.

questions.question: What is the safest way to control your speed on a downgrade?
questions.answer2: Use your brakes at all times.
questions.answer3: Coast in neutral.
questions.explanation: On very long downgrades, your brakes won't be able to do the job on their own. However, if you select the correct low gear, engine braking will slow your vehicle. This will allow you to preserve your brakes for particularly steep areas instead of using them all the time and having them fade.

questions.question: Which of the following should cause you to refuse a vehicle until it is repaired?
questions.answer3: Tires that are retreads
questions.answer4: Tires that have different tread patterns
questions.explanation: Tires of different sizes can cause serious imbalances, steering problems, and braking difficulties.

questions.question: What should you do if you detect exhaust fumes inside the cab?
questions.answer3: Make a note on your post-trip report.
questions.explanation: Exhaust fumes leaking into the cab can be fatal, either by poisoning you or making you drowsy and thus inviting an accident. Stop at once and don't continue until the problem has been found and corrected.

questions.question: What is the safety distance between you and the vehicle in front if you're driving a 30-foot vehicle at less than 40 miles per hour?
questions.answer3: 4 seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. So for a 30-foot vehicle below 40 mph, this works out to 3 seconds. This is the minimum; other factors such as visibility and road conditions may require you to leave more room.

questions.question: What are blocking and bracing?
questions.answer2: A way to keep cargo secure
questions.answer3: A form of coupling
questions.explanation: Blocking is placing material tightly around your cargo to prevent movement. Bracing involves struts running from the top part of the cargo to the floor or walls of the cargo compartment, also to prevent movement.

questions.question: What is the most important reason for performing a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answer1: To make sure that the vehicle is safe
questions.answer2: To make sure you won't be blamed for any existing damage
questions.answer3: To make sure you've got the right paperwork
questions.answer4: To make sure you've signed for the right cargo
questions.explanation: The safety of the vehicle is always paramount.

questions.question: Who is in charge of ensuring that all lights and mirrors are clean?
questions.answer3: Whoever drove the vehicle previously
questions.explanation: Even if the mirrors and lights have been cleaned already, they may get dirty before you take the vehicle out or on your trip. Always have a clean rag or sponge handy to keep them in the best condition.

questions.question: Where should you stop if your car catches fire?
questions.answer3: Near a building
questions.explanation: Keep a burning vehicle away from anything else that could catch fire. In particular, don't go near a service station; the truck fire could ignite gasoline.

questions.question: What is the most important reason to signal ahead of time?
questions.answer1: To encourage other drivers to pass you
questions.answer2: To encourage other drivers to pull into your lane in front of you
questions.answer3: To avoid using the four-way emergency flashers when you are driving very slowly
questions.answer4: To discourage other drivers from trying to pass you
questions.explanation: Warn the drivers behind you that you're about to turn. If you don't signal in time, they may try to pass you on the inside.

questions.question: Which of the following will NOT prevent distracted driving?
questions.answer3: Pre-loosening the lid of your coffee cup
questions.answer4: Adjusting all your mirrors before you start
questions.explanation: Before starting your trip, you should set up your cab just as you like it, but eating and drinking should be done at rest stops.

questions.question: What should you do to avoid being sleepy while driving?
questions.answer1: Open the windows to get some fresh air.
questions.answer3: Stop and sleep.
questions.explanation: The only way to overcome sleep debt is to sleep. Don't take any chances and don't try to beat nature, especially not with drugs or pills.

questions.question: Why are warning placards required on vehicles transporting hazardous materials?
questions.answer1: To warn other drivers to keep their distance
questions.answer2: So traffic cameras can track you
questions.answer3: To let emergency services know what they are dealing with in case of an accident
questions.answer4: To remind you to take extra care
questions.explanation: If you are injured in an accident, you may be unable to tell emergency services what kind of load you're carrying. That's why a vehicle carrying hazardous materials must be clearly marked as such. This will help emergency services to properly assess the situation.

questions.question: Your truck's stopping distance will be shortest when it is
questions.answer3: two-thirds empty.
questions.explanation: It may not be obvious, but the stopping distance will be shortest when the truck is fully loaded. This is because everything about the truck was designed to work best with a full load. When you drive an empty or partially filled truck, be aware that your stopping distances may be longer.

questions.question: Where can you find the maximum weight loading for a given tire pressure?
questions.answer3: On the dashboard
questions.explanation: Every tire should have its maximum weight loadings for different tire pressures written on the tire wall.

questions.question: How far into your journey should you conduct your first cargo inspection?
questions.answer3: Within 50 miles
questions.explanation: Finding out that your load was poorly secured can prevent a major disaster. You must inspect the securement of your cargo within the first 50 miles and then every 150 miles or every three hours (whichever comes first) afterward. [2.1.6- Inspection During Trips; Section 2: Driving Safely; Illinois Commercial Drivers License Study Guide]

questions.question: Which of the following should NOT be a cause for concern when inspecting your tires?
questions.answer3: Tires from different manufacturers
questions.explanation: As long as the tires match in size, are properly inflated, and are in good shape, they don't have to be from the same manufacturer.

questions.question: How should you check for leaks in hydraulic brakes?
questions.answer1: Drive forward, then slam on the brakes hard.
questions.answer2: Depress the pedal and listen for leaks.
questions.answer3: Hold the brake pedal down for 5 seconds, then pump it 3 times.
questions.answer4: Pump the brake pedal 3 times, then hold it down for 5 seconds.
questions.explanation: Pumping the brake pedal should cause resistance. Then you should be able to hold the brake pedal for 5 seconds without feeling any weakness or give.

questions.question: What should you do when you have a choice of two left turn lanes?
questions.answer1: use the one on the left.
questions.answer2: use the one on the right.
questions.answer3: use either.
questions.explanation: If there are two left turn lanes, use the one on the right. That will leave you more room to swing around the turn and make it easier for you to see traffic on your left.

questions.question: What is the prerequisite for step 2 of the seven-step inspection (Check Engine Compartment)?
questions.answer1: the parking brakes are on and/or the wheels are chocked.
questions.answer3: all lights are working.
questions.explanation: Before doing anything physical with the vehicle, make sure that it can't move and endanger you or others.

questions.question: How do you calculate the safe distance between your vehicle and the one ahead of you?
questions.answer1: Count the seconds from when the vehicle ahead of you passes some object to when you reach that same object.
questions.answer3: Estimate the length of the vehicle in front, then estimate how many vehicle lengths there are between it and you.
questions.answer4: Use your odometer to measure a specific distance and divide it by the time it took you to reach there.
questions.explanation: Count the seconds from when the vehicle ahead of you passes some object to when you reach that same object. This is the simplest and most accurate way to make this calculation.

questions.question: Why you must be in the right gear before descending a hill?
questions.answer1: it will help you speed up when you get to the bottom.
questions.answer2: it's illegal to change gears on a hill.
questions.answer3: it will help extend the life of the transmission.
questions.answer4: you won't be able to downshift after you start descending.
questions.explanation: Engine braking is essential when descending a hill, which means you have to be in a low gear before starting downhill. Once the wheels start to speed up, it may be difficult or impossible to shift gears.

questions.question: What is the best way to know what another driver is doing?
questions.answer1: Watch the driver's head and body movements.
questions.answer2: Watch the speed of the driver's vehicle.
questions.answer3: Watch the rear lights of the driver's vehicle.
questions.answer4: Guess what you would do in that driver's situation.
questions.explanation: Drivers may forget to signal, but they rarely fail to look where they are going. If you're close enough to observe another driver's head and body movements, you may pick up valuable clues about the driver's next action.

questions.question: In which occasions should you do not use your low beam headlights?
questions.answer3: in rain.
questions.explanation: Low beams can be helpful in conditions of dim light or poor visibility. You don't need them when driving through patches of shade. In fact, flicking them on and off might distract or confuse other drivers.

questions.question: When backing up, which side should you back toward?
questions.answer3: Either side
questions.explanation: If given a choice, always back toward the left side because you can see more on that side.

questions.question: How many times should you shift gears while crossing railroad tracks?
questions.answer3: Twice
questions.answer4: As many times as you think necessary
questions.explanation: You must not shift gears as you cross railroad tracks because it would increase the likelihood of a stall. Make sure you're in the right gear before you start to cross.

questions.question: How often should you check your gauges (air pressure, temperature, etc.)?
questions.answer1: At the beginning and end of each trip
questions.answer3: Every time the vehicle is stationary
questions.explanation: After your senses, your gauges are the next best way to monitor the status of your vehicle. Check them regularly.

questions.question: What should you do seeing a hazard ahead?
questions.answer1: Speed up to pass it as quickly as possible.
questions.answer3: Alert others by pointing and sounding your horn.
questions.answer4: Start planning what to do if the hazard becomes an emergency.
questions.explanation: A hazard is only a potential emergency. Don't act out of panic, but calmly plan what to do if matters get worse.

questions.question: When double clutching, what should you do if you have difficulty getting into the next gear?
questions.answer1: Force the lever until you get into gear.
questions.answer2: Drop back to the previous gear.
questions.answer3: Rev the engine to jolt the transmission.
questions.answer4: Return to neutral, increase the engine speed to match road speed, and try again.
questions.explanation: If you have difficulty getting into the next gear, do NOT try to force it. Instead, return to neutral, release the clutch, increase the engine speed to match road speed, and try again.

questions.question: How should you care for conscious accident victims?
questions.answer3: Get them to walk around if they can.
questions.explanation: Do not move accident victims unless there is a danger of fire or explosion or from passing traffic. Do not give them food, drinks, or drugs because that might worsen their symptoms or injuries. If someone is bleeding heavily, try to stanch it by applying pressure. Otherwise, just keep them warm until medical help arrives.

questions.question: What's the most important tool you have for monitoring the condition of your vehicle on the road?
questions.answer3: Comments from other truckers
questions.explanation: Become thoroughly familiar with your vehicle so that you will be able to sense any changes immediately. Use your senses (look, listen, smell, feel) to detect problems.

questions.question: You should have at least one tie-down for every ____ feet of cargo.
questions.explanation: The rule is one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. However, you must have a minimum of two tie-downs for any cargo, no matter how small.

questions.question: DO NOT use water on a _______ fire
questions.answer3: wood
questions.explanation: If you pour water on burning gasoline, you will just spread the burning gasoline over a wider area. Instead, use a fire extinguisher that is rated class B (flammable liquids) at least.

questions.question: To pull away in snow or icy conditions, you should
questions.answer2: quickly accelerate to your desired speed.
questions.answer3: let the vehicle start to slide before applying the accelerator.
questions.answer4: keep the brake partially depressed as you pull away.
questions.explanation: Excessive acceleration or braking can cause wheelspin and skids, especially in snow or ice. Careful, gradual, gentle acceleration can avoid this.

questions.question: As you approach on- and off-ramps, you should remember
questions.answer3: that the length of the ramp may be too short.
questions.answer4: that the posted speed limit may be too high for your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Posted speed limits are a maximum, not a mandate. You should consider taking on- and off-ramps well below posted speed limits, especially if your vehicle or cargo have a relatively high center of gravity. (Tests have actually shown that tankers can roll over at the speed limits posted for curves.)

questions.question: Both federal and state law require __________ to inspect a commercial motor vehicle before a trip.
questions.answer2: the driver and a qualified engineer
questions.answer3: the driver
questions.explanation: The responsibility for the safety and roadworthiness of your vehicle is yours alone.

questions.question: Why should you make sure to keep your vehicle in the middle of your lane?
questions.answer1: To keep other vehicles from passing you
questions.answer3: To let other drivers get the best view of you
questions.answer4: To leave the most space for a turn
questions.explanation: Many roads have drop-offs (sharp differences in elevation) at their edges. These can disrupt your steering or tilt your vehicle toward the side of the road so that it catches overhanging trees or wires. In fact, research has shown that a pavement drop-off of as little as 2 inches can cause loss of control when the driver attempts to return to the center of the lane. Leave a decent space from the edge of the road so you won't slip into a drop-off.

questions.question: Which of these substances can impair your ability to drive safely?
questions.answer3: Some prescription medications
questions.explanation: Some prescription medications and some over-the-counter cold medicines may cause drowsiness. Always check the label. If you're still unsure, ask your pharmacist or doctor before taking them.

questions.question: You should downshift in advance before
questions.answer3: approaching a bridge.
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill allows you to take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required, which is usually lower than the gear required to climb the hill. Downshifting before a curve will slow you down and help you get the power you will need to accelerate out of the curve.

questions.question: In very hot weather, how often should you inspect your tires?
questions.answer3: Every 3 hours or every 150 miles
questions.explanation: If your tires are too hot to touch with your bare hands, then they are too hot to drive safely with. Let them cool down, which will naturally bring them back to their correct pressure as well. Don't be tempted to let air out, because once the tires cool, the pressure will drop too low.

questions.question: Your hands should be at the _______ o'clock positions on the steering wheel.
questions.answer3: 10 and 2
questions.explanation: Keeping your hands opposite each other on the steering wheel helps you stay in control if anything such as a pothole tries to wrench the wheel out of your hands.

questions.question: The aggregate working load limit of your cargo tiedowns must be at least ______ times the weight of the cargo.
questions.answer3: one-half
questions.explanation: Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations Part 393.106, issued by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA), requires the aggregate working load limit of any securement system used to secure an article or group of articles against movement to be at least one-half times the weight of the article or group of articles.

questions.question: Which lights should you use the most when driving at night?
questions.answer3: Emergency flashers
questions.explanation: When driving at night, you should use your high beams to see farther as long as it is safe and legal and you will not blind any other drivers. You should dim your lights when you are within 500 feet of an approaching vehicle or following another vehicle within 500 feet.

questions.question: What is the penalty for your first conviction for driving under the influence (DUI)?
questions.answer1: Lose CDL for 1 year, if DUI while driving a CMV
questions.answer2: Lose CDL for 1 year, if DUI while driving your personal vehicle
questions.answer3: Lose CDL for 3 years, if DUI while transporting hazardous materials
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of DUI, you will lose your CDL for one year whether you were driving a CMV or your personal vehicle. If you were transporting hazardous materials at the time, you will lose your CDL for 3 years. A second conviction for DUI will cause you to lose your CDL for life.

questions.question: When backing, it is important to use a helper
questions.answer2: because people feel more comfortable when you do.
questions.answer3: because you are providing a job for someone else.
questions.answer4: for all of the above reasons.
questions.explanation: It is important to use a helper when you are backing since you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals for "Go" and (most importantly) "Stop."

questions.question: Operation Lifesaver recommends that
questions.answer1: you should not operate a boat while drinking alcoholic beverages.
questions.answer2: you should follow several steps to avoid accidents at railroad grade crossings.
questions.answer3: you should obey new speed limits to avoid harming law enforcement officers.
questions.answer4: you should do all of the above.
questions.explanation: Operation Lifesaver is a rail safety organization that promotes safety at railroad grade crossings and railroad rights-of-way. It recommends a variety of tips to drivers, such as expecting trains to approach at any time, day or night; looking both ways for a second train after the first one has passed; never shifting gears on a railroad crossing; and never racing a train to a railroad crossing.

questions.question: Which is NOT one of the four skill areas that operating a commercial vehicle requires?
questions.answer3: First-aid certification
questions.explanation: As described in detail in section 2.2 of the CDL manual, the four basic skills for safe operation of a commercial vehicle are accelerating, steering, stopping, and backing safely. While first-aid certification might come in handy at some point in your career, it is not one of the four basic skills.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the basic shifting method?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, push in the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, push in the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much distance will it take to stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your stopping distance increases to almost four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 148 feet.

questions.question: Before transporting a sealed load, you must inspect
questions.answer1: a small sample of whatever is inside.
questions.answer2: a picture of whatever is inside.
questions.answer3: that you don't exceed gross weight and axle weight limits.
questions.explanation: While you cannot actually inspect sealed loads, it's still your responsibility to ensure that you do not exceed your axle weight limits and your gross weight restrictions, so check them both.

questions.question: Which of the following can cause a vehicle fire?
questions.answer1: Driver smoking in a rest area
questions.answer3: Spilled fuel cleaned up quickly and properly
questions.explanation: Smoking, flammable cargo, and spilled fuel are potentially dangerous. Properly managed, however, they should not start a fire except under special circumstances such as a short circuit or loose connection.

questions.question: The most important hand signal you should agree on with a helper is
questions.answer3: “Stop.”
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: How often do you have to pull over to inspect your goods while driving?
questions.answer3: Every 3 hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, section 3.1 of the Indiana CDL Manual states that you should check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your trip and then every 3 hours or 150 miles, as well as after each break you take.

questions.question: Which of the following are likely to get stuck at a raised railroad crossing?
questions.answer3: Lowboy
questions.explanation: The two types of combination vehicles most likely to get stuck at a raised railroad crossing are low-slung units (car carriers, lowboys, moving vans, etc.) and single-axle tractors that are pulling a long trailer with the landing gear set to accommodate a tandem-axle tractor. Be very careful when driving such vehicles at railroad crossings.

questions.question: When beginning a long downgrade, which of the following should influence your choice of speed?
questions.answer1: The total weight of the vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: When choosing a safe speed for driving down a steep downgrade, consider its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: You should put the starter switch key into your pocket while you are performing the pre-trip inspection because
questions.answer1: it could damage the steering mechanism.
questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.
questions.answer3: it could damage the starting mechanism.
questions.answer4: any of the above could occur.
questions.explanation: While you are performing the pre-trip inspection, you do not want someone (such as a co-driver) who is unaware of your location to start your vehicle and accidentally injure you.

questions.question: When you inspect the front of your vehicle as part of the walkaround inspection, which of the following do you NOT check?
questions.answer1: The condition of your front axle
questions.answer2: The steering mechanism for possible looseness
questions.answer3: The air pressure gauge
questions.explanation: You do not check the temperature and pressure gauges as part of step 5, "Do Walkaround Inspection." You should have checked those gauges in step 3, "Start Engine and Inspect Inside the Cab." Before you take your CDL knowledge test, you should study the seven-step inspection method to familiarize yourself with what is checked in each step.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: Your liver breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate. Typically, this is one standard drink (one ounce of hard liquor, a one-half glass of wine, or one 12-ounce can of beer) per hour. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: Total stopping distance is a combination of
questions.answer3: perception distance + reaction distance + braking distance.
questions.answer4: reaction distance + viewing distance + braking distance.
questions.explanation: Total stopping distance is the sum of your perception distance (how far the vehicle goes from when you see a hazard until your brain processes it), reaction distance (how far the vehicle goes from when your brain orders your foot to take action until your foot actually starts to brake), and braking distance (how far the vehicle continues to travel once you apply the brake).

questions.question: How many tiedowns are required for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tiedown per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two per load, regardless of the length. So for 20 feet, you would have two tiedowns.

questions.question: Before a trip, to prevent drowsiness, you should
questions.answer1: schedule trips for the daytime hours.
questions.answer3: avoid medications that cause drowsiness.
questions.explanation: Sleep debt is a dangerous condition in which missing sleep adds up until you risk falling asleep at the wheel unless you get some rest. People are often surprised that getting less than six hours of sleep per night triples the risk of an accident. Before a trip, you should get adequate sleep (adults need 8 to 9 hours to maintain alertness); prepare your route carefully to identify total distance, stopping points, and other logistical considerations; schedule trips for the hours during which you are normally awake, not the middle of the night; drive with a passenger; avoid medications that cause drowsiness; consult your physician if you suffer from daytime sleepiness, have difficulty sleeping at night, or take frequent naps; and incorporate exercise into your daily life to give yourself more energy.

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you
questions.answer1: avoid using your cell phone until you reach your destination.
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in the first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: smoke, eat, and drink on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no other vehicles around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. Avoid using your cell phone until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: Any of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide to the left, a driver might try to pass you on your right while you are turning. Instead, make the turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This will deny drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true about an escape ramp?
questions.answer1: It may be located a few miles from the top of a downgrade.
questions.answer2: It is of no use if you are traveling too fast.
questions.answer3: It may be made of soft gravel.
questions.explanation: Escape ramps are designed with soft gravel, upgrades, or both, to slow down vehicles that experience brake failure on a downgrade. Regardless of your speed, look for one of these escape ramps, which can save lives, equipment, and cargo.

questions.question: If you are traveling at 55 mph in a 30-foot vehicle, you should leave how many seconds of following distance?
questions.answer3: 3 seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. So for a 30-foot vehicle going 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: If you have a flat tire, you should not do which of the following?
questions.answer3: Immediately brake hard.
questions.answer4: Be aware that a tire has failed.
questions.explanation: Hard braking could cause your vehicle to go out of control, so brake gently only after the vehicle has slowed down and you have regained control.

questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations Part 392.22, issued by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA). These regulations also specify where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as two-way roads and curves. (Those situations are also covered in section 2.5.2 of the Indiana CDL Manual.)

questions.question: Common medications for colds
questions.answer2: have warning labels indicating they shouldn't be used while you are driving a CMV.
questions.answer3: are fine, as long as you use them carefully and drink plenty of coffee.
questions.answer4: are illegal to use while you are operating a CMV.
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, many over-the-counter cold medications can cause drowsiness, sedation, or disturbed coordination, which make them dangerous for CMV operators. However, not all cold remedies have these side effects. If you are unsure about the effects of a particular medication, check the warning label or ask your pharmacist or doctor.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels and any visible evidence of cracks or leaks.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key steering component?
questions.answer3: Gear box
questions.explanation: The gear box is an integral part of the steering system. The other three choices are parts of the suspension system.

questions.question: To transport cargo safely, which of the following are you NOT responsible for?
questions.answer1: Ensuring the safety of the cargo
questions.answer3: Making sure that cargo is properly secured
questions.answer4: Ensuring the freshness of sealed cargo
questions.explanation: You are not responsible for the state of sealed cargo, nor can you inspect it. You are only responsible for the safety of the cargo, ensuring that it is balanced, secured, and not overloaded, and does not get in the way of emergency equipment.

questions.question: In which of the following two situations should you downshift?
questions.answer1: Starting down a hill and entering a curve
questions.answer2: Starting up a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer3: Starting down a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer4: Starting up a hill and entering a curve
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill lets you take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required, which is usually lower than the gear required to climb the hill. Downshifting before a curve improves stability and helps you get the power you will need to accelerate out of the turn.

questions.question: It has just reached freezing. Which of the following areas may be slippery?
questions.answer3: A wet-looking road
questions.explanation: Once the temperature drops to freezing, some sections of road will start to freeze before others. The first to freeze will be shaded areas and bridges. If the road appears wet, it may be covered in black ice, a thin layer of slippery ice through which you can see the road.

questions.question: On which of the following types of fires should you NOT use a B:C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Wood
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher should not be used on burning materials that you can use ordinary water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: If you feel drowsy while driving, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Open the windows for some fresh air.
questions.answer3: Pull off the road and get some sleep.
questions.explanation: If you are drowsy, cold air, fresh air, or caffeinated beverages may make you feel more alert only momentarily. The only real solution is to get off the road as soon as possible and get some real rest.

questions.question: Signs of distracted drivers include
questions.answer2: vehicles constantly traveling above the speed limit.
questions.answer3: drivers listening to overly loud music.
questions.explanation: Whether the conversation takes place face-to-face or through a cell phone, text messaging, or CB radio, it still requires a driver's attention and may distract the person.

questions.question: Letting the air out of hot tires
questions.answer1: is a good idea because the extra pressure will be relieved.
questions.answer2: is a bad idea because when the tires cool off, the pressure will be too low.
questions.answer3: will have no effect at all.
questions.answer4: will cool them down. You will be able to continue your journey sooner.
questions.explanation: When tires get hot, the air pressure increases. However, relieving that extra pressure will leave the air pressure too low when the tires cool again, and then the tires may catch fire or blow out. If your tires are too hot to touch, stop until they have cooled down.

questions.question: How do you get started without rolling backwards?
questions.answer1: Put on the parking brake whenever necessary.
questions.answer2: Engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake.
questions.answer3: Apply the trailer brake hand valve.
questions.explanation: If you have a manual transmission vehicle, partly engage the clutch before you take your right foot off the brake. Put on the parking brake whenever necessary to keep from rolling back. Release the parking brake only when you have applied enough engine power to keep from rolling back. On a tractor-trailer equipped with a trailer brake hand valve, the hand valve can be applied to keep from rolling back.

questions.question: An anti-lock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: keep your brakes from locking when you brake hard.
questions.explanation: ABS kicks in only to keep the wheels from locking up, which could cause a skid. ABS does not change the way you normally brake the rest of the time. It is not a substitute for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, or regular maintenance.

questions.question: Always try to back toward the driver's side because
questions.answer1: it's more comfortable for turning your neck.
questions.answer2: you can see better, watching the vehicle's rear out the side window.
questions.answer3: your truck will naturally pull toward the driver's side.
questions.answer4: all of the above are true.
questions.explanation: You should always back toward the driver's side because you will be able to see things much more easily. For example, you can keep an eye on the vehicle's rear by viewing it out your side window. If your truck pulls in either direction, it needs service. Your neck's comfort should not affect your safety decision.

questions.question: If the engine is not overheated, is it completely safe to remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer3: Yes, as long as there is no overflow.
questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.
questions.explanation: It is not enough for the engine not to be overheated. The cooling system must cool completely before you attempt to remove the radiator cap. Even then, you should be very careful because there may still be tremendous pressure and damaging steam and fluids.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an anti-lock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: The minimum tread depth for front tires is
questions.answer3: 1/2 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: What can you do at an accident scene to help avoid another accident?
questions.answer1: Stay in your vehicle and do nothing until help arrives.
questions.answer2: Set out warning devices to keep other vehicles from running into the accident scene.
questions.answer3: Leave your vehicle, do nothing, and get to higher ground.
questions.answer4: Have a drink to calm your nerves.
questions.explanation: Unless you have been injured, it is your responsibility to ensure that others can see your vehicle at an accident scene. Set out your warning devices as quickly as possible to avoid further accidents such as a pile-up.

questions.question: What is a common cause of tire fires?
questions.answer3: Cold tires
questions.explanation: Underinflated tires and dual tires that touch are the most common causes of tire fires.

questions.question: Why should you cover your cargo?
questions.answer1: To protect individuals from any spilled cargo
questions.answer2: To protect your cargo from bad weather
questions.answer3: Because many states require it
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: There are several reasons to cover your cargo, including protecting other people and the cargo itself. In addition, it will help you comply with regulations in several states.

questions.question: How long does it take a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double railroad track?
questions.answer3: More than 30 seconds
questions.explanation: You can expect it to take more than 15 seconds for a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double track and at least 14 seconds to clear a single track.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are
questions.answer1: signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo.
questions.answer2: signs on the inside of the vehicle that remind the driver of what he or she is carrying.
questions.answer3: signs that help tax collectors determine how much to tax a hazardous cargo.
questions.answer4: signs that warn the public to stay at least 1,000 feet away from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are four regulated signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo for those who need to know, such as emergency service personnel or those who load and unload cargo.

questions.question: What is the best method for calculating the number of seconds of following distance you have?
questions.answer1: Wait until the vehicle ahead of you passes a shadow or landmark. Then start to count the seconds until you reach it.
questions.answer2: Get 1/4 closer to the car in front of you, then back off again. Multiply how long this took you by four to give the following distance.
questions.answer3: Use the stopwatch on your cell phone to determine how long it takes you to reach a mile marker after the car in front of you has passed it.
questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to reach some object after the vehicle in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here either will not work or involve dangerous distractions. Note that you should increase your following distance in heavy traffic, in bad weather, with heavy vehicles, or at higher speeds.

questions.question: What is the definition of a hazard?
questions.answer2: A road user or road condition that presents a possible danger
questions.answer3: Something you must stop for
questions.explanation: A hazard is a road user or road condition that presents a possible danger. A hazard is something that could go wrong but shouldn't if you've been vigilant.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should
questions.answer2: ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.
questions.answer3: call the police from your cell phone if you can do it safely.
questions.explanation: When an aggressive driver is trying to confront you, do not give the person the confrontation that he or she seeks. Instead, seek police, peace, and safety.

questions.question: Do empty trucks have the best braking?
questions.answer3: Yes, but only on wet surfaces.
questions.answer4: Yes, but only if the trucks are newer than 1998.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have greater stopping distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: The most important hand signal you should agree on with a helper is
questions.answer3: “Stop.”
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.

questions.question: If you are traveling at 55 mph in a 30-foot vehicle, you should leave how many seconds of following distance?
questions.answer3: 3 seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. So for a 30-foot vehicle going 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: Truck drivers are in an ideal position to spot and report human trafficking occurring at truck stops and rest areas. Which of the following trafficking red flags should you look for?
questions.answer1: An individual who lacks knowledge of his or her location or community
questions.answer2: An individual not in control of his or her own travel documents, such as a passport or driver's license
questions.answer3: An individual who seems tense, afraid, nervous, or submissive
questions.explanation: Trafficking victims are often moved around. They may be victims of physical, sexual, or forced drug abuse, and they may be forced into prostitution. DO NOT approach possible traffickers. Instead, take descriptions of people, vehicles, times, dates, and locations. Take pictures if you can. Then call the National Hotline at 1-888-3737-888 (US).

questions.question: How far ahead should you look while driving?
questions.answer3: 12 to 15 seconds
questions.explanation: You should look ahead the distance that your CMV will travel in 12 to 15 seconds. At 60 mph, your CMV will travel a quarter mile (1,320 feet) in 15 seconds.

questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.
questions.answer3: it could damage the starting mechanism.
