questions.question: On which of the following types of fires should you NOT use a B:C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Wood
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher should not be used on burning materials that you can use ordinary water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: To maintain alertness on your trips, you should
questions.answer1: schedule your trips for the daytime hours.
questions.answer3: avoid medications that cause drowsiness.
questions.explanation: Sleep debt is a dangerous condition in which missing sleep adds up until you risk falling asleep at the wheel unless you get some rest. People are often surprised that getting less than 6 hours of sleep per night triples the risk of an accident. At least 15% of heavy truck crashes are believed to involve driver fatigue. Before a trip, you should get adequate sleep (adults need 8 to 9 hours to maintain alertness); prepare your route carefully to identify total distance, stopping points, and other logistical considerations; schedule trips for the hours during which you are normally awake, not the middle of the night; drive with a passenger; avoid medications that cause drowsiness; consult your physician if you suffer from daytime sleepiness, have difficulty sleeping at night, or take frequent naps; and incorporate exercise into your daily life to give yourself more energy.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to brake to a stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your braking distance increases by roughly the square of the speed increase – to about four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 184 feet.

questions.question: When you apply for a Commercial Learner Permit or a CDL for the first time, which of the following are you NOT required to provide?
questions.answer2: Two proofs of residency in New Mexico
questions.answer3: Your valid New Mexico driver license
questions.explanation: To apply for a Commercial Learner Permit or a CDL for the first time, you must provide all of the following documentation: your Social Security card, your New Mexico driver license, your DOT medical certification, two proofs of residency in New Mexico, and proof of your US citizenship or lawful presence in the US. This last you can prove with a state birth certificate, a US passport, a consular report of your birth abroad, a certificate of naturalization, or other documents.

questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulation 49 CFR 392.22. This regulation also specifies where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as undivided two-way roads and curves. (These situations are also covered in section 2.5.2 of the New Mexico Commercial Driver License Manual.)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four fundamental abilities required to operate a commercial motor vehicle?
questions.answer3: First-aid certification
questions.explanation: As described in detail in section 2.2 of the New Mexico Commercial Driver License Manual, the four basic skills for safe operation of a commercial motor vehicle are accelerating, steering, stopping, and backing safely. While first-aid certification might come in handy at some point in your career, it is not one of the four basic skills.

questions.question: How often do you have to pull over to inspect your goods while driving?
questions.answer3: Every three hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, the New Mexico Commercial Driver License Manual states that you should check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your trip and then every 3 hours or 150 miles, as well as after each break you take.

questions.question: Which lights should you use the most when driving at night?
questions.answer3: Emergency flashers
questions.explanation: While driving at night, you should use your high beams to see farther as long as it is safe and legal and you will not blind any other drivers. Section 2.11.5 of the New Mexico Commercial Driver License Manual recommends that you dim your headlights whenever you are within 500 feet of another vehicle.

questions.question: If you have a flat tire, you should not do which of the following?
questions.answer3: Brake hard and immediately.
questions.answer4: Be aware that a tire has failed.
questions.explanation: Hard braking could cause your vehicle to go out of control, so brake gently only after the vehicle has slowed down and you have regained control.

questions.question: What is a common cause of tire fires?
questions.answer3: Cold tires
questions.explanation: Underinflated tires and dual tires that touch are the most common causes of tire fires.

questions.question: Which of the following retarder assertions is true?
questions.answer1: Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for braking.
questions.answer2: When your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarder may cause them to skid.
questions.answer3: You should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow-covered.
questions.answer4: All of the above statements are correct.
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should always turn off your retarders in poor weather.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the basic shifting method?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, press the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, press the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: Why should you cover your cargo?
questions.answer1: To protect individuals from any spilled cargo
questions.answer2: To protect your cargo from bad weather
questions.answer3: Because many states require it
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: There are several reasons to cover your cargo, including protecting other people and the cargo itself. In addition, it will help you comply with regulations in several states.

questions.question: If you are convicted of a second DUI offense in either a CMV or your personal vehicle, how long will you lose your CDL driving privileges?
questions.answer3: Life
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of DUI for a second time, you will lose your CDL privileges for life. While you are driving a CMV, a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.04% or above qualifies as DUI. Your first offense is a wake-up call and a chance to get help, but your second offense is going to mean unemployment. If you get a DUI, seek help before you lose your salary and your future.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.
questions.answer3: Call the police from your cell phone if you can do it safely.
questions.explanation: If an aggressive driver is trying to confront you, do not give the person the confrontation that he or she seeks. Instead, seek police, peace, and safety.

questions.question: How many tie-downs are required for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tie-down per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two per load, regardless of the length. So for 20 feet, you should have two tie-downs.

questions.question: You should examine each tire as you inspect it.
questions.answer1: if you can see any fabric through the sidewall.
questions.answer2: if the valve stem is cracked.
questions.answer3: if there are any cuts in the tire.
questions.explanation: Tires are crucial. Check for all sorts of possible problems, including worn tires (inadequate tread depth or fabric showing through sidewalls), cracked valve stems, and cuts or other damage. Section 2.1.3 of the New York State Commercial Driver's Manual has a full list of checks for you to make.

questions.question: What should the colors of your side marker lights be?
questions.answer3: Red at front, others amber
questions.explanation: Your side marker lights are red at the rear and amber elsewhere.

questions.question: You will receive a three-year sentence if you are convicted of railroad grade crossing offenses twice within three years.
questions.answer3: a 60-day disqualification.
questions.explanation: Railroad grade crossing violations include failing to stop if a train is approaching and failing to obey traffic-control signals. If you are convicted of a railroad grade crossing violation, you will be disqualified from commercial driving for 60 days if it was your first offense, 120 days if it was your second offense within three years, or one year if it was your third offense within three years.

questions.question: When driving a highly loaded vehicle on __________, pay close attention to the space beneath the car.
questions.answer3: a railroad grade crossing
questions.explanation: When your vehicle is heavily loaded, there may be very little space underneath it. This is often a problem on dirt roads and in unpaved yards. Don't take a chance on getting hung up. It is also possible to get stuck when driving a low-slung vehicle such as a lowboy or moving van across a raised railroad grade crossing.

questions.question: If you are convicted of __________, you will lose your CDL for at least one year if it was your first offense.
questions.answer1: refusing to undergo blood alcohol testing
questions.answer2: committing a felony involving the use of a vehicle
questions.answer3: driving a vehicle under the influence of a controlled substance
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of a serious offense such as one of these, you will lose your CDL for at least one year if it was your first offense. (If you were driving a CMV placarded for hazardous materials at the time of the offense, you will lose your CDL for at least three years.) If you are convicted for a second time, you will lose your CDL for life.

questions.question: When should you use the low range if your vehicle has an automatic transmission?
questions.answer3: Before entering an upgrade
questions.explanation: If you keep applying the brakes to control your speed on a steep descent, the brakes will fade (lose their effectiveness). Instead, if your vehicle has an automatic transmission, select a low range that prevents the transmission from shifting up beyond the selected gear. This will generate a braking effect to slow the vehicle, known as engine braking. The lower the gear, the greater the engine braking effect. Apply the brakes only when engine braking is insufficient or you want to stop.

questions.question: On a 17-foot load, you have two tiedowns. How many more tiedowns are you going to require?
questions.answer3: Two
questions.explanation: You should have one tiedown per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two, regardless of the length. So for a 17-foot load, two tiedowns is enough.

questions.question: How often do you have to pull over to inspect your goods while driving?
questions.answer3: Every three hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, the New York State Commercial Driver's Manual states that you should check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your trip and then every 3 hours or 150 miles, as well as after each break you take.

questions.question: To put out a fire with a fire extinguisher, follow these steps:
questions.answer2: stay as far away from the fire as possible.
questions.answer3: aim at the source or base of the fire, not up in the flames.
questions.explanation: In a fire, your first priority is your safety and that of others. To use a fire extinguisher to put out a fire, stand upwind from the fire at a safe distance. Let the wind carry the extinguisher from you to the fire. Aim the extinguisher at the source or base of the fire, not up in the flames. Persist until the burning material has cooled to the point that the fire cannot restart.

questions.question: What is the best way to test a parking brake?
questions.answer1: Stop your vehicle, set the parking brake, and gently pull against it in low gear.
questions.answer2: Stop your vehicle, set the parking brake, and push the power unit from the outside.
questions.answer3: Set the parking brake while driving at 10 mph.
questions.answer4: Face your vehicle downhill and apply the parking brake.
questions.explanation: Stop your vehicle and set only the parking brake you want to test (power unit or trailer). Select a low gear. Gently pull forward against the parking brake to make sure the parking brake holds.

questions.question: What are the most significant distinctions between aggressive driving and road rage?
questions.answer3: The outcome of the situation
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is driving in a selfish or pushy manner, which is dangerous enough. Road rage is even worse: intentionally driving to threaten, attempt, or commit a violent act. Aggressive driving generally involves traffic infractions while road rage generally involves crimes.

questions.question: How many seconds of following distance should you leave if you're driving a 30-foot vehicle at 55 mph?
questions.answer3: 3 seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. Therefore, for a 30-foot vehicle traveling at 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: The perception distance is the distance traveled by your vehicle
questions.answer1: from when you apply the brakes to when your vehicle comes to a stop.
questions.answer2: from when your eyes see a hazard to when you apply the brakes.
questions.answer3: from when your eyes see a hazard to when your brain recognizes the hazard.
questions.answer4: from when your eyes see a hazard to when your vehicle comes to a stop.
questions.explanation: It takes time for your brain to process information. Your perception time is the time that elapses from when your eyes see a hazard to when your brain recognizes it as a hazard that requires you to act. The average perception time for an alert driver is 1¾ seconds. Your perception distance is the distance that your vehicle will travel in that time. At 55 mph, this accounts for 142 feet traveled.

questions.question: You must notify your employer within 30 days, if you are convicted of any traffic violations except __________.
questions.answer3: parking.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations except parking violations, you must notify your employer within 30 days. This applies whether you were driving a commercial motor vehicle or some other motor vehicle at the time.

questions.question: If you are convicted of two significant traffic infractions involving a commercial motor vehicle (CMV) within three years, you will lose your CDL for at least 60 days. Which of the following are examples of such violations?
questions.answer1: Speeding at 15 mph or more above the speed limit
questions.answer3: Using a handheld cell phone
questions.explanation: You will lose your CDL for at least 60 days if you are convicted of two serious traffic violations involving a CMV within a three-year period. For three serious traffic violations within a three-year period, you will lose your CDL for at least 120 days. Such violations include speeding at 15 mph or more above the speed limit, driving recklessly, making improper or erratic lane changes, tailgating, and texting or talking on a handheld cell phone.

questions.question: If you are convicted of driving a commercial motor vehIf you are guilty of operating a commercial motor vehicle (CMV) that has been ordered out of operation by federal or state inspectors,icle (CMV) that federal or state inspectors have ordered out of service,
questions.answer1: you will have to pay a $100 fine.
questions.answer2: you will have to pay a $500 fine.
questions.answer3: you will be disqualified from commercial driving for at least 30 days.
questions.answer4: you will be disqualified from commercial driving for at least 90 days.
questions.explanation: If a federal or state inspector judges a CMV to be unsafe, they will order it out of service. If you are convicted of driving it anyway, you will be disqualified from commercial driving for between 90 days and one year if it's your first offense.

questions.question: How speed you should reduce when driving on packed snow?
questions.answer3: one-third.
questions.explanation: When a road is wet, stopping distance is increased, and you should reduce your speed by one-third. On packed snow, slow to one-half your usual speed or less. On icy roads, slow to a crawl and stop driving as soon as you can do so safely.

questions.question: To receive a New York CDL, you must be
questions.answer1: a resident of New York State.
questions.answer3: the holder of a CDL from another state.
questions.explanation: To obtain a New York CDL, you must be a resident of New York State. Furthermore, you can only hold one license at a time. If you move to New York from another state, you must exchange your out-of-state CDL for a New York CDL within 30 days of becoming a legal resident of New York.

questions.question: If you're carrying an excessive burden, you must have all of the following EXCEPT
questions.answer3: warning flags or lamps.
questions.answer4: cargo covers for the whole load.
questions.explanation: If you're going to carry an oversized load, check that all required signs (flags, lamps, and reflectors) are safely and properly mounted and all required permits are in your possession. Some oversized loads may also require a police escort or pilot vehicles with warning signs or flashing lights.

questions.question: When may you transport hazardous goods without a hazardous materials (HazMat) endorsement on your CDL?
questions.answer1: If you're only driving across town
questions.answer2: If you're just backing into the street
questions.answer3: If your employer's usual HazMat drivers are unavailable
questions.answer4: If your vehicle doesn't require placarding
questions.explanation: You must have a hazardous materials (HazMat) endorsement on your CDL to drive a vehicle that is placarded for hazardous materials. However, not all hazardous material shipments require placarding your vehicle. For example, relatively small quantities of consumer-grade chemicals such as drain openers and bleaches may be exempt. New York State follows federal regulations on this. [49 CFR 172.500], [17 NYCRR Part 820]

questions.question: How many reflective warning triangles should you have on hand in case of an emergency?
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's emergency equipment must include warning devices such as three reflective red triangles, three liquid flares, or six fusees.

questions.question: What is the risk of transporting livestock in particular?
questions.answer1: They can change your vehicle's center of gravity.
questions.answer3: Their smell can be distracting.
questions.explanation: These large animals may lean on curves, shifting the center of gravity of your vehicle and thus increasing the chance of a rollover. Slow down and use caution on sharp curves such as on-ramps and off-ramps.

questions.question: Is there a specific danger in transporting hanging meat?
questions.answer1: Its smell may make it difficult to find places to park.
questions.answer2: You may have to drive extra fast to get it delivered fresh.
questions.answer3: It may change your vehicle's handling characteristics.
questions.answer4: You may be confronted by animal rights protesters.
questions.explanation: Hanging meat carcasses have a high center of gravity and may sway on curves, changing the handling characteristics of your vehicle. Slow down and use caution on sharp curves such as on-ramps and off-ramps.

questions.question: Tar "bleeds" through the pavement in extremely hot temperatures. What impact could this have?
questions.answer2: It may make the road more slippery.
questions.answer3: It may get in your engine.
questions.answer4: It may spatter on your windshield.
questions.explanation: Tar in the road pavement frequently rises to the surface in very hot weather. Spots where tar "bleeds" to the surface are very slippery. Avoid these spots where possible and be ready to counteract a skid.

questions.question: Which is NOT one of the four basic abilities required to operate a commercial motor vehicle?
questions.answer3: First-aid certification
questions.explanation: As described in detail in section 2.2 of the New York State Commercial Driver's Manual, the four basic skills for safe operation of a commercial motor vehicle are accelerating, steering, stopping, and backing safely. While first-aid certification might come in handy at some point in your career, it is not one of the four basic skills.

questions.question: When there's a hazard ahead, It's almost always quicker for you to _________ than to come to a full stop
questions.answer3: downshift
questions.explanation: Large vehicles have long stopping distances. If you're faced with a hazard ahead and you don't have enough room to stop, try to steer away from the hazard. It's usually quicker to turn away than to come to a full stop. (However, top-heavy vehicles and tractors with multiple trailers may flip over.)

questions.question: When should you NOT use retarders?
questions.answer1: If your drive wheels have poor traction
questions.answer2: When you're slowing down from a high speed
questions.answer3: When you're driving in traffic
questions.answer4: When you plan to immediately speed up again
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely on slippery roads. Therefore, you should turn off your retarders whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow-covered.

questions.question: What is a “header board?"
questions.answer1: A slang term for a license plate
questions.answer2: Another term for the rear door of a trailer
questions.answer3: Another term for a dashboard
questions.explanation: A front-end header board is located at the front part of a trailer. The header board prevents cargo from moving forward (and possibly injuring you) in the event of a crash or sudden stop. Check to make sure that the header board is secure, upright, and undamaged (no dents, no corrosion, no missing rivets, etc.).

questions.question: What is the main goal of a vehicle inspection?
questions.answer2: To make sure your vehicle is safe
questions.answer3: To check the cleanliness of your vehicle
questions.answer4: To make sure the paint is not chipped
questions.explanation: The main purpose of a vehicle inspection is to determine whether your vehicle is safe enough to drive. This includes your safety and that of other road users. In addition, discovering defects during a vehicle inspection can help avert a costly or even dangerous breakdown on the road.

questions.question: How do you test a vehicle's hydraulic brakes for leaks?
questions.answer1: Pump the brakes 3 times. Then apply firm pressure for 5 seconds.
questions.answer2: Pump the brakes 5 times. Then apply firm pressure for 3 seconds.
questions.answer3: Pump the brakes 3 times. Then apply firm pressure for 10 seconds.
questions.answer4: Apply firm pressure for 5 seconds. Then pump the brakes 3 times.
questions.explanation: To test a vehicle equipped with hydraulic brakes for leaks in the brakes, first pump the brakes three times. Next, apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. If it moves, the brakes may have a leak or some other problem.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should do all of the following EXCEPT
questions.answer3: avoid tricks such as flashing your brake lights.
questions.explanation: Don't try to speed up to outdistance or appease a tailgater. No speed is too fast for some tailgaters. Instead, increase your following distance and if possible, keep right to let the tailgater pass.

questions.question: Always try to back toward the driver's side because
questions.answer1: you can see better, watching the vehicle's rear from the side window.
questions.answer2: your truck will probably pull toward the driver's side.
questions.answer3: there are always more hazards on the left.
questions.answer4: all of the above are true.
questions.explanation: You should always back toward the driver's side even if you have to go around the block to put your vehicle in this position. By backing toward the driver's side, you will be able to see things much more easily. For example, you can keep an eye on the vehicle's rear by viewing it from your side window. If your truck pulls in either direction, it needs service. There may be hazards on either side of your vehicle, of course.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels and any visible evidence of cracks or leaks.

questions.question: Total stopping distance equals
questions.answer3: perception distance + reaction distance + braking distance.
questions.answer4: reaction distance + viewing distance + braking distance.
questions.explanation: Total stopping distance is the sum of your perception distance (how far your vehicle goes from when you see the hazard until your brain processes it), reaction distance (how far the vehicle goes from when your brain orders your foot to take action until your foot actually starts to brake), and braking distance (how far the vehicle continues to travel once you apply the brake).

questions.question: Which of the following should NOT be checked during a trip?
questions.answer3: Text messages
questions.explanation: During your trip, you should keep an eye on all of your vehicle's key systems, such as the instruments, gauges, tires, voltmeter, mirrors, and cargo. Make sure you put your phone aside for the entire trip.

questions.question: Letting the air out of hot tires
questions.answer1: is a good idea because the extra pressure will be relieved.
questions.answer2: is a bad idea because when the tires cool off, the pressure will be too low.
questions.answer3: will have no effect at all.
questions.answer4: will cool them down. You will be able to continue your trip sooner.
questions.explanation: When tires get hot, the air pressure increases. However, relieving that extra pressure will leave the air pressure too low when the tires cool again, and then the tires may catch fire or blow out. If your tires are too hot to touch, stop until they have cooled down.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an antilock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key steering component?
questions.answer3: Gear box
questions.explanation: The gear box is an integral part of the steering system. The other three choices are parts of the suspension system.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are
questions.answer1: signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo.
questions.answer2: signs on the inside of the vehicle that remind the driver of what he or she is carrying.
questions.answer3: signs that help tax collectors determine how much to tax a hazardous cargo.
questions.answer4: signs that warn the public to stay at least 1,000 feet from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are four regulated signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo for those who need to know, such as emergency service personnel or those who load and unload cargo.

questions.question: When you start to drive down a steep downgrade, which of the following should influence your choice of speed?
questions.answer1: The total weight of your vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: When choosing a safe speed for driving down a steep downgrade, consider its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: An antilock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: keep your wheels from locking when you brake hard.
questions.explanation: ABS kicks in only to keep the wheels from locking, which could cause a skid. ABS does not change the way you normally brake the rest of the time. It is not a substitute for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, or regular maintenance.

questions.question: You should do the following to assist you stay aware and safe while driving:
questions.answer1: avoid medications that can cause drowsiness.
questions.answer2: drink coffee if you get drowsy.
questions.answer3: roll down your windows to get fresh air.
questions.answer4: have a whiskey to brace yourself.
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, some prescription and over-the-counter medications can cause drowsiness, sedation, or impaired coordination, which make them dangerous for CMV operators. If you are unsure about the effects of a particular medication, check the warning label or ask your pharmacist or doctor. Never try to fight drowsiness with coffee, fresh air, or especially alcohol. The only "cure" for being tired is sleeping until you are rested.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: Your body breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate. Typically, this is one standard drink per hour, where one standard drink equals 1.5 ounces of hard liquor, 5 ounces of wine, or one 12-ounce can of beer. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: All of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide to the left, a driver may try to pass you on your right while you are turning. Instead, make the right turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This will deny drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: When evaluating hoses with the instructor during your pre-trip examination, seek for
questions.answer3: frays in the water pump belt.
questions.answer4: a low windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: When you inspect hoses during your pre-trip test, you need to look for signs of leaks, such as puddles on the ground or fluids that are dripping on the underside of the engine or transmission. Also check the hoses for cracks or other problems.

questions.question: Why is it important to use a helper when backing?
questions.answer2: Because people feel more comfortable when you do
questions.answer3: Because you are providing a job for someone else
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: It is important to use a helper when you are backing because you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals for "Go" and (most importantly) "Stop."

questions.question: What is the gross vehicle weight (GVW)?
questions.answer1: A vehicle's maximum weight rating, specified by its manufacturer
questions.answer2: The total weight of the vehicle, towed vehicles, and the load
questions.answer3: The total weight of a single vehicle and its load
questions.explanation: GVW is the simplest of the vehicle weight terms, defined as the weight of just a single vehicle and the load that it is carrying.

questions.question: On which of the following types of fires should you NOT use a B:C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Wood
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher should not be used on burning materials that you can use ordinary water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the basic shifting method?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, press the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, press the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: Why should you cover your cargo?
questions.answer1: To protect individuals from any spilled cargo
questions.answer2: To protect your cargo from bad weather
questions.answer3: Because many states require it
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: There are several reasons to cover your cargo, including protecting other people and the cargo itself. In addition, it will help you comply with regulations in several states.

questions.question: If you have more than one driver license,
questions.answer2: you will be fined at least $250 if it's your first offense.
questions.answer3: you will receive a warning if it's your first offense.
questions.answer4: you will be fined at least $500 if it's your first offense.
questions.explanation: By law, you cannot have more than one license. You cannot obtain a North Carolina CDL until you surrender all other licenses. If you are convicted of having more than one license, you will be fined at least $250 for a first offense and at least $500 for a subsequent offense.

questions.question: Which of the following convictions may cause you to be disqualified from driving a commercial motor vehicle (CMV)?
questions.answer1: Using your personal vehicle to commit a felony
questions.answer2: Driving your personal vehicle while impaired by alcohol (DWI)
questions.answer3: Speeding while driving your personal vehicle
questions.explanation: You will be disqualified from driving CMVs at least temporarily if you are convicted of using a CMV to commit a felony or are twice convicted of certain serious traffic violations, such as excessive speeding. Even a conviction for drunk driving in your personal vehicle that results in your license being canceled, suspended, or revoked will also cause you to be disqualified from operating CMVs for one year.

questions.question: Which lights should you use the most when driving at night?
questions.answer3: Emergency flashers
questions.explanation: While driving at night, you should use your high beams to see farther as long as it is safe and legal and you will not blind any other drivers. Section 2.11.5 of the North Carolina Commercial Driver License Manual recommends that you dim your headlights whenever you are within 500 feet of another vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about an escape ramp is FALSE?
questions.answer1: It may be located a few miles from the top of a downgrade.
questions.answer2: It is of no use if you are traveling too fast.
questions.answer3: It may be made of soft gravel.
questions.explanation: Escape ramps are designed with soft gravel, upgrades, or both, to slow down vehicles that experience brake failure on a downgrade. Regardless of your speed, look for one of these escape ramps, which can save lives, equipment, and cargo.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four fundamental abilities required to operate a commercial motor vehicle?
questions.answer3: First-aid certification
questions.explanation: As described in detail in section 2.2 of the North Carolina Commercial Driver License Manual, the four basic skills for safe operation of a commercial motor vehicle are accelerating, steering, stopping, and backing safely. While first-aid certification might come in handy at some point in your career, it is not one of the four basic skills.

questions.question: Why should you use a helper when you are backing?
questions.answer2: Because people feel more comfortable when you do
questions.answer3: Because you are providing a job for someone else
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: It is important to use a helper when you are backing because you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals for "Go" and (most importantly) "Stop."

questions.question: How often do you have to pull over to inspect your goods while driving?
questions.answer3: Every 3 hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, the North Carolina Commercial Driver License Manual states that you should check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your trip and then every 3 hours or 150 miles, as well as after each break you take.

questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulation 49 CFR 392.22. This regulation also specifies where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as undivided two-way roads and curves. (These situations are also covered in section 2.5.2 of the North Carolina Commercial Driver License Manual.)

questions.question: If you are convicted of any traffic violation except parking, you must notify your employer within
questions.answer3: 45 days.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violation except parking, you must notify your employer within 30 days, regardless of whether the violation occurred in your CMV or your personal vehicle.

questions.question: Federal law requires employers to test their commercial drivers for drugs and alcohol. If you test positive for drugs, your employer must report it to
questions.answer3: the North Carolina State Highway Patrol.
questions.explanation: Federal law requires employers to test their commercial drivers for drugs and alcohol. Under North Carolina law, if you test positive for drugs, your employer must report it to the DMV within five business days. [49 CFR 382], [NC Gen Stat § 20-37.19]

questions.question: If you are traveling at 55 mph in a 30-foot vehicle, you should leave how many seconds of following distance?
questions.answer3: 3 seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. Therefore, for a 30-foot vehicle traveling at 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: Always try to back toward the driver's side because
questions.answer1: it's more comfortable for turning your neck.
questions.answer2: you can see better, watching the vehicle's rear from the side window.
questions.answer3: your truck will probably pull toward the driver's side.
questions.answer4: all of the above are true.
questions.explanation: You should always back toward the driver's side because you will be able to see things much more easily. For example, you can keep an eye on the vehicle's rear by viewing it from your side window. If your truck pulls in either direction, it needs service. Your neck's comfort should not affect your safety decision.

questions.question: The minimum tire tread depth for front tires is
questions.answer3: 1/2 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels and any visible evidence of cracks or leaks.

questions.question: Total stopping distance equals
questions.answer3: perception distance + reaction distance + braking distance.
questions.answer4: reaction distance + viewing distance + braking distance.
questions.explanation: Total stopping distance is the sum of your perception distance (how far your vehicle goes from when you see the hazard until your brain processes it), reaction distance (how far the vehicle goes from when your brain orders your foot to take action until your foot actually starts to brake), and braking distance (how far the vehicle continues to travel once you apply the brake).

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you
questions.answer1: avoid using your cell phone until you reach your destination.
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in the first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: eat, drink, and smoke only on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no other vehicles around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. Avoid using your cell phone until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: Letting the air out of hot tires
questions.answer1: is a good idea because the extra pressure will be relieved.
questions.answer2: is a bad idea because when the tires cool off, the pressure will be too low.
questions.answer3: will have no effect at all.
questions.answer4: will cool them down. You will be able to continue your trip sooner.
questions.explanation: When tires get hot, the air pressure increases. However, relieving that extra pressure will leave the air pressure too low when the tires cool again, and then the tires may catch fire or blow out. If your tires are too hot to touch, stop until they have cooled down.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an antilock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: What is the definition of a hazard?
questions.answer2: A road user or road condition that presents a possible danger
questions.answer3: Something you must stop for
questions.explanation: A hazard is a road user or road condition that presents a possible danger. A hazard is something that can go wrong but shouldn't if you've been vigilant.

questions.question: How long does it take a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double railroad track?
questions.answer3: More than 30 seconds
questions.explanation: You can expect it to take more than 15 seconds for a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double track and at least 14 seconds to clear a single track.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key steering component?
questions.answer3: Gear box
questions.explanation: The gear box is an integral part of the steering system. The other three choices are parts of the suspension system.

questions.question: What is the best method for calculating the number of seconds of following distance you have?
questions.answer1: Wait until the vehicle ahead of you passes a shadow or landmark. Then count the seconds until you reach it.
questions.answer2: Get 1/4 closer to the vehicle in front of you, then back off again. Multiply how long this took you by four to give the following distance.
questions.answer3: Use the stopwatch on your cell phone to determine how long it takes you to reach a mile marker after the vehicle in front of you has passed it.
questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to reach some stationary object after the vehicle in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here either don't work or involve dangerous distractions. Note that you should increase your following distance in heavy traffic, in bad weather, with heavy vehicles, or at higher speeds.

questions.question: To transport cargo safely, which of the following are you NOT responsible for?
questions.answer1: Ensuring the safety of the cargo
questions.answer3: Making sure that cargo is properly secured
questions.answer4: Ensuring the freshness of sealed cargo
questions.explanation: You are not responsible for the state of sealed cargo, nor can you inspect it. You are only responsible for the safety of the cargo, ensuring that it is balanced, secured, and not overloaded, and does not get in the way of emergency equipment.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are
questions.answer1: signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo.
questions.answer2: signs on the inside of the vehicle that remind the driver of what he or she is carrying.
questions.answer3: signs that help tax collectors determine how much to tax a hazardous cargo.
questions.answer4: signs that warn the public to stay at least 1,000 feet from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are four regulated signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo for those who need to know, such as emergency service personnel or those who load and unload cargo.

questions.question: When you start to drive down a steep downgrade, which of the following should influence your choice of speed?
questions.answer1: The total weight of your vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: When choosing a safe speed for driving down a steep downgrade, consider its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: How do you get started without rolling backwards?
questions.answer1: Set the parking brake whenever necessary.
questions.answer2: Engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake.
questions.answer3: Apply the trailer brake hand valve.
questions.explanation: If you have a manual transmission vehicle, partly engage the clutch before you take your right foot off the brake. Set the parking brake whenever necessary to keep from rolling back. Release the parking brake only when you have applied enough engine power to keep from rolling back. On a tractor-trailer equipped with a trailer brake hand valve, the hand valve can be applied to keep from rolling back.

questions.question: If the engine is not overheated, is it completely safe to remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer3: Yes, as long as there is no overflow.
questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.
questions.explanation: It is not enough for the engine not to be overheated. The cooling system must cool completely before you attempt to remove the radiator cap. Even then, you should be very careful because there may still be tremendous pressure and damaging steam and fluids.

questions.question: Do empty trucks have the best braking?
questions.answer3: Yes, but only on wet surfaces.
questions.answer4: Yes, but only if the trucks are newer than 1998.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have longer stopping distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: An antilock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: keep your wheels from locking when you brake hard.
questions.explanation: ABS kicks in only to keep the wheels from locking, which could cause a skid. ABS does not change the way you normally brake the rest of the time. It is not a substitute for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, or regular maintenance.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: Your body breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate. Typically, this is one standard drink per hour, where one standard drink equals 1.5 ounces of hard liquor, 5 ounces of wine, or one 12-ounce can of beer. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely to cause a vehicle fire?
questions.answer1: Driver smoking in a rest area
questions.answer3: Spilled fuel cleaned up quickly and properly
questions.explanation: Smoking, flammable cargo, and spilled fuel are potentially dangerous. Properly managed, however, they should not start a fire except under special circumstances such as a short circuit or loose connection.

questions.question: What can you do at an accident scene to help avoid another accident?
questions.answer1: Stay in your vehicle and do nothing until help arrives.
questions.answer2: Set out warning devices to keep other vehicles from running into the accident scene.
questions.answer3: Leave your vehicle, do nothing, and get to higher ground.
questions.answer4: Have a drink to calm your nerves.
questions.explanation: Unless you have been injured, it is your responsibility to ensure that others can see your vehicle at the accident scene. Set out your warning devices as quickly as possible to avoid further accidents such as a pile-up.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: All of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide to the left, a driver may try to pass you on your right while you are turning. Instead, make the right turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This will deny drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: In which of the following two situations should you downshift?
questions.answer1: Starting down a hill and entering a curve
questions.answer2: Starting up a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer3: Starting down a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer4: Starting up a hill and entering a curve
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill lets you take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required, which is usually lower than the gear required to climb the hill. Downshifting before a curve improves stability and helps you get the power you will need to accelerate out of the turn.

questions.question: It has just reached freezing. Which of the following areas may be slippery?
questions.answer3: A wet-looking road
questions.explanation: Once the temperature drops to freezing, some sections of road will start to freeze before others. The first to freeze will be shaded areas and bridges. If the road appears wet, it may be covered in black ice, a thin layer of slippery ice through which you can see the road.

questions.question: You should put the starter switch key into your pocket while you perform the pre-trip inspection because
questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.
questions.answer3: it could damage the starting mechanism.
questions.answer4: any of the above could occur.
questions.explanation: While you are performing the pre-trip inspection, you do not want someone (such as a co-driver) who is unaware of your location to start your vehicle and accidentally injure you.

questions.question: Before transporting a sealed load, you must inspect
questions.answer1: a small sample of whatever is inside.
questions.answer2: a picture of whatever is inside.
questions.answer3: that you don't exceed gross weight or axle weight limits.
questions.explanation: While you cannot actually inspect sealed loads, it's still your responsibility to ensure that you do not exceed your axle weight limits or gross weight restrictions, so check them both.

questions.question: The most significant hand gesture on which you and your assistance should both agree is
questions.answer3: “Stop.”
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: On which of the following types of fires should you NOT use a B:C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Wood
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher should not be used on burning materials that you can use ordinary water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: If you feel drowsy while driving, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Open the windows for some fresh air.
questions.answer3: Pull off the road and get some sleep.
questions.explanation: If you are drowsy, cold air, fresh air, or caffeinated beverages may make you feel more alert only momentarily. The only real solution is to get off the road as soon as possible and get some real rest.

questions.question: Which of the following might get stuck at a raised railroad crossing?
questions.answer3: Lowboy
questions.explanation: The two types of combination vehicles most likely to get stuck at a raised railroad crossing are low-slung units (car carriers, lowboys, moving vans, etc.) and single-axle tractors that are pulling a long trailer with its landing gear set to accommodate a tandem-axle tractor. Be very careful when driving such vehicles at railroad crossings.

questions.question: To maintain alertness on your trips, you should
questions.answer1: schedule your trips for the daytime hours.
questions.answer3: avoid medications that cause drowsiness.
questions.explanation: Sleep debt is a dangerous condition in which missing sleep adds up until you risk falling asleep at the wheel unless you get some rest. People are often surprised that getting less than 6 hours of sleep per night triples the risk of an accident. At least 15% of heavy truck crashes are believed to involve driver fatigue. Before a trip, you should get adequate sleep (adults need 8 to 9 hours to maintain alertness); prepare your route carefully to identify total distance, stopping points, and other logistical considerations; schedule trips for the hours during which you are normally awake, not the middle of the night; drive with a passenger; avoid medications that cause drowsiness; consult your physician if you suffer from daytime sleepiness, have difficulty sleeping at night, or take frequent naps; and incorporate exercise into your daily life to give yourself more energy.

questions.question: Signs of distracted drivers include
questions.answer2: vehicles constantly traveling above the speed limit.
questions.answer3: drivers listening to overly loud music.
questions.explanation: Whether the conversation takes place face-to-face or through a cell phone, text messaging, or CB radio, it still requires a driver's attention and may distract the person.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to brake to a stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your braking distance increases by roughly the square of the speed increase – to about four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 184 feet.

questions.question: If you have a flat tire, you should not do which of the following?
questions.answer3: Brake hard and immediately.
questions.answer4: Be aware that a tire has failed.
questions.explanation: Hard braking could cause your vehicle to go out of control, so brake gently only after the vehicle has slowed down and you have regained control.

questions.question: What is a common cause of tire fires?
questions.answer3: Cold tires
questions.explanation: Underinflated tires and dual tires that touch are the most common causes of tire fires.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the basic shifting method?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, press the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, press the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. questions.answer2: Ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.

questions.explanation: If an aggressive driver is trying to confront you, do not give the person the confrontation that he or she seeks. Instead, seek police, peace, and safety.

questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tie-down per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two per load, regardless of the length. So for 20 feet, you should have two tie-downs.

questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.

questions.question: Do empty trucks have the best braking?
questions.answer3: Yes, but only on wet surfaces.
questions.answer4: Yes, but only if the trucks are newer than 1998.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have longer stopping distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: How many tiedowns are required for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tiedown per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two per load, regardless of the length. So for 20 feet, you should have two tiedowns.

questions.question: An antilock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: keep your wheels from locking when you brake hard.
questions.explanation: ABS kicks in only to keep the wheels from locking, which could cause a skid. ABS does not change the way you normally brake the rest of the time. It is not a substitute for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, or regular maintenance.

questions.question: You should do the following to assist you stay aware and safe while driving:
questions.answer1: avoid medications that can cause drowsiness.
questions.answer2: drink coffee if you get drowsy.
questions.answer3: roll down your windows to get fresh air.
questions.answer4: have a whiskey to brace yourself.
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, some prescription and over-the-counter medications can cause drowsiness, sedation, or impaired coordination, which make them dangerous for CMV operators. If you are unsure about the effects of a particular medication, check the warning label or ask your pharmacist or doctor. Never try to fight drowsiness with coffee, fresh air, or especially alcohol. The only "cure" for being tired is sleeping until you are rested.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: Your body breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate. Typically, this is one standard drink per hour, where one standard drink equals 1.5 ounces of hard liquor, 5 ounces of wine, or one 12-ounce can of beer. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: What can you do at an accident scene to help avoid another accident?
questions.answer1: Stay in your vehicle and do nothing until help arrives.
questions.answer2: Set out warning devices to keep other vehicles from running into the accident scene.
questions.answer3: Leave your vehicle, do nothing, and get to higher ground.
questions.answer4: Have a drink to calm your nerves.
questions.explanation: Unless you have been injured, it is your responsibility to ensure that others can see your vehicle at the accident scene. Set out your warning devices as quickly as possible to avoid further accidents such as a pile-up.

questions.question: Each of the following tasks is involved in starting the engine and inspecting the cab, EXCEPT
questions.answer3: starting the engine, then listening for unusual noises.
questions.answer4: starting the engine, then putting the gearshift in neutral.
questions.explanation: Please note that the question says "EXCEPT." When performing this part of the inspection, start the engine after you have put the gearshift in neutral. Then listen for any unusual noises. Once you perform the engine check, you will check all your gauges and controls, such as the air pressure gauge and transmission controls.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: All of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide to the left, a driver may try to pass you on your right while you are turning. Instead, make the right turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This will deny drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: When evaluating hoses with the instructor during your pre-trip examination, seek for
questions.answer3: frays in the water pump belt.
questions.answer4: a low windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: When you inspect hoses during your pre-trip test, you need to look for signs of leaks, such as puddles on the ground or fluids that are dripping on the underside of the engine or transmission. Also check the hoses for cracks or other problems.

questions.question: In which of the following two situations should you downshift?
questions.answer1: Starting down a hill and entering a curve
questions.answer2: Starting up a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer3: Starting down a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer4: Starting up a hill and entering a curve
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill lets you take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required, which is usually lower than the gear required to climb the hill. Downshifting before a curve improves stability and helps you get the power you will need to accelerate out of the turn.

questions.question: It has just reached freezing. Which of the following areas may be slippery?
questions.answer3: A wet-looking road
questions.explanation: Once the temperature drops to freezing, some sections of road will start to freeze before others. The first to freeze will be shaded areas and bridges. If the road appears wet, it may be covered in black ice, a thin layer of slippery ice through which you can see the road.

questions.question: Why is it important to use a helper when backing?
questions.answer2: Because people feel more comfortable when you do
questions.answer3: Because you are providing a job for someone else
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: It is important to use a helper when you are backing because you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals for "Go" and (most importantly) "Stop."

questions.question: You should put the starter switch key into your pocket while you perform the pre-trip inspection because
questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.
questions.answer3: it could damage the starting mechanism.
questions.answer4: any of the above could occur.
questions.explanation: While you are performing the pre-trip inspection, you do not want someone (such as a co-driver) who is unaware of your location to start your vehicle and accidentally injure you.

questions.question: Before transporting a sealed load, you must inspect
questions.answer1: a small sample of whatever is inside.
questions.answer2: a picture of whatever is inside.
questions.answer3: that you don't exceed gross weight or axle weight limits.
questions.explanation: While you cannot actually inspect sealed loads, it's still your responsibility to ensure that you do not exceed your axle weight limits or gross weight restrictions, so check them both.

questions.question: The most significant hand gesture on which you and your assistance should both agree is
questions.answer3: “Stop.”
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: What is the gross vehicle weight (GVW)?
questions.answer1: A vehicle's maximum weight rating, specified by its manufacturer
questions.answer2: The total weight of the vehicle, towed vehicles, and the load
questions.answer3: The total weight of a single vehicle and its load
questions.explanation: GVW is the simplest of the vehicle weight terms, defined as the weight of just a single vehicle and the load that it is carrying.

questions.question: On which of the following types of fires should you NOT use a B:C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Wood
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher should not be used on burning materials that you can use ordinary water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to brake to a stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your braking distance increases by roughly the square of the speed increase – to about four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 184 feet.

questions.question: In North Dakota, the maximum height of a commercial motor vehicle (CMV) is
questions.answer3: 16 feet.
questions.explanation: There is no Federal vehicle height requirement for CMVs. Each state may set its own height restrictions. In North Dakota, the maximum height of a CMV is 14 feet, whether or not the CMV is loaded.

questions.question: How often do you have to pull over to inspect your goods while driving?
questions.answer3: Every three hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, the North Dakota Commercial Drivers License Manual states that you should check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your trip and then every 3 hours or 150 miles, as well as after each break you take.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four fundamental abilities required to operate a commercial motor vehicle?
questions.answer3: First-aid certification
questions.explanation: As described in detail in section 2.2 of the North Dakota Commercial Drivers License Manual, the four basic skills for safe operation of a commercial motor vehicle are accelerating, steering, stopping, and backing safely. While first-aid certification might come in handy at some point in your career, it is not one of the four basic skills.

questions.question: Which lights should you use the most when driving at night?
questions.answer3: Emergency flashers
questions.explanation: While driving at night, you should use your high beams to see farther as long as it is safe and legal and you will not blind any other drivers. Section 2.11.5 of the North Dakota Commercial Drivers License Manual states that you should dim your headlights whenever you are within 500 feet of an oncoming vehicle or within 300 feet of a vehicle you are following.

questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulation 49 CFR 392.22. This regulation also specifies where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as undivided two-way roads and curves. (These situations are also covered in section 2.5.2 of the North Dakota Commercial Drivers License Manual.)

questions.question: How many hours of sleep per night does the average adult need to maintain alertness?
questions.answer3: Eight to nine hours
questions.explanation: Sleep debt is a dangerous condition in which missing sleep adds up until you risk falling asleep at the wheel unless you get some rest. Getting less than six hours of sleep per night triples the risk of an accident. At least 15% of heavy truck crashes are believed to involve driver fatigue. Before a trip, you should get adequate sleep. The average person needs seven or eight hours of sleep every 24 hours to maintain alertness.

questions.question: If you have a flat tire, you should not do which of the following?
questions.answer3: Brake hard and immediately.
questions.answer4: Be aware that a tire has failed.
questions.explanation: Hard braking could cause your vehicle to go out of control, so brake gently only after the vehicle has slowed down and you have regained control.

questions.question: What is a common cause of tire fires?
questions.answer3: Cold tires
questions.explanation: Underinflated tires and dual tires that touch are the most common causes of tire fires.

questions.question: Which of the following retarder assertions is true?
questions.answer1: Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for braking.
questions.answer2: When your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarder may cause them to skid.
questions.answer3: You should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow-covered.
questions.answer4: All of the above statements are correct.
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should always turn off your retarders in poor weather.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the basic shifting method?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, press the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, press the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: Why should you cover your cargo?
questions.answer1: To protect individuals from any spilled cargo
questions.answer2: To protect your cargo from bad weather
questions.answer3: Because many states require it
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: There are several reasons to cover your cargo, including protecting other people and the cargo itself. In addition, it will help you comply with regulations in several states.

questions.question: If you are convicted of a second DUI offense in either a CMV or your personal vehicle, how long will you lose your CDL driving privileges?
questions.answer3: Life
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of DUI for a second time, you will lose your CDL privileges for life. While you are driving a CMV, a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.04% or above qualifies as DUI. Your first offense is a wake-up call and a chance to get help, but your second offense is going to mean unemployment. If you get a DUI, seek help before you lose your salary and your future.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.
questions.answer3: Call the police from your cell phone if you can do it safely.
questions.explanation: If an aggressive driver is trying to confront you, do not give the person the confrontation that he or she seeks. Instead, seek police, peace, and safety.
