questions.question: How many tie-downs are required for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tie-down per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two per load, regardless of the length. So for 20 feet, you should have two tie-downs.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover while driving a combination vehicle, you should
questions.answer1: keep the cargo as low as possible and drive slowly around turns.
questions.answer2: keep the cargo near the center of the vehicle and drive slowly on the highway.
questions.answer3: keep the cargo as low as possible and drive slowly on the highway.
questions.answer4: keep the cargo high off the ground and drive slowly around turns.
questions.explanation: More than half of truck driver deaths in accidents are the result of truck rollovers. The higher the truck's center of gravity, the more likely it is to roll over. If the cargo is to one side, it will make the trailer lean, which can also make a rollover more likely. To help prevent a rollover, keep your cargo centered and as low as possible, and drive slowly around turns.

questions.question: If you are traveling at 55 mph in a 30-foot vehicle, you should leave how many seconds of following distance?
questions.answer3: 3 seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. Therefore, for a 30-foot vehicle traveling at 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: Always try to back toward the driver's side because
questions.answer1: it's more comfortable for turning your neck.
questions.answer2: you can see better, watching the vehicle's rear from the side window.
questions.answer3: your truck will probably pull toward the driver's side.
questions.answer4: all of the above are true.
questions.explanation: You should always back toward the driver's side because you will be able to see things much more easily. For example, you can keep an eye on the vehicle's rear by viewing it from your side window. If your truck pulls in either direction, it needs service. Your neck's comfort should not affect your safety decision.

questions.question: The minimum tire tread depth for front tires is
questions.answer3: 1/2 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels and any visible evidence of cracks or leaks.

questions.question: Total stopping distance equals
questions.answer3: perception distance + reaction distance + braking distance.
questions.answer4: reaction distance + viewing distance + braking distance.
questions.explanation: Total stopping distance is the sum of your perception distance (how far your vehicle goes from when you see the hazard until your brain processes it), reaction distance (how far the vehicle goes from when your brain orders your foot to take action until your foot actually starts to brake), and braking distance (how far the vehicle continues to travel once you apply the brake).

questions.question: Which of the following should NOT be checked during a trip?
questions.answer3: Text messages
questions.explanation: During your trip, you should keep an eye on all of your vehicle's key systems, such as the instruments, gauges, tires, voltmeter, mirrors, and cargo. Make sure you put your phone aside for the entire trip.

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you
questions.answer1: avoid using your cell phone until you reach your destination.
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in the first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: eat, drink, and smoke only on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no other vehicles around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. Avoid using your cell phone until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: Letting the air out of hot tires
questions.answer1: is a good idea because the extra pressure will be relieved.
questions.answer2: is a bad idea because when the tires cool off, the pressure will be too low.
questions.answer3: will have no effect at all.
questions.answer4: will cool them down. You will be able to continue your trip sooner.
questions.explanation: When tires get hot, the air pressure increases. However, relieving that extra pressure will leave the air pressure too low when the tires cool again, and then the tires may catch fire or blow out. If your tires are too hot to touch, stop until they have cooled down.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an antilock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: What is the definition of a hazard?
questions.answer2: A road user or road condition that presents a possible danger
questions.answer3: Something you must stop for
questions.explanation: A hazard is a road user or road condition that presents a possible danger. A hazard is something that can go wrong but shouldn't if you've been vigilant.

questions.question: How long does it take a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double railroad track?
questions.answer3: More than 30 seconds
questions.explanation: You can expect it to take more than 15 seconds for a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double track and at least 14 seconds to clear a single track.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key steering component?
questions.answer3: Gear box
questions.explanation: The gear box is an integral part of the steering system. The other three choices are parts of the suspension system.

questions.question: What is the best method for calculating the number of seconds of following distance you have?
questions.answer1: Wait until the vehicle ahead of you passes a shadow or landmark. Then count the seconds until you reach it.
questions.answer2: Get 1/4 closer to the vehicle in front of you, then back off again. Multiply how long this took you by four to give the following distance.
questions.answer3: Use the stopwatch on your cell phone to determine how long it takes you to reach a mile marker after the vehicle in front of you has passed it.
questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to reach some stationary object after the vehicle in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here either don't work or involve dangerous distractions. Note that you should increase your following distance in heavy traffic, in bad weather, with heavy vehicles, or at higher speeds.

questions.question: To transport cargo safely, which of the following are you NOT responsible for?
questions.answer1: Ensuring the safety of the cargo
questions.answer3: Making sure that cargo is properly secured
questions.answer4: Ensuring the freshness of sealed cargo
questions.explanation: You are not responsible for the state of sealed cargo, nor can you inspect it. You are only responsible for the safety of the cargo, ensuring that it is balanced, secured, and not overloaded, and does not get in the way of emergency equipment.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are
questions.answer1: signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo.
questions.answer2: signs on the inside of the vehicle that remind the driver of what he or she is carrying.
questions.answer3: signs that help tax collectors determine how much to tax a hazardous cargo.
questions.answer4: signs that warn the public to stay at least 1,000 feet from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are four regulated signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo for those who need to know, such as emergency service personnel or those who load and unload cargo.

questions.question: When you start to drive down a steep downgrade, which of the following should influence your choice of speed?
questions.answer1: The total weight of your vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: When choosing a safe speed for driving down a steep downgrade, consider its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: How do you get started without rolling backwards?
questions.answer1: Set the parking brake whenever necessary.
questions.answer2: Engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake.
questions.answer3: Apply the trailer brake hand valve.
questions.explanation: If you have a manual transmission vehicle, partly engage the clutch before you take your right foot off the brake. Set the parking brake whenever necessary to keep from rolling back. Release the parking brake only when you have applied enough engine power to keep from rolling back. On a tractor-trailer equipped with a trailer brake hand valve, the hand valve can be applied to keep from rolling back.

questions.question: How speed you should reduce when you drive on wet roads?
questions.answer3: one-third.
questions.explanation: When a road is wet, stopping distance is increased, and you should reduce your speed by one-third. On snow, slow to one-half your usual speed. On icy roads, slow to a crawl and stop driving as soon as you can do so safely.

questions.question: If the engine is not overheated, is it completely safe to remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer3: Yes, as long as there is no overflow.
questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.
questions.explanation: It is not enough for the engine not to be overheated. The cooling system must cool completely before you attempt to remove the radiator cap. Even then, you should be very careful because there may still be tremendous pressure and damaging steam and fluids.

questions.question: Do empty trucks have the best braking?
questions.answer3: Yes, but only on wet surfaces.
questions.answer4: Yes, but only if the trucks are newer than 1998.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have longer stopping distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: How many tiedowns are required for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tiedown per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two per load, regardless of the length. So for 20 feet, you should have two tiedowns.

questions.question: An antilock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: keep your wheels from locking when you brake hard.
questions.explanation: ABS kicks in only to keep the wheels from locking, which could cause a skid. ABS does not change the way you normally brake the rest of the time. It is not a substitute for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, or regular maintenance.

questions.question: You should do the following to assist you stay aware and safe while driving:
questions.answer1: avoid medications that can cause drowsiness.
questions.answer2: drink coffee if you get drowsy.
questions.answer3: roll down your windows to get fresh air.
questions.answer4: have a whiskey to brace yourself.
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, some prescription and over-the-counter medications can cause drowsiness, sedation, or impaired coordination, which make them dangerous for CMV operators. If you are unsure about the effects of a particular medication, check the warning label or ask your pharmacist or doctor. Never try to fight drowsiness with coffee, fresh air, or especially alcohol. The only "cure" for being tired is sleeping until you are rested.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: Your body breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate. Typically, this is one standard drink per hour, where one standard drink equals 1.5 ounces of hard liquor, 5 ounces of wine, or one 12-ounce can of beer. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: What can you do at an accident scene to help avoid another accident?
questions.answer1: Stay in your vehicle and do nothing until help arrives.
questions.answer2: Set out warning devices to keep other vehicles from running into the accident scene.
questions.answer3: Leave your vehicle, do nothing, and get to higher ground.
questions.answer4: Have a drink to calm your nerves.
questions.explanation: Unless you have been injured, it is your responsibility to ensure that others can see your vehicle at the accident scene. Set out your warning devices as quickly as possible to avoid further accidents such as a pile-up.

questions.question: Each of the following tasks is involved in starting the engine and inspecting the cab, EXCEPT
questions.answer3: starting the engine, then listening for unusual noises.
questions.answer4: starting the engine, then putting the gearshift in neutral.
questions.explanation: Please note that the question says "EXCEPT." When performing this part of the inspection, start the engine after you have put the gearshift in neutral. Then listen for any unusual noises. Once you perform the engine check, you will check all your gauges and controls, such as the air pressure gauge and transmission controls.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: All of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide to the left, a driver may try to pass you on your right while you are turning. Instead, make the right turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This will deny drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: When evaluating hoses with the instructor during your pre-trip examination, seek for
questions.answer3: frays in the water pump belt.
questions.answer4: a low windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: When you inspect hoses during your pre-trip test, you need to look for signs of leaks, such as puddles on the ground or fluids that are dripping on the underside of the engine or transmission. Also check the hoses for cracks or other problems.

questions.question: In which of the following two situations should you downshift?
questions.answer1: Starting down a hill and entering a curve
questions.answer2: Starting up a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer3: Starting down a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer4: Starting up a hill and entering a curve
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill lets you take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required, which is usually lower than the gear required to climb the hill. Downshifting before a curve improves stability and helps you get the power you will need to accelerate out of the turn.

questions.question: It has just reached freezing. Which of the following areas may be slippery?
questions.answer3: A wet-looking road
questions.explanation: Once the temperature drops to freezing, some sections of road will start to freeze before others. The first to freeze will be shaded areas and bridges. If the road appears wet, it may be covered in black ice, a thin layer of slippery ice through which you can see the road.

questions.question: Why is it important to use a helper when backing?
questions.answer2: Because people feel more comfortable when you do
questions.answer3: Because you are providing a job for someone else
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: It is important to use a helper when you are backing because you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals for "Go" and (most importantly) "Stop."

questions.question: You should put the starter switch key into your pocket while you perform the pre-trip inspection because
questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.
questions.answer3: it could damage the starting mechanism.
questions.answer4: any of the above could occur.
questions.explanation: While you are performing the pre-trip inspection, you do not want someone (such as a co-driver) who is unaware of your location to start your vehicle and accidentally injure you.

questions.question: Before transporting a sealed load, you must inspect
questions.answer1: a small sample of whatever is inside.
questions.answer2: a picture of whatever is inside.
questions.answer3: that you don't exceed gross weight or axle weight limits.
questions.explanation: While you cannot actually inspect sealed loads, it's still your responsibility to ensure that you do not exceed your axle weight limits or gross weight restrictions, so check them both.

questions.question: The most significant hand gesture on which you and your assistance should both agree is
questions.answer3: “Stop.”
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: What is the gross vehicle weight (GVW)?
questions.answer1: A vehicle's maximum weight rating, specified by its manufacturer
questions.answer2: The total weight of the vehicle, towed vehicles, and the load
questions.answer3: The total weight of a single vehicle and its load
questions.explanation: GVW is the simplest of the vehicle weight terms, defined as the weight of just a single vehicle and the load that it is carrying.

questions.question: On which of the following types of fires should you NOT use a B:C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Wood
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher should not be used on burning materials that you can use ordinary water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: How often do you have to pull over to inspect your goods while driving?
questions.answer3: Every three hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, the Oregon Commercial Driver Manual states that you should check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your trip and then every 3 hours or 150 miles, as well as after each break you take.

questions.question: Which lights should you use the most when driving at night?
questions.answer3: Emergency flashers
questions.explanation: While driving at night, you should use your high beams to see farther as long as it is safe and legal and you will not blind any other drivers. Section 2.11.5 of the Oregon Commercial Driver Manual recommends that you dim your headlights whenever you are within 500 feet of an oncoming vehicle. It also notes that under Oregon law, you must dim your headlights whenever you are within 350 feet of a vehicle you are following.

questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulation 49 CFR 392.22. This regulation also specifies where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as undivided two-way roads and curves. (These situations are also covered in section 2.5.2 of the Oregon Commercial Driver Manual.)

questions.question: To go over the Siskiyou Pass safely, what should you do?
questions.answer1: Before you start, make sure that your lights are working.
questions.answer2: Consider using tire chains on ice or snow.
questions.answer3: Check your brakes before you enter the downgrade.
questions.answer4: Do all of the above (and more).
questions.explanation: The Siskiyou Pass is a mountain pass through the Siskiyou Mountains. One six-mile stretch of road is particularly hazardous, with a steep 6% downgrade; sharp curves; and black ice, fog, or snow often from October through April. To go over the pass safely, you should take numerous precautions: Know the locations of escape ramps along the way if you should need them. Make sure you have warning devices (triangles) with you just in case. Before you start, be sure you are rested and alert, not fatigued. Check your brakes and lights and use engine braking through the downgrade. Watch for black ice, fog, or snow. In ice or snow, consider using tire chains.

questions.question: How many hours of sleep per night does the average adult need?
questions.answer3: 8 to 9 hours
questions.explanation: Sleep debt is a dangerous condition in which missing sleep adds up until you risk falling asleep at the wheel unless you get some rest. Getting less than six hours of sleep per night triples the risk of an accident. At least 15% of heavy truck crashes are believed to involve driver fatigue. Before a trip, you should get adequate sleep. The average person needs seven or eight hours of sleep every 24 hours to maintain alertness.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four fundamental abilities required to operate a commercial motor vehicle?
questions.answer3: First-aid certification
questions.explanation: As described in detail in section 2.2 of the Oregon Commercial Driver Manual, the four basic skills for safe operation of a commercial motor vehicle are accelerating, steering, stopping, and backing safely. While first-aid certification might come in handy at some point in your career, it is not one of the four basic skills.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to brake to a stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your braking distance increases by roughly the square of the speed increase – to about four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 184 feet.

questions.question: If you have a flat tire, you should not do which of the following?
questions.answer3: Brake hard and immediately.
questions.answer4: Be aware that a tire has failed.
questions.explanation: Hard braking could cause your vehicle to go out of control, so brake gently only after the vehicle has slowed down and you have regained control.

questions.question: What is a common cause of tire fires?
questions.answer3: Cold tires
questions.explanation: Underinflated tires and dual tires that touch are the most common causes of tire fires.

questions.question: Which of the following retarder assertions is true?
questions.answer1: Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for braking.
questions.answer2: When your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarder may cause them to skid.
questions.answer3: You should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow-covered.
questions.answer4: All of the above statements are correct.
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should always turn off your retarders in poor weather.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the basic shifting method?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, press the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, press the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: Why should you cover your cargo?
questions.answer1: To protect individuals from any spilled cargo
questions.answer2: To protect your cargo from bad weather
questions.answer3: Because many states require it
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: There are several reasons to cover your cargo, including protecting other people and the cargo itself. In addition, it will help you comply with regulations in several states.

questions.question: If you are convicted of a second DUI offense in either a CMV or your personal vehicle, how long will you lose your CDL driving privileges?
questions.answer3: Life
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of DUI for a second time, you will lose your CDL privileges for life. While you are driving a CMV, a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.04% or above qualifies as DUI. Your first offense is a wake-up call and a chance to get help, but your second offense is going to mean unemployment. If you get a DUI, seek help before you lose your salary and your future.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.
questions.answer3: Call the police from your cell phone if you can do it safely.
questions.explanation: If an aggressive driver is trying to confront you, do not give the person the confrontation that he or she seeks. Instead, seek police, peace, and safety.

questions.question: Which of the following wheel or rim issues is potentially dangerous?
questions.answer3: Welding repairs
questions.explanation: When you inspect the wheels and rims, be alert for missing clamps, spacers, studs, or lugs; mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings; or wheels or rims that have had welding repairs. Any of these problems can be dangerous.

questions.question: If your brakes become damp, they may
questions.answer3: apply unevenly.
questions.explanation: If your brakes get wet, they may apply unevenly, work weakly, or grab, any of which can be dangerous. Try to maintain light pressure on the brakes for a short distance to heat them up and dry them out.

questions.question: What is your total stopping distance when you're driving at 55 mph under good driving conditions?
questions.answer3: at least 353 feet.
questions.explanation: At 55 mph under good driving conditions, your total stopping distance will be at least 419 feet: 142 feet of perception distance + 61 feet of reaction distance + 216 feet of braking distance. (The length of a football field including the two end zones is 360 feet.) Under poor driving conditions, the total stopping distance may be even longer.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely to cause a tire fire?
questions.answer1: Different makes of tires on different wheels
questions.answer3: Dual tires that touch
questions.explanation: Common causes of tire fires include underinflated tires and dual tires that touch each other or parts of the vehicle.

questions.question: What's the best way to take a curve?
questions.answer1: Brake in the curve as needed.
questions.answer2: Slow down before the curve and accelerate slightly in the curve.
questions.answer3: Slow down before the curve and stay at that speed from then on.
questions.answer4: Speed up before the curve and slow down in the curve.
questions.explanation: If you try to take a curve too fast, your vehicle may skid or roll over. However, braking in a curve can lock the wheels and cause a skid. Instead, slow down before the curve. Use a gear that will let you accelerate slightly once you're in the curve. This will help you keep control.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a key steering system component?
questions.answer3: Leaf spring
questions.explanation: The tie rod, gear box, and steering shaft are parts of the steering system. A leaf spring is part of the suspension system.

questions.question: If you must stop on a road or the shoulder of a road, you must set out your warning devices within
questions.answer3: 15 minutes.
questions.explanation: Federal regulations require you to set out your emergency warning devices (such as reflective triangles) within 10 minutes of stopping. Federal regulations also stipulate where you must place your warning devices relative to your vehicle. See section 2.5.2 of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Commercial Driver's Manual for details. [49 CFR 392.22]

questions.question: For what time should you schedule your trip?
questions.answer1: In the middle of the night, when there is little traffic
questions.answer2: In the middle of the day, when there is the most daylight
questions.answer3: For the hours during which you are normally awake
questions.answer4: When it best fits your social life
questions.explanation: At least 15% of heavy truck crashes are believed to involve driver fatigue. Before a trip, you should get adequate sleep; prepare your route carefully to identify total distance, stopping points, and other logistical considerations; schedule trips for the hours during which you are normally awake, not the middle of the night; and avoid medications that cause drowsiness.

questions.question: Which of the following should you do inside the cab during your pre-trip inspection?
questions.answer2: Check that you have all your required papers.
questions.answer3: Secure all loose items.
questions.explanation: In the last part of Step 6 of the seven-step pre-trip inspection, you get in the cab and make sure it's ready. Turn off any unnecessary lights, check that you have all your required papers, and secure loose items. Then start your engine.

questions.question: The minimum tire tread depth for front tires is
questions.answer3: 6/32 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four fundamental abilities required to operate a commercial motor vehicle?
questions.answer3: First-aid certification
questions.explanation: As described in detail in section 2.2 of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Commercial Driver's Manual, the four basic skills for safe operation of a commercial motor vehicle are accelerating, steering, stopping, and backing safely. While first-aid certification might come in handy at some point in your career, it is not one of the four basic skills.

questions.question: What is the Gross Combination Weight (GCW)?
questions.answer1: The combined weight of the power unit and trailers
questions.answer2: The weight of a trailer plus its cargo
questions.answer3: The weight of the power unit plus the cargo
questions.answer4: The combined weight of the power unit, trailers, and cargo
questions.explanation: The Gross Combination Weight (GCW) of a vehicle is the combined weight of the power unit, trailers, and cargo. Make sure you know how to use this concept. For example, if a bridge has an eight-ton weight limit, a loaded tractor-trailer must weigh no more than eight tons to cross that bridge legally and safely.

questions.question: Which of the following types of fires should you NOT attempt to extinguish with water?
questions.answer3: Tire
questions.explanation: Never attempt to extinguish an electrical fire with water. Water can conduct electricity. If you are holding a fire extinguisher that is spraying water on an electrical fire, you may receive a fatal electrical shock. Instead, use a fire extinguisher that is rated at least C (nonconducting), such as carbon dioxide or dry chemical.

questions.question: Do empty trucks have shorter stopping distances than loaded trucks?
questions.answer3: Yes, but only on wet surfaces.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have longer stopping distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: If you are convicted of knowingly using a commercial motor vehicle (CMV) to transport illegal drugs, you will be disqualified from commercial driving for
questions.answer3: 10 years.
questions.explanation: Under Pennsylvania law, the distribution of illegal drugs is a felony. If you are convicted of knowingly using a commercial motor vehicle (CMV) to distribute illegal drugs, you will be disqualified from commercial driving for life. No exceptions. This is in addition to the legal penalties (prison, a hefty fine, or both) that you will face for the felony. [75 PA Cons Stat § 1611]

questions.question: In Pennsylvania, the maximum height of a commercial motor vehicle (CMV) is
questions.answer3: 13 feet 6 inches.
questions.explanation: There is no Federal vehicle height requirement for CMVs. Each state may set its own height restrictions. In Pennsylvania, the maximum height of a CMV is 13 feet 6 inches, whether or not the CMV is loaded.

questions.question: In the dark, what is the maximum distance that you can see with high beams?
questions.answer3: 800 feet
questions.explanation: In the dark, your low beams let you see about 250 feet ahead, and your high beams let you see about 350 – 500 feet ahead. Don't drive so fast that you'll be unable to stop within the range of your headlights. Otherwise, by the time you spot a hazard, it might be too late to stop.

questions.question: How often do you have to pull over to inspect your goods while driving?
questions.answer3: Every three hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Commercial Driver's Manual states that you should check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your trip and then every 3 hours or 150 miles, as well as after each break you take.

questions.question: When parking your vehicle, you should look for a parking space
questions.answer1: into which your vehicle will fit snugly.
questions.answer2: with enough room to let you back out.
questions.answer3: that you can pull straight through.
questions.answer4: that is as close as possible to your destination.
questions.explanation: When parking your vehicle, you should look for a parking space that you can go straight through rather than back out of. Also note the layout of the parking lot and your parking space's location within it so you won't have difficulty exiting the parking space later.

questions.question: Crossing a double railroad track should be done with extreme caution because
questions.answer1: it's wider than a single track.
questions.answer2: there may be more than one train.
questions.answer3: trains may be more frequent.
questions.answer4: there will probably be a flag person there.
questions.explanation: At a double railroad track, a train on one track may hide a train on the other track. After the train you can see has cleared the railroad crossing, look both ways to make sure that there are no trains on the other track before you start across the railroad crossing. This is especially important at crossings without warning signals, gates, or flagmen to warn you of other trains.

questions.question: When you proceed through an underpass, your vertical clearance may be affected by
questions.answer3: repaving of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Don't assume that the vertical clearance signs positioned at underpasses are correct. Repaving or packed snow may have raised the effective height of the road surface, reducing the clearance since the signs were installed. Furthermore, without the weight of cargo, an empty truck may be significantly taller than a loaded one, which can also reduce the vertical clearance.

questions.question: What is the axle weight?
questions.answer1: What each axle weighs by itself
questions.answer2: The combined weight of the power unit's axles only
questions.answer3: The combined weight of all the axles of your vehicle
questions.answer4: The maximum weight that can be supported by one axle
questions.explanation: The axle weight is the maximum weight that an individual axle can support. When a vehicle's axles are relatively close together, a high axle weight risks overloading bridges and roadways. Also, vehicles with high axle weights can cause much more damage to the road surface. Federal law currently limits axle weights on federally funded highways to 20,000 pounds on a single axle and 34,000 pounds on a tandem axle.

questions.question: What are the benefits of completing a post-trip inspection report?
questions.answer1: So that you can't be blamed for any subsequent damage
questions.answer2: To prove you finished your trip
questions.answer3: To alert others to safety problems requiring repair
questions.explanation: You should do a post-trip inspection of each vehicle you operated. Note any safety-related problems that you found while driving the vehicle and repairs that you believe are needed. The inspection report will let the next driver know if there are safety-related problems. It will also let the motor carrier know if safety-related repairs are needed. Federal regulations require an inspection report be completed by the end of the day's use of the vehicle. [49 CFR 396.11]

questions.question: What's the maximum amount of play that your steering wheel should have?
questions.answer3: 2 degrees
questions.explanation: Steering wheel play of more than 10 degrees can make it harder to steer. Ten degrees of play is roughly equivalent to two inches of play at the rim of a 20-inch steering wheel.

questions.question: If ________ or more of the leaves in any leaf spring are broken or missing, the vehicle will be put out of service.
questions.answer3: one-third
questions.explanation: If one-fourth or more of the leaves in any leaf spring are broken or missing, the vehicle will be put out of service.

questions.question: The heaviest items in your load should be placed
questions.answer3: to one side.
questions.explanation: Load your vehicle to keep its center of gravity as low as possible. A truck with a high center of gravity is more likely to roll over on a curve, even if the truck is not exceeding the posted speed limit for the curve.

questions.question: What should you do first if you see a hazard ahead?
questions.answer1: Come to a complete stop as soon as it is safe to do so.
questions.answer3: Make a contingency plan.
questions.answer4: Do nothing until you get closer to it.
questions.explanation: A hazard is a road user or road condition that presents a possible danger. A hazard is not an emergency – but it can become one. When you spot a hazard, think about the emergencies that could develop and formulate plans (such as evasive action or braking) to deal with them. Be ready to carry out those plans if necessary. It's all part of being a safe, defensive driver.

questions.question: What is a hazard's definition?
questions.answer1: A road user or road condition that presents a possible danger
questions.answer3: Something you must stop for
questions.explanation: A hazard is a road user or road condition that presents a possible danger. A hazard is something that can go wrong but shouldn't if you've been vigilant.

questions.question: You hear a noise that sounds like a tire blowout while driving a vehicle with twin tires. Your vehicle's handling, on the other hand, appears to be unaffected. So, what are your options?
questions.answer2: Check your tires at the next stop.
questions.answer3: Stop and check your tires now.
questions.answer4: Look in your mirrors to try to spot trouble.
questions.explanation: If a dual tire blows out, handling may not be affected – at first. However, the other tire will then have to carry the entire load, which may damage it too. If you hear what sounds like a blowout on a vehicle with dual tires, stop and check the tires.

questions.question: Your emergency kit does NOT need to include
questions.answer3: a fire extinguisher.
questions.explanation: While a jacket might keep you comfortable, it is not a required part of your emergency kit. You must have a working fire extinguisher, warning devices, and spare electrical fuses (unless your vehicle has circuit breakers).

questions.question: Why should you use a helper when you are backing?
questions.answer1: Because every truck has blind spots
questions.answer2: To make sure you don't damage your truck
questions.answer3: Because it's the law
questions.answer4: To check your style of driving
questions.explanation: You should use a helper when you are backing because you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals for "Go" and (most importantly) "Stop."

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should do all of the following EXCEPT
questions.answer3: avoid tricks such as flashing your brake lights.
questions.explanation: Don't try to speed up to outdistance or appease a tailgater. No speed is too fast for some tailgaters. Instead, increase your following distance and if possible, keep right to let the tailgater pass.

questions.question: How far ahead should you look while driving?
questions.answer3: 12 to 15 seconds
questions.explanation: You should look ahead the distance that your CMV will travel in 12 to 15 seconds. At 60 mph, your CMV will travel a quarter mile (1,320 feet) in 15 seconds.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels and any visible evidence of cracks or leaks.

questions.question: Total stopping distance equals
questions.answer3: perception distance + reaction distance + braking distance.
questions.answer4: reaction distance + viewing distance + braking distance.
questions.explanation: Total stopping distance is the sum of your perception distance (how far your vehicle goes from when you see the hazard until your brain processes it), reaction distance (how far the vehicle goes from when your brain orders your foot to take action until your foot actually starts to brake), and braking distance (how far the vehicle continues to travel once you apply the brake).

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you
questions.answer1: avoid using your cell phone until you reach your destination.
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in the first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: eat, drink, and smoke only on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no other vehicles around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. Avoid using your cell phone until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: To transport cargo safely, which of the following are you NOT responsible for?
questions.answer1: Ensuring the safety of the cargo
questions.answer3: Making sure that cargo is properly secured
questions.answer4: Ensuring the freshness of sealed cargo
questions.explanation: You are not responsible for the state of sealed cargo, nor can you inspect it. You are only responsible for the safety of the cargo, ensuring that it is balanced, secured, and not overloaded, and does not get in the way of emergency equipment.

questions.question: When you start to drive down a steep downgrade, which of the following should influence your choice of speed?
questions.answer1: The total weight of your vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: When choosing a safe speed for driving down a steep downgrade, consider its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: If the engine is not overheated, is it completely safe to remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer3: Yes, as long as there is no overflow.
questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.
questions.explanation: It is not enough for the engine not to be overheated. The cooling system must cool completely before you attempt to remove the radiator cap. Even then, you should be very careful because there may still be tremendous pressure and damaging steam and fluids.

questions.question: An antilock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: keep your wheels from locking when you brake hard.
questions.explanation: ABS kicks in only to keep the wheels from locking, which could cause a skid. ABS does not change the way you normally brake the rest of the time. It is not a substitute for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, or regular maintenance.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: Your body breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate. Typically, this is one standard drink per hour, where one standard drink equals 1.5 ounces of hard liquor, 5 ounces of wine, or one 12-ounce can of beer. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: What can you do at an accident scene to help avoid another accident?
questions.answer1: Stay in your vehicle and do nothing until help arrives.
questions.answer2: Set out warning devices to keep other vehicles from running into the accident scene.
questions.answer3: Leave your vehicle, do nothing, and get to higher ground.
questions.answer4: Have a drink to calm your nerves.
questions.explanation: Unless you have been injured, it is your responsibility to ensure that others can see your vehicle at the accident scene. Set out your warning devices as quickly as possible to avoid further accidents such as a pile-up.

questions.question: When evaluating hoses with the instructor during your pre-trip examination, seek for
questions.answer3: frays in the water pump belt.
questions.answer4: a low windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: When you inspect hoses during your pre-trip test, you need to look for signs of leaks, such as puddles on the ground or fluids that are dripping on the underside of the engine or transmission. Also check the hoses for cracks or other problems.

questions.question: It has just reached freezing. Which of the following areas may be slippery?
questions.answer3: A wet-looking road
questions.explanation: Once the temperature drops to freezing, some sections of road will start to freeze before others. The first to freeze will be shaded areas and bridges. If the road appears wet, it may be covered in black ice, a thin layer of slippery ice through which you can see the road.

questions.question: You should put the starter switch key into your pocket while you perform the pre-trip inspection because
questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.
questions.answer3: it could damage the starting mechanism.
questions.answer4: any of the above could occur.
questions.explanation: While you are performing the pre-trip inspection, you do not want someone (such as a co-driver) who is unaware of your location to start your vehicle and accidentally injure you.

questions.question: The most significant hand gesture on which you and your assistance should both agree is
questions.answer3: “Stop.”
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: Which of the following retarder assertions is true?
questions.answer1: Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for braking.
questions.answer2: When your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarder may cause them to skid.
questions.answer3: You should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow-covered.
questions.answer4: All of the above statements are correct.
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should always turn off your retarders in poor weather.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the basic shifting method?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, press the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, press the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.
questions.answer3: Call the police from your cell phone if you can do it safely.
questions.explanation: If an aggressive driver is trying to confront you, do not give the person the confrontation that he or she seeks. Instead, seek police, peace, and safety.

questions.question: How many tie-downs are required for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tie-down per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two per load, regardless of the length. So for 20 feet, you should have two tie-downs.

questions.question: If you are traveling at 55 mph in a 30-foot vehicle, you should leave how many seconds of following distance?
questions.answer3: 3 seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. Therefore, for a 30-foot vehicle traveling at 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: Always try to back toward the driver's side because
questions.answer1: it's more comfortable for turning your neck.
questions.answer2: you can see better, watching the vehicle's rear from the side window.
questions.answer3: your truck will probably pull toward the driver's side.
questions.answer4: all of the above are true.
questions.explanation: You should always back toward the driver's side because you will be able to see things much more easily. For example, you can keep an eye on the vehicle's rear by viewing it from your side window. If your truck pulls in either direction, it needs service. Your neck's comfort should not affect your safety decision.

questions.question: The minimum tire tread depth for front tires is
questions.answer3: 1/2 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: Which of the following should NOT be checked during a trip?
questions.answer3: Text messages
questions.explanation: During your trip, you should keep an eye on all of your vehicle's key systems, such as the instruments, gauges, tires, voltmeter, mirrors, and cargo. Make sure you put your phone aside for the entire trip.

questions.question: Letting the air out of hot tires
questions.answer1: is a good idea because the extra pressure will be relieved.
questions.answer2: is a bad idea because when the tires cool off, the pressure will be too low.
questions.answer3: will have no effect at all.
questions.answer4: will cool them down. You will be able to continue your trip sooner.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an antilock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.

questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: How long does it take a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double railroad track?
questions.answer3: More than 30 seconds

questions.question: Which of the following is a key steering component?

questions.question: What is the best method for calculating the number of seconds of following distance you have?
questions.answer1: Wait until the vehicle ahead of you passes a shadow or landmark. Then count the seconds until you reach it.

questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to reach some stationary object after the vehicle in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here either don't work or involve dangerous distractions. questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?

questions.question: To maintain alertness on your trips, you should
questions.answer1: schedule your trips for the daytime hours.
questions.answer3: avoid medications that cause drowsiness.
questions.explanation: Sleep debt is a dangerous condition in which missing sleep adds up until you risk falling asleep at the wheel unless you get some rest. questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to brake to a stop?

questions.question: If you are convicted of a second DUI offense in either a CMV or your personal vehicle, how long will you lose your CDL driving privileges?
questions.answer3: Life
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of DUI for a second time, you will lose your CDL privileges for life. Your first offense is a wake-up call and a chance to get help, but your second offense is going to mean unemployment. If you get a DUI, seek help before you lose your salary and your future.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.
questions.answer3: Call the police from your cell phone if you can do it safely.
questions.explanation: If an aggressive driver is trying to confront you, do not give the person the confrontation that he or she seeks. Instead, seek police, peace, and safety.

questions.question: How many tie-downs are required for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tie-down per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two per load, regardless of the length. So for 20 feet, you should have two tie-downs.

questions.question: After you submit an Affidavit for CDL History Check, your CDL history for the past _______ will be checked.
questions.answer3: ten years
questions.explanation: When you apply for a Rhode Island CDL, you must submit an Affidavit for CDL History Check. After you do so, a ten-year check of your CDL history will be conducted. What they find may affect your eligibility for a Rhode Island CDL.

questions.question: Which lights should you use the most when driving at night?
questions.answer3: Emergency flashers
questions.explanation: While driving at night, you should use your high beams to see farther as long as it is safe and legal and you will not blind any other drivers. Section 2.11.5 of the Rhode Island Commercial Driver License Manual recommends that you dim your headlights whenever you are within 500 feet of another vehicle.

questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulation 49 CFR 392.22. This regulation also specifies where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as undivided two-way roads and curves. (These situations are also covered in section 2.5.2 of the Rhode Island Commercial Driver License Manual.)

questions.question: How often do you have to pull over to inspect your goods while driving?
questions.answer3: Every three hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, the Rhode Island Commercial Driver License Manual states that you should check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your trip and then every 3 hours or 150 miles, as well as after each break you take.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four fundamental abilities required to operate a commercial motor vehicle?
questions.answer3: First-aid certification
questions.explanation: As described in detail in section 2.2 of the Rhode Island Commercial Driver License Manual, the four basic skills for safe operation of a commercial motor vehicle are accelerating, steering, stopping, and backing safely. While first-aid certification might come in handy at some point in your career, it is not one of the four basic skills.

questions.question: If you are traveling at 55 mph in a 30-foot vehicle, you should leave how many seconds of following distance?
questions.answer3: 3 seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. Therefore, for a 30-foot vehicle traveling at 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: Always try to back toward the driver's side because
questions.answer1: it's more comfortable for turning your neck.
questions.answer2: you can see better, watching the vehicle's rear from the side window.
questions.answer3: your truck will probably pull toward the driver's side.
questions.answer4: all of the above are true.
questions.explanation: You should always back toward the driver's side because you will be able to see things much more easily. For example, you can keep an eye on the vehicle's rear by viewing it from your side window. If your truck pulls in either direction, it needs service. Your neck's comfort should not affect your safety decision.

questions.question: The minimum tire tread depth for front tires is
questions.answer3: 1/2 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels and any visible evidence of cracks or leaks.

questions.question: Total stopping distance equals
questions.answer3: perception distance + reaction distance + braking distance.
questions.answer4: reaction distance + viewing distance + braking distance.
questions.explanation: Total stopping distance is the sum of your perception distance (how far your vehicle goes from when you see the hazard until your brain processes it), reaction distance (how far the vehicle goes from when your brain orders your foot to take action until your foot actually starts to brake), and braking distance (how far the vehicle continues to travel once you apply the brake).

questions.question: Which of the following should NOT be checked during a trip?
questions.answer3: Text messages
questions.explanation: During your trip, you should keep an eye on all of your vehicle's key systems, such as the instruments, gauges, tires, voltmeter, mirrors, and cargo. Make sure you put your phone aside for the entire trip.

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you
questions.answer1: avoid using your cell phone until you reach your destination.
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in the first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: eat, drink, and smoke only on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no other vehicles around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. Avoid using your cell phone until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: Letting the air out of hot tires
questions.answer1: is a good idea because the extra pressure will be relieved.
questions.answer2: is a bad idea because when the tires cool off, the pressure will be too low.
questions.answer3: will have no effect at all.
questions.answer4: will cool them down. You will be able to continue your trip sooner.
questions.explanation: When tires get hot, the air pressure increases. However, relieving that extra pressure will leave the air pressure too low when the tires cool again, and then the tires may catch fire or blow out. If your tires are too hot to touch, stop until they have cooled down.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an antilock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: What is the definition of a hazard?
questions.answer2: A road user or road condition that presents a possible danger
questions.answer3: Something you must stop for
questions.explanation: A hazard is a road user or road condition that presents a possible danger. A hazard is something that can go wrong but shouldn't if you've been vigilant.

questions.question: How long does it take a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double railroad track?
questions.answer3: More than 30 seconds
questions.explanation: You can expect it to take more than 15 seconds for a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double track and at least 14 seconds to clear a single track.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key steering component?
questions.answer3: Gear box
questions.explanation: The gear box is an integral part of the steering system. The other three choices are parts of the suspension system.

questions.question: What is the best method for calculating the number of seconds of following distance you have?
questions.answer1: Wait until the vehicle ahead of you passes a shadow or landmark. Then count the seconds until you reach it.
questions.answer2: Get 1/4 closer to the vehicle in front of you, then back off again. Multiply how long this took you by four to give the following distance.
questions.answer3: Use the stopwatch on your cell phone to determine how long it takes you to reach a mile marker after the vehicle in front of you has passed it.
questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to reach some stationary object after the vehicle in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here either don't work or involve dangerous distractions. Note that you should increase your following distance in heavy traffic, in bad weather, with heavy vehicles, or at higher speeds.

questions.question: To transport cargo safely, which of the following are you NOT responsible for?
questions.answer1: Ensuring the safety of the cargo
questions.answer3: Making sure that cargo is properly secured
questions.answer4: Ensuring the freshness of sealed cargo
questions.explanation: You are not responsible for the state of sealed cargo, nor can you inspect it. You are only responsible for the safety of the cargo, ensuring that it is balanced, secured, and not overloaded, and does not get in the way of emergency equipment.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are
questions.answer1: signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo.
questions.answer2: signs on the inside of the vehicle that remind the driver of what he or she is carrying.
questions.answer3: signs that help tax collectors determine how much to tax a hazardous cargo.
questions.answer4: signs that warn the public to stay at least 1,000 feet from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are four regulated signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo for those who need to know, such as emergency service personnel or those who load and unload cargo.

questions.question: When you start to drive down a steep downgrade, which of the following should influence your choice of speed?
questions.answer1: The total weight of your vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: When choosing a safe speed for driving down a steep downgrade, consider its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: How do you get started without rolling backwards?
questions.answer1: Set the parking brake whenever necessary.
questions.answer2: Engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake.
questions.answer3: Apply the trailer brake hand valve.
questions.explanation: If you have a manual transmission vehicle, partly engage the clutch before you take your right foot off the brake. Set the parking brake whenever necessary to keep from rolling back. Release the parking brake only when you have applied enough engine power to keep from rolling back. On a tractor-trailer equipped with a trailer brake hand valve, the hand valve can be applied to keep from rolling back.

questions.question: How speed you should reduce when you drive on wet roads?
questions.answer3: one-third.
questions.explanation: When a road is wet, stopping distance is increased, and you should reduce your speed by one-third. On snow, slow to one-half your usual speed. On icy roads, slow to a crawl and stop driving as soon as you can do so safely.

questions.question: If the engine is not overheated, is it completely safe to remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer3: Yes, as long as there is no overflow.
questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.
questions.explanation: It is not enough for the engine not to be overheated. The cooling system must cool completely before you attempt to remove the radiator cap. Even then, you should be very careful because there may still be tremendous pressure and damaging steam and fluids.

questions.question: Do empty trucks have the best braking?
questions.answer3: Yes, but only on wet surfaces.
questions.answer4: Yes, but only if the trucks are newer than 1998.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have longer stopping distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: An antilock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: keep your wheels from locking when you brake hard.
questions.explanation: ABS kicks in only to keep the wheels from locking, which could cause a skid. ABS does not change the way you normally brake the rest of the time. It is not a substitute for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, or regular maintenance.

questions.question: You should do the following to assist you stay aware and safe while driving:
questions.answer1: avoid medications that can cause drowsiness.
questions.answer2: drink coffee if you get drowsy.
questions.answer3: roll down your windows to get fresh air.
questions.answer4: have a whiskey to brace yourself.
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, some prescription and over-the-counter medications can cause drowsiness, sedation, or impaired coordination, which make them dangerous for CMV operators. If you are unsure about the effects of a particular medication, check the warning label or ask your pharmacist or doctor. Never try to fight drowsiness with coffee, fresh air, or especially alcohol. The only "cure" for being tired is sleeping until you are rested.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: Your body breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate. Typically, this is one standard drink per hour, where one standard drink equals 1.5 ounces of hard liquor, 5 ounces of wine, or one 12-ounce can of beer. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: What can you do at an accident scene to help avoid another accident?
questions.answer1: Stay in your vehicle and do nothing until help arrives.
questions.answer2: Set out warning devices to keep other vehicles from running into the accident scene.
questions.answer3: Leave your vehicle, do nothing, and get to higher ground.
questions.answer4: Have a drink to calm your nerves.
questions.explanation: Unless you have been injured, it is your responsibility to ensure that others can see your vehicle at the accident scene. Set out your warning devices as quickly as possible to avoid further accidents such as a pile-up.

questions.question: Each of the following tasks is involved in starting the engine and inspecting the cab, EXCEPT
questions.answer3: starting the engine, then listening for unusual noises.
questions.answer4: starting the engine, then putting the gearshift in neutral.
questions.explanation: Please note that the question says "EXCEPT." When performing this part of the inspection, start the engine after you have put the gearshift in neutral. Then listen for any unusual noises. Once you perform the engine check, you will check all your gauges and controls, such as the air pressure gauge and transmission controls.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: All of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide to the left, a driver may try to pass you on your right while you are turning. Instead, make the right turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This will deny drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: When evaluating hoses with the instructor during your pre-trip examination, seek for
questions.answer3: frays in the water pump belt.
questions.answer4: a low windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: When you inspect hoses during your pre-trip test, you need to look for signs of leaks, such as puddles on the ground or fluids that are dripping on the underside of the engine or transmission. Also check the hoses for cracks or other problems.

questions.question: In which of the following two situations should you downshift?
questions.answer1: Starting down a hill and entering a curve
questions.answer2: Starting up a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer3: Starting down a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer4: Starting up a hill and entering a curve
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill lets you take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required, which is usually lower than the gear required to climb the hill. Downshifting before a curve improves stability and helps you get the power you will need to accelerate out of the turn.

questions.question: It has just reached freezing. Which of the following areas may be slippery?
questions.answer3: A wet-looking road
questions.explanation: Once the temperature drops to freezing, some sections of road will start to freeze before others. The first to freeze will be shaded areas and bridges. If the road appears wet, it may be covered in black ice, a thin layer of slippery ice through which you can see the road.

questions.question: Why is it important to use a helper when backing?
questions.answer2: Because people feel more comfortable when you do
questions.answer3: Because you are providing a job for someone else
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: It is important to use a helper when you are backing because you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals for "Go" and (most importantly) "Stop."

questions.question: You should put the starter switch key into your pocket while you perform the pre-trip inspection because
questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.
questions.answer3: it could damage the starting mechanism.
questions.answer4: any of the above could occur.
questions.explanation: While you are performing the pre-trip inspection, you do not want someone (such as a co-driver) who is unaware of your location to start your vehicle and accidentally injure you.

questions.question: Before transporting a sealed load, you must inspect
questions.answer1: a small sample of whatever is inside.
questions.answer2: a picture of whatever is inside.
questions.answer3: that you don't exceed gross weight or axle weight limits.
questions.explanation: While you cannot actually inspect sealed loads, it's still your responsibility to ensure that you do not exceed your axle weight limits or gross weight restrictions, so check them both.

questions.question: What is the gross vehicle weight (GVW)?
questions.answer1: A vehicle's maximum weight rating, specified by its manufacturer
questions.answer2: The total weight of the vehicle, towed vehicles, and the load
questions.answer3: The total weight of a single vehicle and its load
questions.explanation: GVW is the simplest of the vehicle weight terms, defined as the weight of just a single vehicle and the load that it is carrying.

questions.question: On which of the following types of fires should you NOT use a B:C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Wood
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher should not be used on burning materials that you can use ordinary water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: To maintain alertness on your trips, you should
questions.answer1: schedule your trips for the daytime hours.
questions.answer3: avoid medications that cause drowsiness.
questions.explanation: Sleep debt is a dangerous condition in which missing sleep adds up until you risk falling asleep at the wheel unless you get some rest. People are often surprised that getting less than 6 hours of sleep per night triples the risk of an accident. At least 15% of heavy truck crashes are believed to involve driver fatigue. Before a trip, you should get adequate sleep (adults need 8 to 9 hours to maintain alertness); prepare your route carefully to identify total distance, stopping points, and other logistical considerations; schedule trips for the hours during which you are normally awake, not the middle of the night; drive with a passenger; avoid medications that cause drowsiness; consult your physician if you suffer from daytime sleepiness, have difficulty sleeping at night, or take frequent naps; and incorporate exercise into your daily life to give yourself more energy.

questions.question: How often do you have to pull over to inspect your goods while driving?
questions.answer3: Every three hours or 150 miles

questions.question: The most significant hand gesture on which you and your assistance should both agree is
questions.answer3: Stop.
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: Which of the following are governed by Jacob's Law?
questions.answer1: Requirements for vehicles that transport students to or from school
questions.answer2: The way that vehicles must approach railroad crossings
questions.answer3: The penalties for driving under the influence (DUI) for a second time
questions.answer4: The rules for distinguishing excepted commerce from non-excepted commerce
questions.explanation: Jacob's Law stipulates that any vehicle that regularly transports students to or from school must meet all federal safety standards for school buses. Plus, you must have a CDL with a passenger endorsement to drive any such vehicle that can transport 16 or more persons including yourself. The law was named after Jacob Strebler, who was killed in 1994 at the age of six when the side of the school van in which he was riding was hit by a truck. The van did not meet federal school bus standards for side-impact protection.

questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulation 49 CFR 392.22.
