questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to brake to a stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your braking distance increases by roughly the square of the speed increase – to about four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 184 feet.

questions.question: If you have a flat tire, you should not do which of the following?
questions.answer3: Brake hard and immediately.
questions.answer4: Be aware that a tire has failed.
questions.explanation: Hard braking could cause your vehicle to go out of control, so brake gently only after the vehicle has slowed down and you have regained control.

questions.question: What is a common cause of tire fires?
questions.answer3: Cold tires
questions.explanation: Underinflated tires and dual tires that touch are the most common causes of tire fires.

questions.question: Which of the following retarder assertions is true?
questions.answer1: Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for braking.
questions.answer2: When your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarder may cause them to skid.
questions.answer3: You should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow-covered.
questions.answer4: All of the above statements are correct.
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should always turn off your retarders in poor weather.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the basic shifting method?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, press the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, press the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. questions.question: Why should you cover your cargo?
questions.answer1: To protect individuals from any spilled cargo
questions.answer2: To protect your cargo from bad weather
questions.answer3: Because many states require it
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: There are several reasons to cover your cargo, including protecting other people and the cargo itself. In addition, it will help you comply with regulations in several states.

questions.question: If you are convicted of a second DUI offense in either a CMV or your personal vehicle, how long will you lose your CDL driving privileges?
questions.answer3: Life
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of DUI for a second time, you will lose your CDL privileges for life. questions.explanation: The gear box is an integral part of the steering system. The other three choices are parts of the suspension system.

questions.question: What is the best method for calculating the number of seconds of following distance you have?
questions.answer1: Wait until the vehicle ahead of you passes a shadow or landmark. Then count the seconds until you reach it.
questions.answer2: Get 1/4 closer to the vehicle in front of you, then back off again. Multiply how long this took you by four to give the following distance.
questions.answer3: Use the stopwatch on your cell phone to determine how long it takes you to reach a mile marker after the vehicle in front of you has passed it.
questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to reach some stationary object after the vehicle in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here either don't work or involve dangerous distractions. Note that you should increase your following distance in heavy traffic, in bad weather, with heavy vehicles, or at higher speeds.

questions.question: To transport cargo safely, which of the following are you NOT responsible for?
questions.answer1: Ensuring the safety of the cargo
questions.answer3: Making sure that cargo is properly secured
questions.answer4: Ensuring the freshness of sealed cargo
questions.explanation: You are not responsible for the state of sealed cargo, nor can you inspect it. You are only responsible for the safety of the cargo, ensuring that it is balanced, secured, and not overloaded, and does not get in the way of emergency equipment.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are
questions.answer1: signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo.
questions.answer2: signs on the inside of the vehicle that remind the driver of what he or she is carrying.
questions.answer3: signs that help tax collectors determine how much to tax a hazardous cargo.
questions.answer4: signs that warn the public to stay at least 1,000 feet from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are four regulated signs on the outside of the vehicle that identify the hazard class of the cargo for those who need to know, such as emergency service personnel or those who load and unload cargo.

questions.question: When you start to drive down a steep downgrade, which of the following should influence your choice of speed?
questions.answer1: The total weight of your vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: When choosing a safe speed for driving down a steep downgrade, consider its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: How do you get started without rolling backwards?
questions.answer1: Set the parking brake whenever necessary.
questions.answer2: Engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake.
questions.answer3: Apply the trailer brake hand valve.
questions.explanation: If you have a manual transmission vehicle, partly engage the clutch before you take your right foot off the brake. Set the parking brake whenever necessary to keep from rolling back. Release the parking brake only when you have applied enough engine power to keep from rolling back. On a tractor-trailer equipped with a trailer brake hand valve, the hand valve can be applied to keep from rolling back.

questions.question: How speed you should reduce when you drive on wet roads?
questions.answer3: one-third.
questions.explanation: When a road is wet, stopping distance is increased, and you should reduce your speed by one-third. On snow, slow to one-half your usual speed. On icy roads, slow to a crawl and stop driving as soon as you can do so safely.

questions.question: If the engine is not overheated, is it completely safe to remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer3: Yes, as long as there is no overflow.
questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.
questions.explanation: It is not enough for the engine not to be overheated. The cooling system must cool completely before you attempt to remove the radiator cap. Even then, you should be very careful because there may still be tremendous pressure and damaging steam and fluids.

questions.question: Do empty trucks have the best braking?
questions.answer3: Yes, but only on wet surfaces.
questions.answer4: Yes, but only if the trucks are newer than 1998.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have longer stopping distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: An antilock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: keep your wheels from locking when you brake hard.
questions.explanation: ABS kicks in only to keep the wheels from locking, which could cause a skid. ABS does not change the way you normally brake the rest of the time. It is not a substitute for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, or regular maintenance.

questions.question: You should do the following to assist you stay aware and safe while driving:
questions.answer1: avoid medications that can cause drowsiness.
questions.answer2: drink coffee if you get drowsy.
questions.answer3: roll down your windows to get fresh air.
questions.answer4: have a whiskey to brace yourself.
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, some prescription and over-the-counter medications can cause drowsiness, sedation, or impaired coordination, which make them dangerous for CMV operators. If you are unsure about the effects of a particular medication, check the warning label or ask your pharmacist or doctor. Never try to fight drowsiness with coffee, fresh air, or especially alcohol. The only "cure" for being tired is sleeping until you are rested.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: Your body breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate. Typically, this is one standard drink per hour, where one standard drink equals 1.5 ounces of hard liquor, 5 ounces of wine, or one 12-ounce can of beer. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: What can you do at an accident scene to help avoid another accident?
questions.answer1: Stay in your vehicle and do nothing until help arrives.
questions.answer2: Set out warning devices to keep other vehicles from running into the accident scene.
questions.answer3: Leave your vehicle, do nothing, and get to higher ground.
questions.answer4: Have a drink to calm your nerves.
questions.explanation: Unless you have been injured, it is your responsibility to ensure that others can see your vehicle at the accident scene. Set out your warning devices as quickly as possible to avoid further accidents such as a pile-up.

questions.question: Each of the following tasks is involved in starting the engine and inspecting the cab, EXCEPT
questions.answer3: starting the engine, then listening for unusual noises.
questions.answer4: starting the engine, then putting the gearshift in neutral.
questions.explanation: Please note that the question says "EXCEPT." When performing this part of the inspection, start the engine after you have put the gearshift in neutral. Then listen for any unusual noises. Once you perform the engine check, you will check all your gauges and controls, such as the air pressure gauge and transmission controls.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: All of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide to the left, a driver may try to pass you on your right while you are turning. Instead, make the right turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This will deny drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: When evaluating hoses with the instructor during your pre-trip examination, seek for
questions.answer3: frays in the water pump belt.
questions.answer4: a low windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: When you inspect hoses during your pre-trip test, you need to look for signs of leaks, such as puddles on the ground or fluids that are dripping on the underside of the engine or transmission. Also check the hoses for cracks or other problems.

questions.question: In which of the following two situations should you downshift?
questions.answer1: Starting down a hill and entering a curve
questions.answer2: Starting up a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer3: Starting down a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer4: Starting up a hill and entering a curve
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill lets you take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required, which is usually lower than the gear required to climb the hill. Downshifting before a curve improves stability and helps you get the power you will need to accelerate out of the turn.

questions.question: It has just reached freezing. Which of the following areas may be slippery?
questions.answer3: A wet-looking road
questions.explanation: Once the temperature drops to freezing, some sections of road will start to freeze before others. The first to freeze will be shaded areas and bridges. If the road appears wet, it may be covered in black ice, a thin layer of slippery ice through which you can see the road.

questions.question: Why is it important to use a helper when backing?
questions.answer2: Because people feel more comfortable when you do
questions.answer3: Because you are providing a job for someone else
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: It is important to use a helper when you are backing because you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals for "Go" and (most importantly) "Stop."

questions.question: You should put the starter switch key into your pocket while you perform the pre-trip inspection because
questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.
questions.answer3: it could damage the starting mechanism.
questions.answer4: any of the above could occur.
questions.explanation: While you are performing the pre-trip inspection, you do not want someone (such as a co-driver) who is unaware of your location to start your vehicle and accidentally injure you.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to brake to a stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your braking distance increases by roughly the square of the speed increase – to about four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 148 feet.

questions.question: Before transporting a sealed load, you must inspect
questions.answer1: a small sample of whatever is inside.
questions.answer2: a picture of whatever is inside.
questions.answer3: that you don't exceed gross weight or axle weight limits.
questions.explanation: While you cannot actually inspect sealed loads, it's still your responsibility to ensure that you do not exceed your axle weight limits or gross weight restrictions, so check them both.

questions.question: The most significant hand gesture on which you and your assistance should both agree is
questions.answer3: “Stop.”
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: What is the gross vehicle weight (GVW)?
questions.answer1: A vehicle's maximum weight rating, specified by its manufacturer
questions.answer2: The total weight of the vehicle, towed vehicles, and the load
questions.answer3: The total weight of a single vehicle and its load
questions.explanation: GVW is the simplest of the vehicle weight terms, defined as the weight of just a single vehicle and the load that it is carrying.

questions.question: On which of the following types of fires should you NOT use a B:C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Wood
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher should not be used on burning materials that you can use ordinary water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: To maintain alertness on your trips, you should
questions.answer1: schedule your trips for the daytime hours.
questions.answer3: avoid medications that cause drowsiness.
questions.explanation: Sleep debt is a dangerous condition in which missing sleep adds up until you risk falling asleep at the wheel unless you get some rest. People are often surprised that getting less than 6 hours of sleep per night triples the risk of an accident. At least 15% of heavy truck crashes are believed to involve driver fatigue. Before a trip, you should get adequate sleep (adults need 8 to 9 hours to maintain alertness); prepare your route carefully to identify total distance, stopping points, and other logistical considerations; schedule trips for the hours during which you are normally awake, not the middle of the night; drive with a passenger; avoid medications that cause drowsiness; consult your physician if you suffer from daytime sleepiness, have difficulty sleeping at night, or take frequent naps; and incorporate exercise into your daily life to give yourself more energy.

questions.question: To transport cargo to or from his or her farm, a farmer does NOT need a CDL to drive a farm vehicle within ______ miles of the farm.
questions.explanation: You do not need a CDL to transport farm-related cargo to or from your farm within a 150-mile radius of your farm.

questions.question: How often do you have to pull over to inspect your goods while driving?
questions.answer3: Every three hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, the South Dakota Commercial Driver License Manual states that you should check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your trip and then every 3 hours or 150 miles, as well as after each break you take.

questions.question: Which lights should you use the most when driving at night?
questions.answer3: Emergency flashers
questions.explanation: While driving at night, you should use your high beams to see farther as long as it is safe and legal and you will not blind any other drivers. Section 2.11.5 of the South Dakota Commercial Driver License Manual recommends that you dim your headlights whenever you are within 500 feet of another vehicle.

questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulation 49 CFR 392.22. This regulation also specifies where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as undivided two-way roads and curves. (These situations are also covered in section 2.5.2 of the South Dakota Commercial Driver License Manual.)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four fundamental abilities required to operate a commercial motor vehicle?
questions.answer3: First-aid certification
questions.explanation: As described in detail in section 2.2 of the South Dakota Commercial Driver License Manual, the four basic skills for safe operation of a commercial motor vehicle are accelerating, steering, stopping, and backing safely. While first-aid certification might come in handy at some point in your career, it is not one of the four basic skills.

questions.question: If you have a flat tire, you should not do which of the following?
questions.answer3: Brake hard and immediately.
questions.answer4: Be aware that a tire has failed.
questions.explanation: Hard braking could cause your vehicle to go out of control, so brake gently only after the vehicle has slowed down and you have regained control.

questions.question: What is a common cause of tire fires?
questions.answer3: Cold tires
questions.explanation: Underinflated tires and dual tires that touch are the most common causes of tire fires.

questions.question: Which of the following retarder assertions is true?
questions.answer1: Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for braking.
questions.answer2: When your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarder may cause them to skid.
questions.answer3: You should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow-covered.
questions.answer4: All of the above statements are correct.
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should always turn off your retarders in poor weather.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the basic shifting method?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, press the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, press the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: Why should you cover your cargo?
questions.answer1: To protect individuals from any spilled cargo
questions.answer2: To protect your cargo from bad weather
questions.answer3: Because many states require it
questions.answer4: For all of the above reasons
questions.explanation: There are several reasons to cover your cargo, including protecting other people and the cargo itself. In addition, it will help you comply with regulations in several states.

questions.question: If you are convicted of a second DUI offense in either a CMV or your personal vehicle, how long will you lose your CDL driving privileges?
questions.answer3: Life
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of DUI for a second time, you will lose your CDL privileges for life. While you are driving a CMV, a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.04% or above qualifies as DUI. Your first offense is a wake-up call and a chance to get help, but your second offense is going to mean unemployment. If you get a DUI, seek help before you lose your salary and your future.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.
questions.answer3: Call the police from your cell phone if you can do it safely.
questions.explanation: If an aggressive driver is trying to confront you, do not give the person the confrontation that he or she seeks. Instead, seek police, peace, and safety.

questions.question: How many tie-downs are required for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tie-down per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two per load, regardless of the length. So for 20 feet, you should have two tie-downs.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a key steering system component?
questions.answer3: Leaf spring
questions.explanation: The tie rod, gear box, and steering shaft are parts of the steering system. A leaf spring is part of the suspension system.

questions.question: What is the main goal of a vehicle inspection?
questions.answer2: To make sure your vehicle is safe
questions.answer3: To check the cleanliness of your vehicle
questions.answer4: To make sure the paint is not chipped
questions.explanation: The main purpose of a vehicle inspection is to determine whether your vehicle is safe enough to drive. This includes your safety and that of other road users. In addition, discovering defects during a vehicle inspection can help avert a costly or even dangerous breakdown on the road.

questions.question: What is the best way to check what is going on behind and to the sides of your vehicle?
questions.answer1: Stop every 50 miles and look around.
questions.answer3: Check your reflection in other vehicles.
questions.answer4: Turn your head to check your blind spots.
questions.explanation: To know what's going on behind and to the sides of your vehicle, check your mirrors regularly while you drive, and check them even more often in special situations. Before you start to drive, adjust your mirrors so that each mirror shows a different part of your vehicle.

questions.question: How do you test a vehicle's hydraulic brakes for leaks?
questions.answer1: Pump the brakes 3 times. Then apply firm pressure for 5 seconds.
questions.answer2: Pump the brakes 5 times. Then apply firm pressure for 3 seconds.
questions.answer3: Pump the brakes 3 times. Then apply firm pressure for 10 seconds.
questions.answer4: Apply firm pressure for 5 seconds. Then pump the brakes 3 times.
questions.explanation: To test a vehicle equipped with hydraulic brakes for leaks in the brakes, first pump the brakes three times. Next, apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. If it moves, the brakes may have a leak or some other problem.

questions.question: Why should you use a helper when you are backing?
questions.answer1: Because every truck has blind spots
questions.answer2: To make sure you don't damage your truck
questions.answer3: Because it's the law
questions.answer4: To check your style of driving
questions.explanation: You should use a helper when you are backing because you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals for "Go" and (most importantly) "Stop."

questions.question: Total stopping distance equals
questions.answer2: perception distance + reaction distance + braking distance.
questions.answer3: perception distance + reaction distance.
questions.answer4: reaction distance + braking distance + signal distance.
questions.explanation: Total stopping distance is the sum of your perception distance (how far the vehicle goes from when you see the hazard until your brain processes it), reaction distance (how far the vehicle goes from when your brain orders your foot to take action until your foot actually starts to brake), and braking distance (how far the vehicle continues to travel once you apply the brake).

questions.question: Which of the following are safe ways to communicate your presence?
questions.answer1: Tapping your horn when it's legal and you're about to pass
questions.answer2: Flashing your headlights at night when you're about to pass
questions.answer3: Using your headlights in bad weather
questions.explanation: There are several ways to safely communicate your presence and intentions. When you're about to pass, lightly tap your horn if it is legal to do so. At night, flash your headlights from low beam to high beam and back again. Use your headlights at night and whenever visibility is difficult, such as in bad weather. Whenever you pull off the road and stop, turn on your four-way emergency flashers. This is especially important at night.

questions.question: If your brakes get wet, they may
questions.answer3: rust immediately.
questions.explanation: If your brakes get wet, they may apply unevenly, work weakly, or grab, any of which can be dangerous. Try to maintain light pressure on the brakes for a short distance to heat them up and dry them out.

questions.question: You will lose your CDL for at least 60 days if you are convicted of two serious traffic violations involving a commercial motor vehicle (CMV) within a three-year period. Such violations include which of the following?
questions.answer1: Speeding at 15 mph or more above the speed limit
questions.answer3: Texting on a handheld cell phone
questions.explanation: You will lose your CDL for at least 60 days if you are convicted of two serious traffic violations involving a CMV within a three-year period. For three serious traffic violations within a three-year period, you will lose your CDL for at least 120 days. Such violations include speeding at 15 mph or more above the speed limit, driving recklessly, making improper or erratic lane changes, tailgating, and (in states such as Tennessee) texting on a handheld cell phone.

questions.question: The minimum tire tread depth for all tires except the front tires is
questions.answer3: 8/32 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: Which of the following are parts of the suspension system?
questions.answer3: Lock ring
questions.explanation: Bearing plates and leaf springs are parts of the suspension system that can become worn from driving over bumps. The pitman arm is part of the steering system, and lock rings help keep the wheels safe.

questions.question: Always try to back toward the driver's side because
questions.answer1: you can see better, watching the vehicle's rear from the side window.
questions.answer2: your truck will probably pull toward the driver's side.
questions.answer3: there are always more hazards on the passenger side.
questions.answer4: all of the above are true.
questions.explanation: You should always back toward the driver's side even if you have to go around the block to put your vehicle in this position. By backing toward the driver's side, you will be able to see things much more easily. For example, you can keep an eye on the vehicle's rear by viewing it from your side window. If your truck pulls in either direction, it needs service. There may be hazards on either side of your vehicle, of course.

questions.question: If your vehicle has an automatic transmission, when should you select a low range?
questions.answer1: If you start to get drowsy
questions.answer2: When you're about to enter a downgrade
questions.answer3: If you feel that you're driving too fast
questions.answer4: When you're about to enter an upgrade
questions.explanation: If you keep applying the brakes to control your speed on a steep descent, the brakes will fade (lose their effectiveness). Instead, if your vehicle has an automatic transmission, select a low range that prevents the transmission from shifting up beyond the selected gear. This will generate a braking effect to slow the vehicle, known as engine braking. The lower the gear, the greater the engine braking effect. Apply the brakes only when engine braking is insufficient or you want to stop.

questions.question: If you have to stop on a one-way or divided roadway, where should you put your warning devices?
questions.answer1: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulation 49 CFR 392.22. This regulation also specifies where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as undivided two-way roads and curves. (These situations are also covered in section 2.5.2 of the Tennessee Commercial Driver License Manual.)

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should do all of the following EXCEPT
questions.answer3: avoid tricks such as flashing your brake lights.
questions.explanation: Don't try to speed up to outdistance or appease a tailgater. No speed is too fast for some tailgaters. Instead, increase your following distance and if possible, move into another lane to let the tailgater pass.

questions.question: What are the main differences between aggressive driving and road rage?
questions.answer3: Intent to do harm
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is driving in a selfish or pushy manner, which is dangerous enough. Road rage is even worse: intentionally driving to harm someone or physically assaulting someone in his or her vehicle.

questions.question: When you're about to start down a steep downgrade, what should you do?
questions.answer3: Release the brakes.
questions.explanation: When you're about to start down a steep downgrade, shift into a low gear and use engine braking to slow your vehicle. Don't try to downshift after your speed has already built up. You will not be able to shift into a lower gear. You may not even be able to get back into any gear and all engine braking effect will be lost.

questions.question: How many reflective warning triangles must you carry with you for emergencies?
questions.explanation: Your truck's emergency equipment must include warning devices such as three reflective red triangles, three liquid burning flares, or six fusees.

questions.question: Which of the following should you check during your trip?
questions.answer3: Pressure gauges
questions.explanation: During your trip, you should be watching a number of things, such as your gauges, instruments, lights, tires, and mirrors. Also keep an eye on your cargo and its security, with or without a cover. Use several of your senses – sight, hearing, and smell – to detect possible trouble.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels and any visible evidence of cracks or leaks.

questions.question: Your emergency kit does NOT need to include
questions.answer3: a fire extinguisher.
questions.explanation: While a jacket might keep you comfortable, it is not a required part of your emergency kit. You must have a working fire extinguisher, warning devices such as flares or reflective triangles, and spare electrical fuses (unless your vehicle has circuit breakers).

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you
questions.answer1: avoid using your cell phone until you reach your destination.
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in the first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: eat, drink, and smoke only on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no other vehicles around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. Avoid using your cell phone until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: Letting the air out of hot tires
questions.answer1: is a good idea because the extra pressure will be relieved.
questions.answer2: is a bad idea because when the tires cool off, the pressure will be too low.
questions.answer3: will have no effect at all.
questions.answer4: will cool them down. You will be able to continue your trip sooner.
questions.explanation: When tires get hot, the air pressure increases. However, relieving that extra pressure will leave the air pressure too low when the tires cool again, and then the tires may catch fire or blow out. If your tires are too hot to touch, stop until they have cooled down.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an antilock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: What is the definition of a hazard?
questions.answer2: A road user or road condition that presents a possible danger
questions.answer3: Something you must stop for
questions.explanation: A hazard is a road user or road condition that presents a possible danger. A hazard is something that can go wrong but shouldn't if you've been vigilant.

questions.question: How long does it take a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double railroad track?
questions.answer3: More than 30 seconds
questions.explanation: You can expect it to take more than 15 seconds for a typical tractor-trailer to clear a double track and at least 14 seconds to clear a single track.

questions.question: To transport cargo safely, which of the following are you NOT responsible for?
questions.answer1: Ensuring the safety of the cargo
questions.answer3: Making sure that cargo is properly secured
questions.answer4: Ensuring the freshness of sealed cargo
questions.explanation: You are not responsible for the state of sealed cargo, nor can you inspect it. You are only responsible for the safety of the cargo, ensuring that it is balanced, secured, and not overloaded, and does not get in the way of emergency equipment.

questions.question: When you start to drive down a steep downgrade, which of the following should influence your choice of speed?
questions.answer1: The total weight of your vehicle and its cargo
questions.answer3: The road conditions
questions.explanation: When choosing a safe speed for driving down a steep downgrade, consider its steepness, its length, the road and weather conditions, and the weight of your vehicle and its cargo.

questions.question: How do you get started without rolling backwards?
questions.answer1: Set the parking brake whenever necessary.
questions.answer2: Engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake.
questions.answer3: Apply the trailer brake hand valve.
questions.explanation: If you have a manual transmission vehicle, partly engage the clutch before you take your right foot off the brake. Set the parking brake whenever necessary to keep from rolling back. Release the parking brake only when you have applied enough engine power to keep from rolling back. On a tractor-trailer equipped with a trailer brake hand valve, the hand valve can be applied to keep from rolling back.

questions.question: If the engine is not overheated, is it completely safe to remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer3: Yes, as long as there is no overflow.
questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.
questions.explanation: It is not enough for the engine not to be overheated. The cooling system must cool completely before you attempt to remove the radiator cap. Even then, you should be very careful because there may still be tremendous pressure and damaging steam and fluids.

questions.question: Do empty trucks have the best braking?
questions.answer3: Yes, but only on wet surfaces.
questions.answer4: Yes, but only if the trucks are newer than 1998.
questions.explanation: Trucks brake best when they are used as they were designed: to carry a properly balanced load. Empty trucks actually have longer stopping distances than loaded trucks because they have less traction.

questions.question: How many tiedowns are required for a 20-foot load?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tiedown per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two per load, regardless of the length. So for 20 feet, you should have two tiedowns.

questions.question: An antilock braking system (ABS) will
questions.answer3: shorten your stopping distance.
questions.answer4: keep your wheels from locking when you brake hard.
questions.explanation: ABS kicks in only to keep the wheels from locking, which could cause a skid. ABS does not change the way you normally brake the rest of the time. It is not a substitute for careful braking, defensive driving, good brakes, or regular maintenance.

questions.question: What will help a drunk sober up?
questions.answer3: Time
questions.explanation: Your body breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate. Typically, this is one standard drink per hour, where one standard drink equals 1.5 ounces of hard liquor, 5 ounces of wine, or one 12-ounce can of beer. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely to cause a vehicle fire?
questions.answer1: Driver smoking in a rest area
questions.answer3: Spilled fuel cleaned up quickly and properly
questions.explanation: Smoking, flammable cargo, and spilled fuel are potentially dangerous. Properly managed, however, they should not start a fire except under special circumstances such as a short circuit or loose connection.

questions.question: What might happen if you swing wide to the left before you turn right?
questions.answer1: Someone might try to pass you on your left.
questions.answer2: Someone might try to pass you on your right.
questions.answer3: You might damage your leaf springs.
questions.answer4: All of the above might happen.
questions.explanation: If you swing wide to the left, a driver may try to pass you on your right while you are turning. Instead, make the right turn with the rear of your vehicle as close to the curb as possible and turn wide as you complete the turn. This will deny drivers room on the right to try to pass you.

questions.question: In which of the following two situations should you downshift?
questions.answer1: Starting down a hill and entering a curve
questions.answer2: Starting up a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer3: Starting down a hill and finishing a curve
questions.answer4: Starting up a hill and entering a curve
questions.explanation: Downshifting before starting down a hill lets you take advantage of engine braking. You should downshift to the gear required, which is usually lower than the gear required to climb the hill. Downshifting before a curve improves stability and helps you get the power you will need to accelerate out of the turn.

questions.question: It has just reached freezing. Which of the following areas may be slippery?
questions.answer3: A wet-looking road
questions.explanation: Once the temperature drops to freezing, some sections of road will start to freeze before others. The first to freeze will be shaded areas and bridges. If the road appears wet, it may be covered in black ice, a thin layer of slippery ice through which you can see the road.

questions.question: You should put the starter switch key into your pocket while you perform the pre-trip inspection because
questions.answer2: someone could start and move the truck.
questions.answer3: it could damage the starting mechanism.
questions.answer4: any of the above could occur.
questions.explanation: While you are performing the pre-trip inspection, you do not want someone (such as a co-driver) who is unaware of your location to start your vehicle and accidentally injure you.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to brake to a stop?
questions.answer3: Twice as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your braking distance increases by roughly the square of the speed increase – to about four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 148 feet.

questions.question: The most significant hand gesture on which you and your assistance should both agree is
questions.answer3: “Stop.”
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, once an accident happens, you can't take it back. That's why it's absolutely essential for you and your helper to have a clear hand signal for "Stop." That way, you'll be able to quickly stop what you are doing before an accident can occur.

questions.question: On which of the following types of fires should you NOT use a B:C fire extinguisher?
questions.answer3: Wood
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher should not be used on burning materials that you can use ordinary water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: If you feel drowsy while driving, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Open the windows for some fresh air.
questions.answer3: Pull off the road and get some sleep.
questions.explanation: If you are drowsy, cold air, fresh air, or caffeinated beverages may make you feel more alert only momentarily. The only real solution is to get off the road as soon as possible and get some real rest.

questions.question: Which of the following might get stuck at a raised railroad crossing?
questions.answer3: Lowboy
questions.explanation: The two types of combination vehicles most likely to get stuck at a raised railroad crossing are low-slung units (car carriers, lowboys, moving vans, etc.) and single-axle tractors that are pulling a long trailer with its landing gear set to accommodate a tandem-axle tractor. Be very careful when driving such vehicles at railroad crossings.

questions.question: How many hours of sleep per night does the average adult need?
questions.answer3: 8 to 9 hours
questions.explanation: Sleep debt is a dangerous condition in which missing sleep adds up until you risk falling asleep at the wheel unless you get some rest. Getting less than six hours of sleep per night triples the risk of an accident. At least 15% of heavy truck crashes are believed to involve driver fatigue. Before a trip, you should get adequate sleep. The average person needs seven or eight hours of sleep every 24 hours to maintain alertness.

questions.question: What is the best method for calculating the number of seconds of following distance you have?
questions.answer1: Wait until the vehicle ahead of you passes a shadow or landmark. Then count the seconds until you reach it.
questions.answer2: Get 1/4 closer to the vehicle in front of you, then back off again. Multiply how long this took you by four to give the following distance.
questions.answer3: Use the stopwatch on your cell phone to determine how long it takes you to reach a mile marker after the vehicle in front of you has passed it.
questions.answer4: Send a text message to a friend to text you back in ten seconds. See how far you have traveled in that time.
questions.explanation: Count how many seconds it takes you to reach some stationary object after the vehicle in front of you has passed it. You can count seconds as follows: "One-thousand-and-one, one-thousand-and-two,..." The other three choices here either will not work or involve dangerous distractions. Note that you should increase your following distance in heavy traffic, in bad weather, with heavy vehicles, or at higher speeds.

questions.question: If you are traveling at 55 mph in a 30-foot vehicle, you should leave how many seconds of following distance?
questions.answer3: 3 seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling at or above 40 mph. Therefore, for a 30-foot vehicle traveling at 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: Which of the following retarder assertions is true?
questions.answer1: Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for braking.
questions.answer2: When your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarder may cause them to skid.
questions.answer3: You should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow-covered.
questions.answer4: All of the above statements are correct.
questions.explanation: While retarders can help reduce the need for braking, they can make a skid more likely in inclement weather or whenever your wheels have poor traction. Therefore, you should always turn off your retarders in poor weather.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the basic shifting method?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, press the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, press the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.
questions.answer3: Call the police from your cell phone if you can do it safely.
questions.explanation: If an aggressive driver is trying to confront you, do not give the person the confrontation that he or she seeks. Instead, seek police, peace, and safety.

questions.question: If you are traveling at 55 mph in a 30-foot vehicle, you should leave how many seconds of following distance?
questions.answer3: 7 seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling above 40 mph. Therefore, for a 30-foot vehicle traveling at 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: If you are stopped by the police and refuse to submit to a chemical test for drugs or alcohol,
questions.answer1: you will lose your CDL for at least one year.
questions.answer2: the police will let you off with a warning.
questions.answer3: you will receive a summons in the mail.
questions.answer4: the police will follow you for a mile to check whether you're able to drive safely.
questions.explanation: If you refuse to submit to chemical testing for drugs or alcohol, you will lose your CDL for at least one year unless you request a hearing and successfully argue your case.

questions.question: Which of these describes how you should use the brake pedal on a steep downhill grade?
questions.answer1: Apply stronger pressure as the vehicle goes downhill.
questions.answer3: Release the brake when you are 5 mph below your safe speed and let your speed come back up to your safe speed. Then repeat braking to 5 mph below your safe speed.
questions.answer4: Brake harder when you are 15 mph above your safe speed.
questions.explanation: The best technique for descending is to assess the slope and conditions and choose a safe speed. Once you reach this speed, gently brake until you are going 5 miles an hour slower, and then let your speed build up again. When you reach your safe speed, brake again, and so forth. This is much less likely overheat your brakes than trying to hold a set speed with the brakes permanently half on.

questions.question: Which lights should you use the most when driving at night?
questions.answer3: Emergency flashers
questions.explanation: While driving at night, you should use your high beams to see farther as long as it is safe and legal and you will not blind any other drivers. Section 2.11.5 of the Texas Commercial Motor Vehicle Drivers Handbook recommends that you dim your headlights whenever you are within 500 feet of another vehicle.

questions.question: You should look at least 12–15 seconds ahead. In city driving, 12–15 seconds is
questions.answer3: about one block.
questions.explanation: At the lower speeds typical of city driving, 12–15 seconds is about one city block. At highway speeds, it's about a quarter of a mile.

questions.question: If you drive at 55 mph rather than 65 mph, you can improve your fuel economy by as much as
questions.answer3: a gallon per trip.
questions.explanation: Tractor-trailers today average about 6.5 miles per gallon of diesel fuel. Driving at 55 mph rather than 65 mph can increase fuel economy by as much as one mile per gallon. That works out to a saving of about two gallons of fuel for every 100 miles traveled. Over the course of a year of driving, that can add up to significant savings.

questions.question: In Texas, the mud flaps on a truck or trailer must reach
questions.answer3: within 6 inches of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Currently, there are no federal regulations on the use of splash guards (mud flaps). Each state is free to create its own regulations. In Texas, the mud flaps on a truck or trailer must reach within 8 inches of the roadway.

questions.question: In Texas, which of the following must come to a complete stop at a rural railroad crossing?
questions.answer3: Trucks carrying explosives
questions.explanation: In Texas, heavy equipment (e.g., bulldozers, steam shovels, steamrollers) and trucks carrying explosives must stop at all railroad crossings. When carrying passengers, school buses and transit or coach buses must stop at all railroad crossings outside business or residential districts. Know the regulations on whether your type of vehicle must stop at railroad crossings. A violation can result in disqualification for at least 60 days.

questions.question: Which of the following should you do inside the cab during your pre-trip inspection?
questions.answer2: Check that you have all your required papers.
questions.answer3: Secure all loose items.
questions.explanation: In the last part of Step 6 of the seven-step pre-trip inspection, get in the cab and make sure it's ready. Turn off any unnecessary lights, check that you have all your required papers, and secure loose items. Then start your engine.

questions.question: If you double your speed, how much more distance will it take to brake to a stop?
questions.answer3: Three times as much
questions.explanation: When you double your speed, your braking distance increases by roughly the square of the speed increase – to about four times as much as before. For example, increasing your speed from 15 to 30 mph will increase your stopping distance from 46 to 148 feet.

questions.question: After your first stop, how often must you stop to check if your cargo is secure?
questions.answer3: Every 3 hours or 150 miles
questions.explanation: While the rules vary by jurisdiction, the Texas Commercial Motor Vehicle Drivers Handbook states that you should check your cargo within the first 50 miles of your trip and then every 3 hours or 150 miles, as well as after each break you take.

questions.question: Streaks of rust on a lug nut are signs that
questions.answer3: it's frozen or stuck.
questions.explanation: Shiny threads or streaks or trails of rust are signs that the lug nut is loose. If so, use a manual torque wrench to tighten the lug nut to the recommended torque for your vehicle.

questions.question: When passing a motorcycle, keep in mind that
questions.answer1: it may be able to accelerate much faster than you can.
questions.answer3: your vehicle can drag a motorcycle off course.
questions.answer4: it can swerve more sharply than a car.
questions.explanation: Your large vehicle generates air suction that can pull the motorcycle two or three feet toward you, depending on the relative speed of the vehicles. For this reason, always leave at least six feet of space between your vehicle and the motorcycle.

questions.question: In Texas, when driving on a downgrade, you must not
questions.answer2: drive faster than 10 mph below the posted speed limit.
questions.answer3: coast downhill.
questions.answer4: sound your horn at a curve.
questions.explanation: Under Texas law, it is illegal for any motor vehicle to coast downhill with the transmission in neutral. It is also illegal for a bus, tractor, or truck to coast downhill with the clutch disengaged. [Texas TRANSP § 545.406]

questions.question: After you start the engine, the oil pressure should rise to normal within
questions.answer3: a mile’s drive.
questions.explanation: Once the engine starts, the oil pressure should rise to normal within seconds. If it doesn't, shut off the engine immediately and check the oil level. If you run the engine without oil, it will soon be damaged.

questions.question: If you are towing another vehicle, the tow connection must not be longer than
questions.answer3: 20 feet.
questions.explanation: When one vehicle is towing another, the tow connection must not be longer than 15 feet from one vehicle to the other.

questions.question: If you are pulling a trailer and a fire breaks out inside it, what should you do?
questions.answer1: Keep driving until you reach a service station.
questions.answer2: Pull off the road, get out of the vehicle and keep the trailer door closed.
questions.answer3: Pull of the road and put the fire out with a fire extinguisher.
questions.explanation: If a fire starts inside a trailer, pull off the road and park in an open area far away from anything that could catch fire. Keep the trailer's doors closed. Opening the doors would allow more oxygen to get to the fire, causing it to spread.

questions.question: Where should you place your warning devices if you must stop on a one-way road or divided highway at night?
questions.answer1: 100 feet, 200 feet, and 300 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer2: 20 feet, 50 feet, and 100 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer3: 50 feet, 100 feet, and 150 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.answer4: 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward approaching traffic
questions.explanation: This is required by Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulation 49 CFR 392.22. This regulation also specifies where to place warning devices on other types of roadways such as undivided two-way roads and curves. (These situations are also covered in section 2.5.2 of the Texas Commercial Motor Vehicle Drivers Handbook.) Note: In Texas, you may follow this procedure only at night. In the daytime, you must set out two red flags instead of these three warning devices. See section 14.2 of the Handbook for details. [Texas TRANSP § 547.502]

questions.question: If you are going through an underpass at which the road has been repaved recently,
questions.answer1: you can drive through it faster than you used to.
questions.answer2: you should slow down to check the new road surface.
questions.answer3: the repaving won't make any difference.
questions.answer4: the vertical clearance may be less than it used to be.
questions.explanation: Don't assume that the vertical clearances shown on signs at bridges and overpasses are correct. Repaving or packed snow may have reduced the clearances since the signs were posted.

questions.question: To avoid overloading bridges, a bridge formula restricts the axle weight for axles that
questions.answer3: are closer together.
questions.explanation: The axle weight is the maximum weight that an individual axle can support. When a vehicle's axles are relatively close together, a high axle weight risks overloading bridges and roadways. To avoid overloading bridges, a bridge formula is often used to specify a lower maximum axle weight for axles that are closer together. The US Department of Transportation uses such a bridge formula to establish the maximum axle weights on interstate highways.

questions.question: In Texas, if your load extends more than 4 feet beyond the rear of your vehicle, you must have
questions.answer1: a red flag on the end of the load in the daytime.
questions.answer2: a red light on the end of the load at night.
questions.answer3: a special permit.
questions.explanation: If your load extends more than four feet beyond the rear of your vehicle, you must do the following: (1) Obtain a special permit from the Texas Department of Transportation Permit Office. (2) Attach a 12-inch-square red flag to the end of your load when traveling during the day. (3) Attach a red light visible for 500 feet to the end of your load when traveling at night. However, there are a couple of exceptions to these requirements. Read sections 14.3 and 14.4 of the Texas Commercial Motor Vehicle Drivers Handbook for details.

questions.question: If you are found to be driving a commercial motor vehicle with your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) above zero but below 0.04%,
questions.answer1: you will be allowed to keep driving.
questions.answer2: you will have to pay a small fine if you're convicted.
questions.answer3: you will be ordered out of service for 24 hours.
questions.explanation: If you are found to be driving a commercial motor vehicle with any amount of alcohol in your blood, you will face a penalty. If your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is below 0.04%, you will be ordered out of service for 24 hours. If you are convicted of having a BAC of 0.04% or above, you will lose your CDL for at least one year if this was your first offense.

questions.question: In Texas, which of the following are you not allowed to transport in an open truck?
questions.answer3: Wood chips
questions.explanation: In Texas, you may not transport any loose material that is capable of blowing or spilling unless (a) the truck bed is completely enclosed on all sides and (b) either the load is completely enclosed or the top of the load is covered to prevent any of it from blowing or spilling.

questions.question: How many commercial driver licenses (CDLs) can you have in various states at the same time?
questions.answer3: Three
questions.explanation: To obtain a Texas CDL, you must be a legal resident of the state. Under federal regulation 49 CFR 383.21, you may hold only one CDL at a time. If you move to Texas from another state where you obtained a CDL, you must exchange your out-of-state CDL for a Texas CDL within 90 days of becoming a legal resident of Texas.

questions.question: Two of the most common causes of tire fires are?
questions.answer1: Underinflation and dual tires that touch
questions.answer2: Overinflation and dual tires that touch
questions.answer3: Mismatched tires and loose lug nuts
questions.answer4: Loose lug nuts and dual tires that touch
questions.explanation: Tires that overheat can catch fire. Underinflation causes increased flexing of the tire, which increases tire temperature. Dual tires that touch each other or other parts of the vehicle can overheat due to friction.

questions.question: What can you do to assist an accident victim who is bleeding profusely and there is no competent expert available?
questions.answer1: Nothing; wait for qualified professionals to arrive.
questions.answer2: Wind a tourniquet above the wound.
questions.answer3: Try to bandage the wound.
questions.answer4: Apply direct pressure to the wound.
questions.explanation: If there are no qualified professionals on the scene as yet, do what you can to help the injured until they arrive. To stop heavy bleeding, apply direct pressure to the wound until the bleeding stops. Use gauze from a first-aid kit, a piece of clothing, or even just your hand if necessary.

questions.question: What kind of warning devices should you use in Texas if you have to stop on the road or the shoulder of the road during the day?
questions.answer3: Your vehicle's four-way emergency flashers
questions.explanation: In Texas, the usual kinds of warning devices (flares, fusees, or reflective triangles) are to be used at night. If you must stop on the road or the shoulder in the daytime, set out red flags at two of the three places where you would set out flares, fusees, or triangles if it were nighttime. See section 14.2 of the Texas Commercial Motor Vehicle Drivers Handbook for details. [Texas TRANSP § 547.502]

questions.question: What can a drunken person do to get sober?
questions.answer3: Fresh air
questions.explanation: Your body breaks down alcohol at a predictable rate. Typically, this is one standard drink per hour, where one standard drink equals 1.5 ounces of hard liquor, 5 ounces of wine, or one 12-ounce can of beer. Neither coffee nor fresh air nor water can increase that rate. You need to wait until the alcohol has been broken down.

questions.question: In case of an emergency, how many reflective warning triangles should you have on hand?
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's emergency equipment must include warning devices such as three reflective red triangles, three liquid flares, or six fusees.

questions.question: What should you do if you have to drive off the road onto the shoulder to prevent colliding with another vehicle?
questions.answer2: Keep one set of wheels on the pavement.
questions.answer3: Stay on the shoulder until you've stopped.
questions.explanation: If you must drive off the roadway onto the shoulder, take several steps to drive safely on the looser surface of the shoulder. Let your vehicle slow itself down; don't brake until your speed is below 20 mph, and then only gently. Try to keep one set of your wheels on the pavement. If possible, don't return to the roadway until after your vehicle has stopped.

questions.question: Which of the following instances does it make sense to not use your horn?
questions.answer1: To alert another driver to your presence
questions.answer2: To express your annoyance at someone
questions.answer3: To alert another driver to a hazard
questions.answer4: To warn a pedestrian who may not have seen you
questions.explanation: Your horn should be used to warn others of possible danger. Sounding the horn to express annoyance or anger is a sign of aggressive driving.

questions.question: What should you do if dense fog reduces visibility to near zero?
questions.answer1: Pull off the road and stop.
questions.answer2: Speed up to get through it quicker.
questions.answer3: Slow down and use your high beams.
questions.answer4: Slow down and use your low beams and fog lights.
questions.explanation: Fog often causes accidents. In Texas in 2016, there were over two thousand crashes in fog, including 45 fatal crashes. When driving in fog, slow down, use your low-beam headlights and fog lights, and drive with extreme caution. However, if visibility is reduced to near zero, pull off the road into a truck stop or rest area and wait until visibility improves. Remember: If you can't see, you can't drive. ["Weather Conditions for Crashes," Texas Department of Transportation, http://ftp.dot.state.tx.us/pub/txdot-info/trf/crash_statistics/2016/23.pdf]

questions.question: What is the maximum combined weight of a single or combination vehicle in Texas?
questions.answer3: 70,000 pounds.
questions.explanation: In Texas, the maximum weight for a single or combination vehicle including its load is 80,000 pounds unless you obtain an oversized/overweight permit from the Texas Department of Transportation Permit Office. Note: There are also size limits and axle weight limits that you must not exceed either. Check with the Texas Department of Motor Vehicles for details. ["Texas Size and Weight Limits," Texas Department of Motor Vehicles, http://txdmv.gov/motor-carriers/oversize-overweight-permits/texas-size-weight-limits/32-motor-carriers/main-menu]

questions.question: What can a fire extinguisher with a B:C rating be used for?
questions.answer3: tire fires.
questions.explanation: A B:C fire extinguisher is suitable for a class B fire (which includes almost all flammable liquids) and is electrically non-conductive (hence its C rating). However, it should not be used on burning materials that you can use ordinary water on, such as wood, paper, and cloth. These require an A or A:B:C fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Objects viewed in a curved (convex) mirror may appear
questions.answer3: faster than they really are.
questions.answer4: farther away than they really are.
questions.explanation: Curved (convex) mirrors give you a wider field of view, but they make objects appear smaller and farther away than they really are. Keep this in mind when you're trying to judge distances.

questions.question: For a 17-foot load, how many tie-downs are required?
questions.explanation: The rule is that you should have one tie-down per 10 feet of cargo, and you must have at least two per load, regardless of the length. So for 17 feet, you should have two tie-downs.

questions.question: To obtain a CDL, you must demonstrate that you meet the requirements:
questions.answer1: you are not addicted to alcohol.
questions.answer2: you are not addicted to drugs.
questions.answer3: you are not an insulin-dependent diabetic.
questions.answer4: all of the above are true.
questions.explanation: Certain medical conditions can affect your ability to drive commercial motor vehicles (CMVs) safely. Under federal regulation 49 CFR 391.41, you may be considered medically unqualified to operate CMVs if your health suffers from certain medical conditions such as addiction to drugs or alcohol, cardiovascular disease, epilepsy, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, psychiatric illness, and so on. However, an exception (medical variance) may be granted if you can show that your medical condition won't significantly affect your ability to operate CMVs. Contact the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration for details.

questions.question: Why should you be extra cautious about drivers who are tourists?
questions.answer1: Because they aren't as smart as local drivers
questions.answer2: Because they may be unfamiliar with the area
questions.answer3: Because they won't know the local radio stations
questions.answer4: Because they are likely to be tired
questions.explanation: Confused drivers represent a hazard. They often change direction suddenly or stop without warning. Tourists unfamiliar with the area can be very hazardous. Clues to tourists include car-top luggage and out-of-state license plates. Use caution when driving near such vehicles.

questions.question: Is there a specific danger in transporting hanging meat?
questions.answer1: Its smell may make it difficult to find places to park.
questions.answer2: You may have to drive extra fast to get it delivered fresh.
questions.answer3: It may change your vehicle's handling characteristics.
questions.answer4: You may be confronted by animal rights protesters.
questions.explanation: Hanging meat carcasses have a high center of gravity and may sway on curves, changing the handling characteristics of your vehicle. Slow down and use caution on sharp curves such as on-ramps and off-ramps.

questions.question: You hear a noise that sounds like a tire blowout while driving a vehicle with twin tires. Your vehicle's handling, on the other hand, appears to be unaffected. So, what are your options?
questions.answer2: Check your tires at the next stop.
questions.answer3: Stop and check your tires now.
questions.answer4: Look in your mirrors to try to spot trouble.
questions.explanation: If a dual tire blows out, handling may not be affected – at first. However, the other tire will then have to carry the entire load, which may damage it too. If you hear what sounds like a blowout on a vehicle with dual tires, stop and check the tires.

questions.question: Why should you use a helper when you are backing?
questions.answer1: Because every truck has blind spots
questions.answer2: To make sure you don't damage your truck
questions.answer3: Because it's the law
questions.answer4: To check your style of driving
questions.explanation: You should use a helper when you are backing because you will be dealing with blind spots that you cannot see. Before you start, the two of you should agree on a set of hand signals for "Go" and (most importantly) "Stop."

questions.question: The minimum tire tread depth for front tires is
questions.answer3: 1/2 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels and any visible evidence of cracks or leaks.

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you
questions.answer1: avoid using your cell phone until you reach your destination.
questions.answer2: have all your emotionally difficult conversations in the first hour of driving.
questions.answer3: eat, drink, and smoke only on straight portions of the road.
questions.answer4: read maps or use your phone only when there are no other vehicles around you.
questions.explanation: A distraction is still a distraction, even on a straightaway or an empty road. Do not eat, drink, smoke, text, read, or have difficult conversations while driving. Avoid using your cell phone until you are done driving for the day.

questions.question: How can you determine if your vehicle is equipped with an antilock braking system (ABS)?
questions.answer1: Check for a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answer2: Check if your vehicle was manufactured after March 1, 1998. (Such vehicles are required to have the panel light.)
questions.answer3: Look for wheel speed sensor wires that are coming from the rear of your brakes.
questions.answer4: All of the above can work.
questions.explanation: Today, most vehicles with ABS have a light on the instrument panel that will light up briefly when the vehicle is started to alert you about the ABS. Or you can check for wires from your brakes.

questions.question: How do you get started without rolling backwards?
questions.answer1: Set the parking brake whenever necessary.
questions.answer2: Engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake.
questions.answer3: Apply the trailer brake hand valve.
questions.explanation: If you have a manual transmission vehicle, partly engage the clutch before you take your right foot off the brake. Set the parking brake whenever necessary to keep from rolling back. Release the parking brake only when you have applied enough engine power to keep from rolling back. On a tractor-trailer equipped with a trailer brake hand valve, the hand valve can be applied to keep from rolling back.

questions.question: If the engine is not overheated, is it completely safe to remove the radiator cap?
questions.answer3: Yes, as long as there is no overflow.
questions.answer4: Yes, as long as the radiator isn't damaged.
questions.explanation: It is not enough for the engine not to be overheated. The cooling system must cool completely before you attempt to remove the radiator cap. Even then, you should be very careful because there may still be tremendous pressure and damaging steam and fluids.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about an escape ramp is FALSE?
questions.answer1: It may be located a few miles from the top of a downgrade.
questions.answer2: It is of no use if you are traveling too fast.
questions.answer3: It may be made of soft gravel.
questions.explanation: Escape ramps are designed with soft gravel, upgrades, or both, to slow down vehicles that experience brake failure on a downgrade. Regardless of your speed, look for one of these escape ramps, which can save lives, equipment, and cargo. Find out ahead of time where the escape ramps are located on your route.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the basic shifting method?
questions.answer2: Pushing in the clutch and shifting into a higher gear at the same time
questions.answer3: Releasing the clutch and pressing the accelerator at the same time
questions.answer4: Accelerating while pressing the clutch and turning toward the driver's side
questions.explanation: You must release the accelerator, press the clutch and shift into neutral at the same time, release the clutch, let the engine and gears slow to the required rpm for the next gear, press the clutch and shift into a higher gear at the same time, then release the clutch and press the accelerator at the same time. Acceleration is not involved until the very end, and definitely not while pressing the clutch.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, what should you do?
questions.answer2: Ignore rude gestures and refuse to react negatively.
questions.answer3: Call the police from your cell phone if you can do it safely.
questions.explanation: If an aggressive driver is trying to confront you, do not give the person the confrontation that he or she seeks. Instead, seek police, peace, and safety.

questions.question: If you are traveling at 55 mph in a 30-foot vehicle, you should leave how many seconds of following distance?
questions.answer3: 3 seconds
questions.explanation: The formula for following distance is one second per ten feet of vehicle, plus an extra second if you are traveling over 40 mph. Therefore, for a 30-foot vehicle traveling at 55 mph, you should leave a following distance of 4 seconds.

questions.question: Always try to back toward the driver's side because
questions.answer1: it's more comfortable for turning your neck.
questions.answer2: you can see better, watching the vehicle's rear from the side window.
questions.answer3: your truck will probably pull toward the driver's side.
questions.answer4: all of the above are true.
questions.explanation: You should always back toward the driver's side because you will be able to see things much more easily. For example, you can keep an eye on the vehicle's rear by viewing it from your side window. If your truck pulls in either direction, it needs service. Your neck's comfort should not affect your safety decision.

questions.question: The minimum tire tread depth for front tires is
questions.answer3: 1/2 inch.
questions.explanation: Front tires require a tread depth of at least 4/32 inch. All other tires require a tread depth of at least 2/32 inch.

questions.question: You should inspect wheel bearing seals for
questions.answer3: tears.
questions.explanation: The most likely problem with wheel bearing seals is leaking, so you should check for grease on the wheels and any visible evidence of cracks or leaks.

questions.question: You don't want to be an abstracted driver, so you

questions.question: Letting the air out of hot tires
